Ecology: unknown

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 619, neotype, Diddens and Lodder
1942, p. 304, isolated from blastomycotic macroglossia, Sri Lanka;
CBS 6519, type strain of C. krissii, from seawater, Pacific Ocean.
Other strains available: CBS 641 and CBS 2328, from chilled beef,
Australia; CBS 947, from human throat; CBS 2000, from sputum,
Norway; CBS 2326, from dog’s skin, Austria; CBS 2329, origin
unknown; CBS 4909, from seawater, Florida; CBS 5122, from human
skin, Germany; CBS 5262, from skin of blue dolphin, Atlantic Ocean;
CBS 5446, 5447, from winter salami, Croatia; CBS 5718, from red clover,
Canada; CBS 6134, 6135, from human feces, Finland; CBS 6165,
from human, Finland; CBS 6391, 6408, 6409, 6410, 6411, all from sausages,
Spain.
Ecology:
The ITS sequence of C. zeylanoides (AY542871) differs by
only one substitution from a sequence deposited in GenBank
(AF035675) under the label Lacazia loboi (syn. Loboa loboi) and
obtained from direct amplification of material in lesions of a diseased
bottlenose dolphin. This casts doubt on the suggestion that the DNA
belonged to Cladosporium sphaerocarpum, as suggested by Haubold
et al. (1998). The putative agent of the infection is thought to be the
authentic Lacazia loboi, an unrelated dimorphic mold in the order
Onygenales (Herr et al. 2001). Taken together with the known
sources of isolation of C. zeylanoides, an association with warmblooded
animals, including marine species, is probable.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-7343-2 (CBS 390.77) and
NRRL Y-7343-6 (CBS 391.77), obtained as single-ascospore isolates
from the diploid type strain.
Ecology:
The single known strain of C. albidus was isolated from
cranberry pomace in Canada (Kurtzman 1977).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 121.29 (ATCC 36174, NRRL
Y-6742), isolated from a human ear, S. Hanawa, China?; CBS 150.61
(ATCC 12091, DAOM 33766), type strain of Ascocybe grovesii, from
pine (Pinus sp.) wood, D.E. Wells, Canada; CBS 183.71 (ATCC 22396),
type strain of Aureomyces mirabilis, from pine (Pinus sp.) wood, A.-L.
Ruokola, Finland; CBS 118.57, from pine (Pinus sp.) wood, A.
Mathiesen-Käärik, Sweden; CBS 184.63, from oak (Quercus sp.) wood,
A.F. Schippers-Lammertse, Japan.
Ecology:
The species was originally isolated from a human ear, but
its main ecological niche seems to be pine or oak wood in association
with bark insects. An extended description of the species was given
by Schippers-Lammertse and Heyting (1962).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-2407 (CBS 2764), isolated
from fermenting fruit in syrup, Spain, J. Santa María, type strain of
Hansenula matritensis; NRRL Y-11552, condensed milk, Spain, J. Santa
María; NRRL Y-7003, condensed milk, Netherlands; NRRL Y-1506
(CBS 162), type strain of Candida globosa, condensed milk, USA.
Complementary mating types: NRRL Y-2407-9 (CBS 7103) and NRRL
Y-2407-10 (CBS 7104), isolated following heat treatment of the
ascosporulating type strain (Wickerham 1958).
Ecology:
Citeromyces matritensis has been isolated only from food
products with high osmotic potential, such as fruit in syrup, sugar
and condensed milk. Sugar cane fluxes should be investigated as a
natural reservoir of C. matritensis, because known isolates are from
substrates containing cane sugar.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-27975 (CBS 9153, IFO 11052,
JCM 11522, TISTR 5777) isolated from dry salted squid, Pichit
Province, Thailand. A second strain (CBS 9152, IFO 11053, JCM 11523,
TISTR 5778) was isolated by Nagatsuka et al. (2002) from fermented
soybeans in Nakornsawan Province, Thailand.
Ecology:
The two known isolates of C. siamensis are from high
osmotic food products, but the occurrence of this species in natural
habitats is unknown.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 1944, clinical specimen,
E. Dietrichson, Norway, type strain of Candida obtusa; CBS 2866, clinical
specimen, The Netherlands; CBS 4870, clinical specimen,
Finland; CBS 4413, type strain of Candida lusitaniae; CBS 4414, and
CBS 4415, from pig digestive tract, N. van Uden, Portugal; CBS 5030,
South Africa; CBS 5094, clinical specimen, Germany; CBS 5299, from
milk of mastitic cow, Greece; CBS 5901, from crow droppings; CBS
6936, from peel juice of Citrus, R.I. Mateles, Israel; CBS 7270, received
by CBS as Candida kruisii, clinical specimen, A.J. Woodgyer, New
Zealand; MTCC 1001, from citrus, G.S. Prasad, India; SUB79-257.1,
from trunk rot of boojum tree (Idria columnaris, Fouquieriaceae), Baja
California N., Mexico; SUB79-267.12 and SUB86-460.5, both from
stem rot of agria cactus (Stenocereus gummosus, Cactaceae), Baja
California N., Mexico; SUB80-29, from leaf rot of Agave sp.
(Agavaceae), Arizona, U.S.A.; SUB86-287, from rotting tissue of cactus
(Cephalocereus russelianus), Venezuela; SUB86-780.2, from stem rot
of cactus (Cephalocereus hoppenstedtii), Mexico; SUB86-968.1, from
cladode rot of prickly pear (Opuntia ficus-indica), Florida, USA,
W.T. Starmer; UCD-FST 69-106, from wet dates, K.L. Boundy-Mills;
UCD-FST 81-467C, from cladode rot of prickly pear (Opuntia phaeacantha),
Arizona, USA, H.J. Phaff,; UWOPS83-1068.1 and UWOPS83-
1080.1, both from decaying fruit of prickly pear (Opuntia stricta),
Cayman Islands; UWOPS83-1156.2, both from fruit fly (Drosophila
bromeliae, Diptera, Drosophilidae) collected on morning glory
(Ipomoea sp., Convolvulaceae), Cayman Islands; UWOPS85-286.1,
from fruit fly (Drosophila carbonaria) collected on mesquite (Prosopis
juliflora, Fabaceae), Arizona, USA; UWOPSWN9-8 and UWOPSWN9-20,
both from effluents of chocolate factory, Ontario, Canada; UWOPS92-
209.1 and many others, from leaf rot of Agave tequilana, Jalisco, Mexico;
UWOPS92-308.1, crushed agave, UWOPS92-321.1 and others, from
Drosophila sp., Tequila distillery, Jalisco, Mexico; UWOPS93-323.1, from
leaf rot of Agave sp., Exumas Cays, Bahamas; UWOPS94-423.2,
from pulque aguamiel, Jalisco, Mexico; G90-207.5 and several
others, from necrotic tissue of various cacti, P.F. Ganter, Antigua; WM
1037,WM1038,WM 02.92,WM 02.196,WM02.348,WM 02.446, clinical
specimens, H.M. Daniel andW. Meyer, Australia.
Complementary mating types: CBS 6936, mating type h1 and CBS
4413, mating type h2.
Ecology:
The ecological niche of C. lusitaniae is ill-defined. Although
the yeast occurs in cactus, it cannot be considered cactophilic, having
been reported only occasionally in nearly 2000 samples (Starmer
et al. 1990). Several strains were recovered from necrotic cactus tissue
in Antigua by P.F. Ganter. Interestingly, these samples did not
yield any C. opuntiae as would normally be expected from that habitat.
In a study of yeasts associated with agave cultivated for tequila
production, Lachance (1993b) found C. lusitaniae to be the most
abundant species in acetic rots at the base of leaves in this plant.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UCD-FST 77-279 (CBS 7068) and UCDFST
78-540A (CBS 7069) are among hundreds of strains isolated from
various species of prickly pear (Cactaceae): in Australia, Opuntia
vulgaris (syn. O. monacantha), O. stricta, O. streptacantha, O. tomentosa;
in Venezuela, O. boldinghii, O. elatior; in Hawaii, USA, O. megacantha
(syn. O. ficus-indica); in Peru, Opuntia sp.; in Arizona, USA,
O. ficus-indica, O. phaeacantha; in Texas, USA, O. lindheimeri; in the
Bahamas, the Antilles, and the Caribbean, O. moniliformis, O. stricta
[UWOPS83-877.1 (ATCC 60725)]; in Mexico, O. ficus-indica, O. oricola,
O. wilcoxii, Nopalea (syn. Opuntia sp.); in Spain and South Africa,
O. ficus-indica; in Brazil, O. vulgaris (received from C.A. Rosa). Some
strains are from columnar cactus species, Stenocereus alamosensis,
S. griseus, S. hystrix, S. pruinosus, S. stellatus, Cephalocereus royenii
[UWOPS 83-718.1], C. lanuginosus, Myrtillocactus cochal. A few strains
were isolated from cactus flies: Drosophila mettleri and D. nigrospiracula
recovered on giant saguaro cactus (Carnegiea gigantea), Arizona,
USA; D. mulleri [UWOPS83-803.2 (ATCC 60724)] and D. mayaguana
collected on Opuntia spp., Caribbean. Several strains were recovered
from the prickly pear moth, Cactoblastis cactorum (Lepidoptera:
Pyralidae). Some strains (received from C.A. Rosa) were recovered
from feeding sites of the moth Sigelgaita (Lepidoptera: Pyralidae) sp.
in Pilosocereus arrabidae (Cactaceae) in Brazil. Strain UWOPS85-351.1
is from the exudate of an oak (Quercus emoryi (Fagaceae) growing in
the vicinity of cacti in Arizona, USA.
Complementary mating types: CBS 7068, mating type h1 and CBS
7069, mating type h2.
Ecology:
Although C. opuntiae occurs in decaying cactus fruit as well
as somatic tissue, the host specificity is remarkable, in view of the
worldwide distribution of the species. C. opuntiae, which is found in
10% of all prickly pear samples ever collected (Lachance et al. 1988b),
accounts for 5% of the yeasts isolated from prickly pears and 2% or
less of isolates from other cactus species (Starmer et al. 1990). Many
vectors (e.g., Drosophila spp.) are likely to contribute significantly
to the yeast's distribution, but the prickly pear moth, Cactoblastis
cactorum, is thought to play a major role in confining C. opuntiae
mostly to Opuntia spp., as the occurrence of the moth coincides to
some extent with the abundance of the yeast (Starmer et al. 1988a).
DNA fingerprinting (Lachance 1990a) and sequencing studies
(Lachance et al. 2000c) indicated that cacti may bear, in their
C. opuntiae biota, a genetically diverse resident component, and
additionally, a more homogeneous population associated with
C. cactorum. Rosa et al. (1992), working in the region of Rio de
Janeiro, Brazil, found C. opuntiae less frequently in Opuntia species than in the columnar cactus Pilosocereus arrabidae, where the yeast
appears to exist in association with the moth Sigelgaita sp.
Considerable inequalities have been observed in the distribution
of mating types within local populations. An h1:h2 ratio greater than
30:1 was observed among Australian isolates (Phaff et al. 1986), with
the nearly exact reverse in strains collected on the Bahamian Island of
Great Inagua (Lachance et al. 2000c). Brazilian isolates exhibited a
20:1 mating type ratio (Rosa et al. 1992). Even more extreme disparities
were found in the Hawaiian archipelago (Lachance et al. 2000c).
Specifically, 76 isolates collected on Maui Island all had mating type
h2. Some of these inequalities are attributed in part to the rapid
movement of bottlenecked populations of C. opuntiae, which is due to
the anthropogenic introduction of the moth Cactoblastis cactorum
used in the biological control of prickly pear cactus. Another factor
that may dampen the equalization of mating types in local population
is the fact that mating in C. opuntiae appears to require direct contact
between compatible cells, G1 arrest due to nitrogen starvation, and
fairly equal mixtures of the two mating types (Lachance et al. 1994).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
This organism has not been cultured and the description of this species
is the same as the generic description.
Type strain: Neotype material, collected in Drosophila melanogaster
intestine from Athens, Georgia, USA., has been deposited in the New
York Botanical Garden Cryptogamic Herbarium, and in the Julian
H. Miller Mycological Herbarium (GAM).

UCD-FST 92-2 and UCD-FST 73-90,
isolated from domestic rabbits, Davis, California, USA. These strains
are no longer available. Additional strains available for analysis
include CBS 8137 and CBS 8666, from rabbits in the UK and USA,
respectively, and NRRL Y-17561, from domestic rabbit dung, Peoria,
Illinois, USA.
Ecology:
Cyniclomyces guttulatus was first observed in the stomach
and intestinal contents of a rabbit and certain other herbivores
by Remak (1845), but he did not find the species in carnivores, birds
or reptiles. These observations were confirmed by Robin (1853).
Cells were observed by Cochet (1940) in rabbit, but not cultured,
and were also seen in low abundance in rat and cavia. The species is
prevalent and easily isolated from the alimentary tract and feces of
hay- or straw-fed rabbits, but not milk-fed rabbits (Rolle and
Mehnert 1957). Buecher and Phaff (1972) isolated an atypical dimorphic
filamentous strain of C. guttulatus from wild jack rabbit.
Shifrine and Phaff (1958) proposed that coprophagy of the soft night
feces, which have a higher viable yeast population, replenishes the
colonization of this species in the rabbit stomach. The necessity for
coprophagy to maintain the population in the rabbit stomach is not
supported by the high number of proliferating C. guttulatus cells
observed by Zierdt et al. (1988) in the mucus layer of the rabbit
stomach .
In a survey of the yeast flora of a variety of mammals, C. guttulatus
was found in the alimentary tract of all 30 rabbits examined, but
not in that of cows, pigs, opossums, sheep, monkeys, cats, dogs,
hedgehogs, mice, guinea pigs and rats (Parle 1957). However, cells
with the distinctive large-celled morphology of this species have
been observed associated with dogs (Houwers and Blankenstein
2001, Neel et al. 2006). Zierdt et al. (1988) observed numerous ascospores
in guinea pig fecal pellets.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 5167 (JCM 2387, NRRL Y-7425), isolated
by Saëz (1960) from feces of the emperor penguin (Aptenodytes

Ecology: unknown

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 789 (JCM 2104, NRRL Y-17914),
isolated from interdigital mycotic lesion; JCM 1441 (CBS 6066, NRRL
Y-7500), type strain of Pichia adzetii, from tanning liquor; JCM 1527,

et al. 2008).
Ecology:
The ecology of D. fabryi is uncertain. As seen under “Origin
of the strains studied”, approximately half of known isolates are
from skin infections, whereas other strains are from sake and rice
vinegar fermentations.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 767 (NRRL Y-7426, JCM 1990), a
strain with the name Saccharomyces hansenii, which was deposited
in the CBS Collection and had been received from the Carlsberg
Laboratory; JCM 1521 (CBS 1795, NRRL Y-173), type strain of
Torulopsis famata; JCM 1526 (CBS 770, NRRL Y-1449), type strain of
Debaryomyces kloeckeri; JCM 2091 and JCM 2094, from cheeses in
Japan; CBS 766 (NRRL Y-1458), cheese; CBS 773 and CBS 791, from
sausages; JCM 2098 (CBS 766, NRRL Y-1458), type strain of
Debaryomyces tyrocola; JCM 2105, as Debaryomyces hudeloi; JCM
2106 (CBS 790, NRRL Y-1451), type strain of Debaryomyces gruetzii;
JCM 2107, type strain of Debaryomyces laedegaardi; JCM 2108 (CBS
787), type strain of Debaryomyces matruchoti; JCM 2109 (CBS 788,
NRRL Y-1452), type strain of Debaryomyces hildegaardi; JCM 2110
(CBS 791), Debaryomyces matruchoti var. cesarii; JCM 2111 (CBS
2333), type strain of Debaryomyces sake, from sake moto; JCM 2112,
type strain of Debaryomyces membranaefaciens var. zingiberi;
JCM 2113, type strain of Debaryomyces miso var. 1; JCM 2114,
Debaryomyces marylandii; JCM 2115, Debaryomyces membranaefaciens
var. hollandicus; JCM 2160 (CBS 773), type strain of Debaryomyces guilliermondii;
JCM 2161 (CBS 772), type strain of Debaryomyces kloeckeri
var. major; CBS 2331 (JCM 2162), type strain of Debaryomyces miso,
from edomiso; JCM 2163 (CBS 812), Debaryomyces nicotianae var.
minor; JCM 2165 (CBS 161), Torulopsis minor; CBS 772, from rennet;
CBS 811 (NRRL Y-1454), type strain of Debaryomyces nicotianae,
from tobacco; CBS 161, from psoriasis; CBS 790 (NRRL Y-1451), from
infected nails; CBS 5704, type strain of Torulopsis westerdijkii, from
infected hand; CBS 770 (NRRL Y-1449), from patient with angina; CBS
788 (NRRL Y-1452), from a wound; JCM 2213, from salmon (shake in
Japanese); nine strains, unknown.
Ecology:
Debaryomyces hansenii is widespread in nature, and is commonly
isolated from soil, the phylloplane of certain plants (Fonseca
and Inacio 2006), the marine environment (Fell 1976), fermented soy
products (Hanya and Nakadai 2003), cheeses (Frölich-Wyder 2003) and similar products, many of which are high in salt (Prista et al.
2005). However, as discussed in the systematics section, above,
D. hansenii is a member of a closely related group of species that are
difficult to separate using phenotypic tests, and it is likely that
strains within this species group have been misidentified in the preceding
studies, which will bias the ecological assessment for this
species.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 1958 (JCM 1528, NRRL Y-2171),
isolated from air in New Zealand, M. di Menna; CBS 4264 (JCM 6179,
NRRL Y-7427), from cider; CBS 1794 (JCM 6178), from a possible case
of human disease; CBS 6905 (JCM 6277), from soil, Iran.
Ecology: unknown

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 8300 (G-398), CBS 8298 (G-393),
CBS 8299 (G-395) and CBS 8301 (G-399), isolated from the gut of
woodlice (Armadillidium vulgare) on leaf litter in a mixed oak pine
forest, Yalta, Ukraine.
Ecology:
Debaryomyces mycophilus is known only from the guts of
woodlice collected in Ukraine. D. mycophilus satisfies its nutritional
requirement for iron by metabolizing a siderophore in the host, but
iron can be utilized in culture by the addition of ferrichrome or high
concentrations of FeCl3 (Thanh et al. 2002).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 5921 (JCM 2095, NRRL Y-7108),
isolated from soil in Nepal; CBS 1325 (JCM 2164), from fermenting

2334, from sediment in spoiled sake, type strain of Debaryomyces
japonicus; JCM 2209 (IFO 0085), unknown source; IFM 54257, from a
dog (Moretti et al. 2007).
Ecology:
Unknown. Strains have been isolated from soil, sake and
other substrates (see above).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 8450 (JCM 9913, NRRL Y-27369),
isolated from exudate of a mesquite tree (Prosopis juliflora), Arizona,

Ecology:
Phaff et al. (1998) reported isolation of nine strains of
D. prosopidis, five from exudates of mesquite trees and four from

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-6670 (CBS 2934), isolated
from a larval feed of the South African carpenter bee (Xylocopa caffra);
NRRL Y-7680 (CBS 5637), from pollen carried by a South African
carpenter bee, both strains from Transvaal, South Africa, J.P. van der
Walt.
Ecology:
Debaryomyces robertsiae appears to be associated with carpenter
bees in South Africa (van der Walt 1959a).

Debaryomyces udenii is known from two soil samples collected

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 74, (ATCC 36234, IFO 1590, NRRL

(1), sherry (1).
Ecology:
The presence of the species on the surface of grape berries
was shown by Renauf and Lonvaud-Funel (2007).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6740 (ATCC 32435, NRRL Y-7931,

Strains of D. anomala have been isolated exclusively from
soil.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 759.85 (NRRL Y-12690), isolated

Ecology:
Unknown, but the single strain was isolated from a cutting
of beech in Hungary.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 190.37 (NRRL Y-17583), isolated from a dead pupa of a fruit fly
(Drosophila melanogaster), Canada, R. Biggs; CBS 740.74 (NRRL Y-
1268), from a fruit fly, E.M. Mrak.
Ecology:
The few known isolates of D. uninucleata have been isolated
from fruit flies in North America.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 741.74 (NRRL Y-2181), from a fruit fly (Drosophila melanogaster),
H.J. Phaff.
Ecology:
The few known isolates of D. uninucleata have been isolated
from fruit flies in North America.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 175.53 (NRRL Y-17564), isolated

152.57, from frass of Ips pini in root of red pine (Pinus resinosa,

Ecology:
The species is obligately associated with bark beetles that
occur under the bark of pine trees (Batra 1963d, 1967).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 766.85 (NRRL Y-12859, IFO 1984),

Ecology:
Dipodascus albidus is only known from exudates of deciduous
trees (Batra 1959).

Paragraph of Species Studied:

ATCC 36758), type strain of Geotrichum armillariae, isolated from gills

unknown source.
Ecology:
The species is thus far only known from basidiocarps of
Armillaria species in the Northern Hemisphere. Asci are only produced
on the natural substrate during a short period in October.
Single-spore isolations invariably gave the Geotrichum anamorph
with characteristic chlamydospores (de Hoog et al. 1986).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 625.74 (NRRL Y-17565, IFO 10805,
ATCC 36746), isolated from rotting cladodes of the cactus Opuntia

from Euphorbia ingens, Pretoria, South Africa, J.P. van der Walt; UOFS
Y 0065, unknown.
Ecology:
The species seems to be restricted to rotten fruits and
leaves of succulents in desert areas.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 184.80 (NRRL Y-17628, IFO 10806),
isolated from guava (Psidium guajaua, Myrtaceae) pulp, V.P. Bhide,
Maharastra, India.
Ecology: The species is very likely associated with fruits.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 259.82 (NRRL Y-17586, IFO
10807, IMI 263027) and CBS 260.82, both isolated from the slime
trail of the myxomycete Badhamia utricularis, M.F. Madelin and
A. Feest, UK.
Ecology:
Isolates of this rare, homothallic species have only been
found on myxomycete thalli.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
TRTC 47587, dried specimen on old carpophore
of Cortinarius huronensis, Ontario, Canada (Redhead and
Malloch 1977).
Ecology:
The type strain of the species has been found on Cortinarius
huronensis in Canada (Redhead and Malloch 1977).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
Rehm Ascom. 1050 (TRTC), on
Armillaria mellea (Agaricales), Krieger, Germany.
Ecology:
The type strain of the species has been found on basidiocarps
of the honey mushroom (Armillaria, Agaricales) in Germany.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS-H 1225, on a polypore (Piptoporus
soloniensis), T. Schumacher, Thailand.
Ecology:
The species has been found on Piptoporus soloniensis
(Aphyllophorales) in Thailand.

Paragraph of Species Studied: Type specimen: PBR M 13/84.
Ecology:
The type strain (PBR M 13/84) of the species has been
found on an agaric.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 106.43 (ex CBS 204.36, NRRL Y-
1360), isolated from cotton, Sudan, V. Massey and A. Guilliermond;
NRRL Y-1363 (ATCC 12995), origin unknown, C. Thaysen; NRRL Y-
7249, from stained cotton bolls, South Africa, W.F.O. Marasas.
Ecology:
Eremothecium ashbyi, as noted below, is a pathogen of cotton
and citrus, and occurs in warmer parts of the northern and southern
hemispheres where these crops are normally grown (Batra 1973).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-12970 (CBS 2608, UCD-FST
66-36, IFO 1220), isolated by V. Peglion in 1897 from diseased hazelnuts
in Italy; CBS 2599 from cotton bolls, Democratic Republic of the
Congo (Belgian Congo); CBS 2600 from cotton bolls, USA; CBS 2601
from tomatoes, British West Indies; CBS 2604, origin not known; CBS
79, from cotton bolls, India (type strain of Nematospora nagpuri); IGC
3027, from Phaseolus vulgaris, Uganda; NRRL Y-1808, from lima
beans, USA; IFO 0658, from A. J. Kluyver, origin not known.
Ecology:
Eremothecium coryli is found in tropical and subtropical
areas of the world as an insect-transmitted pathogen of cotton,
hazelnuts, lima beans, soybeans and tomatoes (Batra 1973).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 270.75 (NRRL Y-17582), isolated
from a plant pathogenic insect, Iran, D. Ershad.
Ecology:
The ecology of this species is probably similar to other species
in the genus, i.e., a plant pathogen associated with plant-feeding
insects, but because only a single strain is known, the ecology
remains speculative.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
Pridham and Raper (1950) and Batra (1973) have provided
extensive documentation of the distribution of E. gossypii and most
other members of Eremothecium. E. gossypii is commonly found in
tropical and subtropical areas of the world as a pathogen of coffee
(Coffea spp.), cotton (Gossypium spp.), soybean (Glycine max) and
other crops. The species appears to be vectored by insects.
Ecology:
CBS 109.26, isolated from fruit of the
scarlet milkweed (Asclepias curassavica, Asclepidaceae) Trinidad, S.F.
Ashby; NRRL Y-1056 (CBS 109.51, ATCC 10895), a high riboflavin producing
strain (Tanner et al. 1948); CBS 117.28, France, A. Guilliermond.

At present, E. sinecaudum is known only from infected mustard
seed of crops grown in Canada (Hemingway 1980, Holley et al.
1984). Possibly the species is spread by plant-feeding insects.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 109.12, isolated from milk, USA;
CBS 110.12, probably the authentic strain for Oidium humi; CBS
121.22, from common hyacinth (Hyacinthus orientalis), Netherlands,
C.M. Berkhout; CBS 122.22, authentic strain for Oospora fragrans var.
minuta, from banana, C.M. Berkhout; CBS 114.23, authentic strain for
Oidium nubilum, C.M. Berkhout; CBS 116.23, authentic strain for
Oospora lactis var. parasitica, from a rotten tomato, F.J. Pritchard and
W.S. Porte, Maryland, USA; CBS 149.26, authentic strain for Oidium
asteroides, A. Castellani; CBS 176.28, from the fruit of a durian (Durio
zibethinus, Malvaceae), A. van Luijk; CBS 178.30, type strain of Oospora
lactis var. exuberans, from poplar (Populus sp., Salicaceae) sap, W.
Stautz, Germany; CBS 180.33, authentic strain for Geotrichum matalense
var. chapmanii; CBS 182.33, type strain of Geotrichum javanense,
from yoghurt, O.R. Verona; CBS 193.34, type strain of Geotrichum
versiforme, M. Moore; CBS 195.35, authentic strain for Geotrichum
matalense, A. Castellani; CBS 178.53, type strain of Endomyces lactis,
S. Windisch; CBS 184.56, from human tongue, Germany, G.A. de Vries;
CBS 178.71, from soil polluted with oil, Germany, homothallic; CBS
476.83, from soil, Senegal, J.A. von Arx; CBS 557.83, type strain of
Geotrichum novakii, from prune, Egypt, J. Zsolt; CBS 279.84, type strain
of Geotrichum redaellii, H. Saëz; CBS 615.84, from Brie cheese, France;
CBS 357.86, unknown. Additional strains examined: from milk (one),
tomato (one), human nail (one), light oil (one), grain (one), soil (two),
fruit (one) and insect (one).
Complementary mating types: Mating type a: CBS 557.83, CBS
357.86. Mating type ?: CBS 180.33, CBS 476.83.
Ecology:
Galactomyces candidus, better known under the anamorphic
name Geotrichum candidum, is world-wide in distribution. The species
is common in all kinds of moist substrates, particularly in fruits
and tomatoes, mainly as the cause of rot in ripe fruits. The species
may occur in a relatively early stage of fruit development and hence
it has been presumed to be a weak pathogen. In other nutrient-rich
substrates, Geo. candidum unambiguously occurs as a saprophyte,
e.g., in silage (O'Brien et al. 2005a), and in lipid-containing materials
such as milk, cream and cheese (Marcellino et al. 2001, Prillinger
et al. 1999). The species occasionally occurs as an opportunist in the
pulmonary system and the digestive tract of humans and other animals
(de Hoog et al. 2000).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 175.89 (NRRL Y-17913, IFO
10822), isolated from soil of an orange orchard, Zimbabwe,
E.E. Butler; CBS 176.89 (NRRL Y-17923), from soil of an orange
orchard, California, USA, E.E. Butler. Other strains examined: from
citrus (three), from soil (four).
Complementary mating types: Mating type A1: CBS 228.38, CBS
175.89, CBS 604.85, CBS 246.96, and CBS 248.96. Mating type A2:
CBS 176.89, CBS 605.85, CBS 247.96, and CBS 249.96.
Ecology:
The species has been found on citrus fruit or in the soil of
citric fruit orchards.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 772.71 (ATCC 22600, NRRL
Y-17569, strain Pr-11), E.E. Butler, homothallic, and CBS 773.71
(ATCC 22601, strain Pr-47), E.E. Butler, both isolated from soil,
Puerto Rico; CBS 774.71 (strain Pr-47A1), E.E. Butler, and CBS 775.71
(strain Pr-47A2), E.E. Butler, both isolated from CBS 773.71 (strain
Pr-47).
Complementary mating types: Mating type A1: CBS 774.71. Mating
type A2: CBS 775.71.
Ecology:
The few strains of the species available have been recovered
from soil supporting the growth of unidentified grasses in Puerto
Rico (Butler and Peterson 1970).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 820.71, isolated from paper pulp,

CBS 179.60 (NRRL Y-17566, IFO
10823), from water-rotted brown Indian hemp (kenaf) (Hibiscus

Known isolates are associated with decaying plant material

CBS 109.12, isolated from milk, USA;

CBS 178.71, from soil polluted with oil, Germany, homothallic; CBS

Geotrichum novakii, from prune, Egypt, J. Zsolt; CBS 279.84, type strain
of Geotrichum redaellii, H. Saëz; CBS 615.84, from Brie cheese, France;
CBS 357.86, unknown. Additional strains examined: from milk (one),

fruit (one) and insect (one).
Complementary mating types: Mating type a: CBS 557.83, CBS
357.86. Mating type ?: CBS 180.33, CBS 476.83.
Ecology:
Galactomyces candidus, better known under the anamorphic
name Geotrichum candidum, is world-wide in distribution. The species
is common in all kinds of moist substrates, particularly in fruits
and tomatoes, mainly as the cause of rot in ripe fruits. The species
may occur in a relatively early stage of fruit development and hence
it has been presumed to be a weak pathogen. In other nutrient-rich
substrates, Geo. candidum unambiguously occurs as a saprophyte,
e.g., in silage (O'Brien et al. 2005a), and in lipid-containing materials
such as milk, cream and cheese (Marcellino et al. 2001, Prillinger
et al. 1999). The species occasionally occurs as an opportunist in the
pulmonary system and the digestive tract of humans and other animals
(de Hoog et al. 2000).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 9891 (NRRL Y-27727), isolated
from the gut of Lelis sp. (Carabidae: Coleoptera), on a basidiocarp of
Thelephora sp., Barro Colorado Island, Panama.
Ecology:
Geotrichum carabidarum has been found in the guts of
Coleoptera and Lepidoptera species (Suh and Blackwell 2006).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 175.89 (NRRL Y-17913, IFO
10822), isolated from soil of an orange orchard, Zimbabwe,
E.E. Butler; CBS 176.89 (NRRL Y-17923), from soil of an orange

Complementary mating types: Mating type A1: CBS 228.38, CBS
175.89, CBS 604.85, CBS 246.96, and CBS 248.96. Mating type A2:
CBS 176.89, CBS 605.85, CBS 247.96, and CBS 249.96.
Ecology:
The species has been found on citrus fruit or in the soil of
citric fruit orchards.

The species has been found in the gut of different species
of Coleoptera (Suh and Blackwell 2006).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 817.71 (NRRL Y-17580, IFO 10802,
ATCC 36758), type strain of Geotrichum armillariae, isolated from gills

818.71, CBS 834.71, CBS 540.76, CBS 623.82, CBS 624.82, CBS 600.83,
all from gills of the Armillaria mellea species aggregate; CBS 165.29,
unknown source.
Ecology:
The species is thus far only known from basidiocarps of
Armillaria species in the Northern Hemisphere. Asci are only produced
on the natural substrate during a short period in October.
Single-spore isolations invariably gave the Geotrichum anamorph
with characteristic chlamydospores (de Hoog et al. 1986).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 866.68, isolated from soil of wheat
field, Germany, W. Gams.
Ecology:
Unknown, because the species is based on a single strain
isolated from wheat field soil.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 409.34 (CBS 5057), isolated from

451.83 (CBS 2143), CBS 452.83 (CBS 2264), from tanned sheep skin;
IGC 3556, from a California black oak (Quercus kelloggii, Fagaceae).

The species has been reported on grapes, cherries and
oranges (Lugauskas et al. 2006).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 9892 (NRRL Y-27729), isolated
from the gut of a histerid beetle (Plagiogramma schmidti, Histeridae:

The species has been found in the gut of Coleoptera and
Lepidoptera species in Panama (Suh and Blackwell 2006).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 179.30 (NRRL Y-17568, IFO
10826), isolated from slime flux of a yew (Taxus baccata, Taxaceae),
W. Stautz; CBS 196.35, from wood pulp, E. Rennerfelt; CBS 627.74
(CBS 5586, ATCC 18019), type strain of Trichosporon penicillatum,
from slime flux of an elm (Ulmus sp., Ulmaceae), H.J. Phaff; CBS
511.83 (CBS 2463), from sewage filter, T.G. Tomlinson.
Ecology:
This species frequently occurs in slime fluxes of trees, and is
probably selected by high concentrations of sugars in this substrate.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 820.71, isolated from paper pulp,
France, homothallic; CBS 267.79, from a beet (Beta vulgaris,
Chenopodiaceae), Netherlands, J.W. Veenbaas-Rijks; CBS 626.83, type
strain of Geotrichum pseudocandidum, from the stomach of an elk,
Paris, France, H. Saëz; CBS 100812, from the bark of a beech log
(Fagus sylvatica, Fagaceae), Switzerland, R. Neal Band; CBS 101161
(UAMH 402), from a sewage treatment filter, England, H.A. Painter;
CBS 101162, from soil, near Lydenburg, South Africa, J.P. van der
Walt; CBS 101163, from soil, South Africa, J.P. van der Walt.
Ecology: The species seems to occur in wood and soil.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 111234, endophyte isolated from
a Norway spruce (Picea abies, Pinaceae), Sweden, isolated by
R. Vasiliauskas.
Ecology:
The only strain available was isolated as an endophyte of
Picea abies in Sweden.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 8821 (UWO-PS 87-2370.1, NRRL
Y 27515), isolated from stem rot of a lobelioid plant (Clermontia
spp., Campanulaceae) Hawaii, USA, M.-A. Lachance; CBS 8822 (UWOPS
87-2440.2), from stem rot of Clermontia sp., Hawaii, USA, M.-A.
Lachance (Cadez et al. 2003).
Ecology:
Lachance et al. (2005) reported that H. clermontiae might
be endemic to the Hawaiian Islands.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 465 (ATCC 10630, NRRL Y-1625),
isolated from infected nail, South Africa, A. Pijper; CBS 95, fermenting
bottled tomatoes, The Netherlands, G. van Rhee; CBS 466 (No. 88
in Melliger 1931), dates (Phoenix dactylifera) originating from Egypt,
deposited by R. Chodat, type strain of Hanseniaspora melligeri; CBS
1972, grape juice, Italy, T. Castelli, authentic strain of Hanseniaspora
apuliensis; CBS 2567, grape must, Israel, A. Capriotti; CBS 2574, grape
juice, Italy, A. Capriotti; CBS 2591, bee trachea, France, R. Chauvin,
type strain of Kloeckera apis; CBS 4378, cecum of baboon, L. do
Carmo Sousa; CBS 5060, culture contaminant, H.J. Phaff; CBS 6619
(AJ 5176), unknown, T. Nakase (Nakase and Komagata 1970a).
Ecology:
Hanseniaspora guilliermondii is a widespread species, associated
mainly with various fruits (Abranches et al. 2000, Trindade
et al. 2002), insects (Morais et al. 1992, 1995b, 1996), plants (Yurkov
and Chernov 2005) and fermenting musts. However, the type strain
was isolated from clinical material (Pijper 1928).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 8818 (UWO-PS 92-218.1, NRRL
Y-27514), isolated from fermenting agave juice (Agave tequilana),
Mexico; CBS 8819 (UWO-PS 92-232.4), Drosophila sp., fermenting
agave juice, Mexico (Cadez et al. 2003); CBS 9197 (UWO-PS
92-221.1), fermenting agave juice, Mexico, M.-A. Lachance.
Ecology:
The three strains of this species were isolated from fermenting
agave juice and from Drosophila spp. captured inside a traditional
tequila distillery in Mexico (Lachance 1995).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 8734 (UWO-PS 91-661.1, NRRL
Y-27513), isolated from from fruit of soapberry (Sapindus sp.,
Sapindaceae), Hawaii, USA, M.-A. Lachance; CBS 8771 (NCAIM Y.725),
from spoiled grape punch, Georgia, USA, T. Deak; CBS 8773, CBS 8774,
CBS 8775, isolated from flowers of Schotia sp. (Fabaceae) tree, South
Africa, P. Meyer; CBS 8815 (UWO-PS 91-643.1), CBS 8823 (UWO-PS 91-
732.2), isolated from drosophilids on berries of Sapindus sp., Hawaii,
USA, M.-A. Lachance (Cadez et al. 2003); CBS 9195 (UWO-PS 87-
2361.1), from stem rot of lobelioid (Clermontia sp., Camapnulaceae),
Hawaii, USA; CBS 9196 (UWO-PS 91-637.1), from drosophilid species
on berries of Sapindus sp., Hawaii, USA, M.-A. Lachance.
Ecology:
Hanseniaspora meyeri has been isolated mainly from natural
habitats (flowers, fruits, stem rots and drosophilids) in Hawaii and
South Africa. However, its presence in spoiled grape punch in
Georgia, USA, suggests its association with a man-made environment
as well (Cadez et al. 2003a).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6782,
CBS 6783, isolated from orange juice, Italy, A.M. van Grinsven; CBS
9921 (DBVPG 4654), CBS 9922 (DBVPG 4656), rotten orange, Argentina.
Ecology:
The variety occidentalis was mostly isolated from soil, whereas
the variety citrica was isolated from oranges and their products (Cadez
et al. 2006). On the basis of incongruent gene genealogies, Cadez et al.
(2006) predicted that the two varieties of H. occidentalis are isolated by
habitat preference. Additionally, Morais et al. (1992) found a specialized
association between H. occidentalis with Drosophila melanogaster in an
urbanwooded area in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. They suggested that this association
reflects specific physiological profiles of H. occidentalis and the availability
of a sucrose-rich food source for D. melanogaster at this location.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2592 (ATCC
32053, NRRL Y-7946), isolated from soil, West Indies, St. Croix,
H. Kufferath, type strain of Pseudosaccharomyces occidentalis; CBS 280,
from soil, West Indies, St. Thomas, Ö. Winge, type strain of
Pseudosaccharomyces antillarum; CBS 282, from soil, Java, H. Kufferath,
type strain of Pseudosaccharomyces javanicus; CBS 283 (NCTC 494), from
soil, Java, A. Klöcker, type strain of Pseudosaccharomyces jensenii; CBS 284
(NCTC 489), from soil, Java, A. Klöcker; CBS 2569, Drosophila sp., Brazil;
CBS 2578 (NCTC 488), from soil, West Indies, St. Thomas, A. Klöcker; CBS
6623 (AJ 5195), CBS 6624 (AJ 5197), unknown, T. Nakase (Nakase and
Komagata 1970a).

CBS 8733 (UWO-PS 87-2121.3, NRRL Y-
27512), isolated from cactus (Opuntia ficus-indica) rot, Hawaii, USA;
CBS 8820 (UWO-PS 87-2120.3), Opuntia ficus-indica rot, Hawaii, USA,
M.-A. Lachance (Cadez et al. 2003); CBS 9791 (FST, UNSW E90), grapes
fromvineyards, New SouthWales, Australia, A.L. Beh.
Ecology:
Hanseniaspora opuntiae was found to be primarily associated
with Cactaceae in the Hawaiian islands (Cadez et al. 2003).
Later the species was also isolated from grape berries in Australia
(strain CBS 9791) and in Greece (Nisiotou and Nychas 2007).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 313 (ATCC 24231, NRRL Y-1613),
isolated from Riesling grapes, Germany, K. Kroemer and
G. Krumbholz; CBS 105 (ATCC 10640, NRRL Y-1611), from grapes,
Italy, T. Castelli, type strain of Pseudosaccharomyces magnus; CBS 106
(ATCC 10635, NRRL Y-1381), from tree bark, Denmark, A. Klöcker,
type strain of Pseudosaccharomyces corticis; CBS 1999, from soil, West
Indies, A. Klöcker, type strain of Pseudosaccharomyces santacruzensis;
CBS 2157, from flower of Trifolium repens, Denmark, A. Lund; CBS
4266, from cider, UK, F.W. Beech; CBS 6554 (ATCC 20111), origin
unknown, Takeda Chem. Ind. Ltd.; CBS 6622 (IFO 0670), origin
unknown; CBS 6704 (AJ 5172), origin unknown, T. Nakase (Nakase
and Komagata 1970a); NCAIM Y.726, from pineapple juice concentrate,
Georgia, USA, T. Deak.
Ecology:
Hanseniaspora osmophila is found mainly in association
with different parts of plants (fruits, flowers, bark), soil, honeydew
systems of Southern beech (Nothofagus sp.) (Serjeant et al. 2008) and
in fruit-based fermented food such as vinegar and wine (Bujdoso
et al. 2002, Hierro et al. 2006a, Solieri et al. 2006).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 8772 (NCAIM Y.741), isolated
from orange juice concentrate, Georgia, USA.
Ecology:
The only known strain of H. pseudoguilliermondii was isolated
from orange juice concentrate.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 314 (ATCC 32369, NRRL Y-1614),
isolated from Muscat grape, Russia, C.J.G. Niehaus; CBS 104 (ATCC
32856), unknown, Ö. Winge, type strain of Pseudosaccharomyces apiculatus;
CBS 279, unknown, Central Laboratory, South Manchurian
Railway (CLSMR), type strain of Kloeckera brevis; CBS 286 (ATCC
10639), from soil, Java, NCTC, type strain of Pseudosaccharomyces
malaianus and Kloeckera lindneri var. pelliculosa; CBS 287, from soil,
Java, Ö. Winge, type strain of Pseudosaccharomyces muelleri; CBS 312,
from fermenting cacao, Ghana, H.A. Dade; CBS 2566, from fruit fly of
the Drosophila obscura group, H.J. Phaff; CBS 2570, from Drosophila
sp., Brazil, A.M. El-Tabey; CBS 2579 (NCTC 492), from soil, Austria, A.
Klöcker, type strain of Pseudosaccharomyces austriacus; CBS 2580,
from soil, H. Kufferath, type strain of Pseudosaccharomyces germanicus;
CBS 2582, from throat, The Netherlands, N.G.M. Orie; CBS 2583,
from fermenting cucumber brine, USA, J.L. Etchells; CBS 2585, from
sour dough, Portugal, N. van Uden, type strain of Kloeckera lodderi;
CBS 2586, from caterpillar, N. van Uden; CBS 2587, from fruit must,
Austria, A. Szilvinyi, authentic strain of K1loeckera brevis var. rohrbachense;
CBS 2588, from tanning fluid, France, J. Boidin; CBS 5073,
from wine grape, Chile, J. Grinbergs; CBS 5450, from seawater,
Florida, USA, S.A. Meyer; CBS 6617 (AJ 4800), from banana (Musa
sapientum), Japan, T. Nakase (Nakase and Komagata 1970a); and 12
additional strains isolated from soil (1), seawater (3), cider (1),
unknown (2), fruit must (2), fresh water (3).
Ecology:
Hanseniaspora uvarum is a widespread yeast species, most
frequently isolated from soil, insects, various fruits and fermenting
musts. It has also been collected from marine and freshwater ecosystems
(de Araujo et al. 1995, Hagler and Mendonca-Hagler 1981) as
well as medical samples (García-Martos et al. 1999). Detailed ecological
studies by Miller and Phaff (1962), Spencer et al. (1992) and
Morais et al. (1995b) showed that H. uvarum and other apiculate
yeast species are the most frequently isolated yeasts that colonize
mature fruits and, moreover, cause their fermentative spoilage.
Additionally, they showed that these apiculate yeasts are dispersed
and served as food for Drosophila spp.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 479 (ATCC 10631, NRRL Y-1626),
isolated from soil, Denmark, A. Klöcker; CBS 281 (NRRL Y-1382), from tree exudate, Japan, type strain of Kloeckera japonica; CBS 311,
from beer, Hungary, H. de Graaf; CBS 480, origin unknown, Ö.
Winge; CBS 481 (ATCC 2108), origin unknown, W.L. Miller; CBS 2590,
from draught beer, UK, isolated by A.E. Wiles; CBS 6558 (NRRL
Y-7575), from pulque, Mexico, C.P. Kurtzman, type strain of Kloeckera
corticis var. pulquensis; CBS 6618, from tomato, Japan, T. Nakase;
NCYC 468, from spoiled beer, L. Hemmons; NCYC 766, origin
unknown, R.R. Davenport; NCAIM Y.642, from cauliflower, California,
T. Török; NCAIM Y.330, origin unknown, F. Kevei.
Ecology:
The ecology of H. valbyensis is similar to that of other apiculate
species, because most strains have been isolated from soil, various
parts of plants and fermented beverages. Morais et al. (1992)
reported isolating the species from Drosophila spp. in the forests of
Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. H. valbyensis, H. guilliermondii and H. occidentalis
were the most frequently isolated yeast species, which suggests a
close association of these species with Drosophila spp.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2171 (ATCC 58436), isolated from
soil in a vineyard, South Africa, J.P. van der Walt; CBS 277 (ATCC
24232), from soil, Algeria, A. Klöcker, type strain of Pseudosaccharomyces
africanus; CBS 2568, from Drosophila persimilis, H.J. Phaff; CBS
2827, from soil, Sardinia, A. Capriotti; CBS 5068, origin unknown,
O. Verona; CBS 6555 (ATCC 20109), unknown, Takeda Chem. Ind.; CBS
6706, origin unknown, T. Nakase; CBS 8031 (ATCC 46412), type strain
of Hanseniaspora nodinigri, from black knot gall on chokeberry (Prunus
virginiana, Rosaceae) Canada, M.-A. Lachance; ATCC 10632, from sour
Calimyrna fig (a variety of Ficus carica), California; ATCC 16512, origin
unknown, Kyowa Ferm. Ind. Co., Ltd.
Ecology:
Strains of H. vineae were mostly obtained from soil, insects
and fruits worldwide. In the study of yeast communities associated
with guava fruit in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil (Abranches et al. 2000), the
apiculate yeasts H. vineae and H. guilliermondii were found among
the prevailing species. In a further study, Abranches et al. (2001)
observed competitive interactions between these apiculate isolates
and isolates of Pichia membranifaciens or Pichia (Issatchenkia) occidentalis
growing in guava and tomato fruit tissues. They also demonstrated
that growth characteristics of apiculate yeasts are habitat
dependent. Nguyen et al. (2007) isolated H. vineae together with
Lachancea fermentati and L. thermotolerans repeatedly from the gut of
corydalids (Neuroptera) and suggested a close association of these
species and their insect hosts.

NRRL Y-1933 (CBS 2352), isolated from
pollen carried by wild bees, Brazil; NRRL Y-1935-NRRL Y-1937, NRRL
Y-1938 (CBS 2353), all from alfalfa silage, College Park, Pennsylvania,
USA, R.W. Stone; NRRL Y-1989 (CBS 5510) isolated from baker's yeast,
Italy, T. Castelli; NRRL Y-1990 (CBS 5509), isolated from human skin,
A. Pijper; NRRL Y-1991 (CBS 5508), diseased caterpillar, unknown location,
A. Ridgeway; NRRL Y-1993-NRRL Y-1997, NRRL Y-2056-NRRL
Y-2059, all from stored, unpolished rice, Louisiana, USA, D.J. Teunisson;
NRRL Y-6590 (CBS 2452), type strain of Trichosporon behrendii, from
sputum, The Netherlands, P.J. van der Werff; NRRL Y-7083, wheat kernel,
Midwest, USA; NRRL Y-7144, ragi, The Netherlands; NRRL Y-7455,
NRRL Y-7456 (CBS 6559), NRRL Y-7457, NRRL Y-7458, NRRL Y-7459 (CBS
6560), NRRL Y-7460, NRRL Y-7461, all from a grain-based chicken feed,
Guatamala; NRRL Y-7529, corn kernel, USA, H. Burmeister; NRRL
Y-12780, corn kernel, Ft. Wayne, Indiana, USA; NRRL Y-12989, from distillery
yeast, USA; NRRL Y-17347, corn kernel, USA; NRRL Y-27394, coffee
berry borer (Hypothenemus hampei, Scolytidae), Mexico; NRRL Y-27402,
insect, location unknown; CBS 7651, type strain of Trichosporon beijingense
(Lu and Li 1991), from rotten fruit of persimmon (Diospyros sp.),
Beijing, China (data from CBS website).
Ecology:
Hyphopichia burtonii has been isolated from a wide variety
of substrates   as seen from the listing under "Origin of the strains
studied". A large proportion of the strains are from high starch substrates,
such as corn, wheat (Kurtzman et al. 1970) and rice
(Teunnison 1954). Interestingly, a few of the strains are from insects
(Vega et al. 2003), and Slavikova and Vadkertiov (1995) reported the
species to be common in water from fish ponds. Nonetheless, high
starch seeds may serve as a major habitat for H. burtonii.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6139 (NRRL Y-7502), which is the
only known strain of H. heimii, was isolated from decaying, insectinvaded
wood, Equatorial Africa.
Ecology:
The only known strain was isolated from insect-invaded
wood.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
AS 2.2384 (CBS 9918, DBVPG 7999)
and AS 2.2385 (DBVPG 8000), both isolated from aerobically deteriorating
corn silage in Tochigi, Japan, April 2002.
Ecology:
Kazachstania aerobia, K. unispora and Saccharomyces cerevisiae
were the dominant species among the yeasts isolated from aerobically
deteriorating corn silage of cultivar Nasu, which had been
ensiled for about 6 months before being exposed to air. After 10 days
of aeration, K. unispora strains were no longer detected, whereas
strains of both K. aerobia and S. cerevisiae were still present (Lu et al.
2004b).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2517 (DBVPG 6069, NRRL Y-8276,
UCD-FST 57-16), NRRL Y-2404, NRRL Y-2405 and NRRL Y-2406, isolated
from soil, South Africa; DBVPG 6310, from Sardinia, Italy.
Ecology:
Most of the known strains of this species have been isolated
from soil in South Africa.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
AS 2.0706 (CBS 10102) isolated from
waste water collected in a paper mill in northeast China.
Ecology:
The only known strain of K. aquatica was isolated near a
paper mill in China.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 5648 (DBVPG 6365), isolated
from sauerkraut, The Netherlands; CBS 6946 (DBVPG 6370, IFO
10850, NRRL Y-27223), isolated from a soft drink.
Ecology: unknown
See K. telluris.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 8638 (DBVPG 7127, NRRL Y-
27203), DBVPG 7128 (NRRL Y-27204) and DBVPG 7129 (NRRL Y-
27205) were isolated from 3-month-old anaerobic maize silage in
The Netherlands.
Ecology:
Middelhoven et al. (2000a) found that the yeast biota of a
3-month-old anaerobic maize silage consisted of two species, which
were present in about equal numbers (approx. 2000 CFU/g). One species
was identified as K. exigua, whereas the other, characterized by
smaller colonies, was K. bulderii.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 134 (DBVPG 6413), origin
unknown; CBS 135 (DBVPG 6481), type strain of Candida holmii,
from buttermilk, The Netherlands; CBS 379 (DBVPG 6252, IFO 1128,
NRRL Y-12640), isolated by H. Naganishi from an unknown substrate,
was chosen as type by Lodder and Kreger-van Rij (1952); CBS 1515
(DBVPG 6354), from fermenting cucumber brine; CBS 2141 (DBVPG
6358), from soil; CBS 5648 (DBVPG 6365), from sauerkraut; CBS
4660 (DBVPG 6402), from grape must, former Czechoslovakia.
Ecology:
Most strains of this species have been isolated from diverse
food sources, hence the ecological niche is not clear.

All known isolates of K. gamospora and K. zonata came from
soil or forest debris in two regions of Japan.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
D4W13 (CBS 107045, NBRC 103634),

All known strains of the species were isolated from fermenting

Ecology: See K. telluris.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
IFO 10673 (CBS 8893, DBVPG 7292),
isolated from soil in Yaku Island, Japan.
Ecology:
Kazachstania humatica and K. yakushimaensis were isolated
from soil in the same area of Yaku Island in Japan.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
SF1S05 (CBS10587, NBRC 102655,
BCRC 23098), and SY4S01, isolated from soil, Taiwan.
Ecology:
See systematics. Systematics: During an investigation of yeast diversity in soil in
Taiwan, Lee et al. (2008) identified some isolates as being species of
Saccharomyces, or related genera of the “Saccharomyces complex”, on
the basis of phenotypic characteristics and sequences of the D1/D2
domains of the LSU rRNA gene. Two of these strains, SF1S05 and
SY4S01, proved to be closely related to Kazachstania transvaalensis, and
were identified as a novel species which was designated as K. jiainica.

DBVPG 6756 (CBS 7662, NRRL Y-
27209), isolated from soil isolated near a hot spring (55 C) on
Kunashir island, Kuril Islands, Russia.
Ecology: Unknown.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2757 (DBVPG 6308, NRRL Y-8280,
UCD-FST 70-3), isolated from soil, South Africa; NRRL YB-4303, NRRL

Africa; CBS 6750 (DBVPG 6906), origin unknown; DBVPG 6963 (UCDFST
56-10), from soil, South Africa.
Ecology:
Most known strains of K. lodderae have been recovered
from soil, but the habitat of this species is not fully known.

Ecology:
All of the currently known strains of K. naganishi have been
isolated from decaying leaves or soil in Japan. However, the ecological
niche of this species is uncertain.

using an enrichment culture on two soil samples from the same
forest in Thailand. However, the actual ecological niche of this species
is uncertain.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
DBVPG 6746 (CBS 3019, NRRL Y-
17920), isolated from soil, South Africa; DBVPG 6748 (CBS 5530), isolated

Leguminosae) in South Africa.
Ecology:
The only known strains of K. spencerorum have been isolated
in South Africa from soil and insect larvae.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
DBVPG 6288 (CBS 2685, IFO 1331, NRRL
YB-4302), isolated from soil, Cape Province, South Africa; DBVPG 7985
(ATCC 26014, CBS 6471), isolated from carnit (acetyl-L-carnitine, a free
form amino acid); NRRL Y-7284 (CBS 6258), NRRL Y-7285, both from
nasal passages of pigeons (Columba livida), USA, H.F. Hasenclever; NRRL
Y-27545 (CBS 6265), fromnasal passage of a pigeon, the Netherlands.
Ecology:
The distribution of K. telluris and the other four known species
of this complex is, with the exception of a few isolates, restricted
to the nasal passages, stomachs and intestinal tracts of birds and mammals.
The species may have some host specificity, since three out of
four known isolates of K. telluris were from pigeons, four of five known
isolates of K. slooffiae were from horses and 27 of 29 well-characterized
strains of K. pintolopesii were from rodents. However, of the five known
strains of K. bovina, only one was isolated from a cow. Most strains
from this species complex have been isolated in the USA and Europe,
but a few strains are from South Africa, South America and Asia.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
DBVPG 6757 (CBS 2186, NRRL Y-
17245), isolated by van der Walt (1956c) from soil in Mozambique.
Ecology: unknown

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 285 (NRRL Y-17531), isolated from
soil, Java, H. Kufferath.
Ecology:
The only known strain of the species was isolated from soil
in Java.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 4438, isolated from marine mud,
Biscayne Bay, J.W. Fell, USA; CBS 4904, from sea water, Torres Strait,
N. van Uden, Portugal. UWOPS 93 11.25 (ML 5079), from sea water,
tidal pool, Shroud Cay, Bahamas, J.W. Fell.
Ecology:
Kluyveromyces aestuarii is presumed to be a marine species,
although special physiological adaptations to saline environments
have not been identified. The discovery of the sister species K. nonfermentans
(Nagahama et al. 1999), also in marine habitats, lends
additional credence to the idea of a special intrinsic adaptation to
the marine environment. De Araujo et al. (1995) identified K. aestuarii
as the predominant isolate in two detritus feeding crabs (Sesarma
rectum and Uca sp.) and a shipworm (Neoteredo reynei) in Brazil. The
species was absent in two species of omnivorous crabs and a clam
species, and rare in another clam. K. aestuarii represented nearly 10%
of an otherwise extremely diverse array of yeast species.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2104, isolated from Drosophila
pseudoobscura (Diptera: Drosophilidae), Shehata et al. (1955); CBS
5061 and CBS 5062, from oak white pocket rot mushroom
(Hymenochaete rubiginosa) and brown oak mushroom (Fistulina
hepatica), J. Boidin, France; UWOPS Gol-283, from climbing shrub
(Actinidia arguta, Actinidiaceae), UWOPS Gol-212, herbaceous perennial
(Chloranthus japonicus, Chloranthaceae), UWOPS Gol-2744, from
white nut tree (Kalopanax septemlobus, Araliaceae), and UWOPS Gol-
2745, from magnolia vine (Schisandra chinensis, Schisandraceae), all
near Vladivostok, Russia, W.I. Golubev; UWOPS 79-183 and numerous
others isolated from black knot (Dibotryon morbosum, Venturiaceae)
of chokecherry (Prunus virginiana, Rosaceae), and from Drosophila
spp., Ontario, Canada.
Ecology:
Kluyveromyces dobzhanskii is isolated at relatively low frequency
from a variety of insects that feed on plants or macrofungi,
or from the plants or fungi themselves. Sukhotina et al. (2006) examined
30 strains of K. dobzhanskii collected from diverse substrates in
various biogeographic regions globally. Electrokaryotyping singled
out three of several isolates from noctuid moths in Spain as highly
divergent in chromosome size distributions. However, the ITS/5.8S
rRNA gene sequences of these strains were identical to those of other
European isolates and exhibited minor differences from strains originating
from insects or plants in eastern Russia and in North
American sources. The authors suggested that the major determinants
of variability in the species are geographic and further that a
small Spanish subpopulation exists in parapatry.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 683, isolated
from gassy cheese, L.A. Allen and B.D. Thornley (1929); CBS
4693, received by CBS from P.F. Brust; UWOPS SM2.5 and many
others from cheese, J.L. Schmidt, France.
Ecology:
Lactose-utilizing strains have arisen almost exclusively in
samples from dairy products, whereas lactose-negative strains originate
mostly from Drosophila or materials known to serve as habitats
for yeast-feeding insects.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS
2105, isolated from Drosophila azteca (Diptera, Drosophilidae, Shehata
et al. 1955); CBS 4372, type strain of Kluyveromyces vanudenii, from
winery equipment (van der Walt and Nel 1963); CBS 2103, type strain
of Kluyveromyces phaseolosporus, from Drosophila pseudoobscura
(Shehata and Mrak 1952); UWOPS 79-127 and several others, from
black knot (Dibotryon morbosum, Ascomycota) of chokecherry (Prunus
virginiana, Rosaceae); UWOPS 82-210 and several others, Drosophila
spp.; UWOPS 81-109 and others, from exudate of red oak (Quercus
rubra); Ontario, Canada. UWOPS 85-256.1, from exudates of Emory
oak (Quercus emoryi, Fagaceae), Arizona (Ganter et al. 1986).

CBS 712, H. Schnegg; CBS 2762, type
strain of Kluyveromyces bulgaricus, isolated from yogurt, J. Santa
Maria; CBS 4857, type strain of K. cicerisporus; CBS 397, type strain of
Kluyveromyces fragilis, yogurt; CBS 5671, type strain of Kluyveromyces
wikenii, from sorghum beer (van der Walt et al. 1966); numerous
strains from cheese, J.L. Schmidt, France; one strain from prickly pear
(Opuntia phaeacantha, Cactaceae), and one from Drosophila carbonaria
(Diptera, Drosophiliae, Ganter et al. 1986).
Ecology:
Kluyveromyces marxianus is known mostly through isolates
from foods and beverages, especially dairy products, but also occurs
in decaying plant tissue and associated insects.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 8778 (JCM 10232, SY-33), isolated
from deep sediment, Suruga or Sagami Bay, Japan.
Ecology:
The discovery of K. nonfermentans in marine habitats
including crabs, coupled with its sisterhood to K. aestuarii, provide
an interesting example of where phylogeny and ecology appear to be
correlated. This prompted Nagahama et al. (1999) to speculate that
the acquisition of a marine habitat preceded the divergence of the
two species. Phylogenomic studies of these species in comparison
with their terrestrial congeners could in the future provide some
insight on the nature of the adaptation of yeasts to marine
environments.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2745 (NRRL Y-8286, UCD-FST 54-
210) isolated from Drosophila pinicola (Diptera, Drosophilidae), Sierra
Nevada Mountains, California, USA, H.J. Phaff; NRRL Y-5973 (UCD-FST
56-40), from slime flux of fir tree (Abies sp., Pinaceae), M.W. Miller, USA;
UWOPS 85-330.5, from exudate of Fremont cottonwood (Populus fremontii,
Salicaceae), UWOPS 85-379.1 and UWOPS 85-384.1, from
Drosophila brooksae, Arizona, Ganter et al. (1986); UWOPS 91-127.2,
from exudate of red oak (Quercus rubra, Fagaceae), Ontario, Canada.
Ecology:
In nature, K. wickerhamii is confined to Drosophila species
and to tree exudates that probably act as Drosophila habitats.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 8494 (UWOPS 95-602.1), CBS 8496
(UWOPS 95-725.1) and many other strains, isolated from flowers of
various species of Hibiscus (Malvaceae) and morning glory (Ipomoea
spp., Convolvulaceae) in New South Wales, Queensland, and the
Northern Territories in Australia; CBS 8495 (UFMG 91-893.2), from
the flower of a morning glory (Ipomoea pes-caprae), Hapuna Beach,
Hawaii, USA; UWOPS 99-671.1 and other strains, nitidulid beetle
(Aethina concolor) from flowers of Hibiscus spp., Ipomoea spp. and
eggplant (Solanum melongina, Solanaceae); UWOPS 99-685.1, from
wasp in a flower of “tindora” (Coccinea grandis, Cucurbitaceae), Nadi
region, Fiji. UWOPS 99-686.1 and other strains, from Aethina concolor
in Ipomoea pes-caprae, Mana Island, Fiji; UWOPS 99-697.1 and other
strains, from Aethina concolor in various Ipomoea species, Rarontonga,
Cook Islands; UWOPS 00-302.3, and many other strains, from Aethina
concolor, nitidulid beetle (Conotelus mexicanus), and fruit fly
(Drosophila spp.) in flowers of various Ipomoea species, Hawaiian
Islands, USA; SUB 00-101.1, and several other strains, from Aethina
concolor in Ipomoea spp., New Caledonia (W.T. Starmer); UWOPS 05-
277b1, from Aethina sp., UWOPS 05-278.1, from Trigona sp.
(Hymenoptera: Apidae), UWOPS 05-280.1, from unidentified nitidulid,
in flowers of Hibiscus tiliaceus, Telok Senangin, Malaysia, and
many other strains from nitidulid beetle (Aethina spp., Coleoptera,
Nitidulidae) and Drosophila hibisci (Diptera, Drosophilidae) found in
those flowers.
Ecology:
Kodamaea anthophila is one of a number of closely related
species that exhibit a strong association with floricolous insects.
Although it was initially thought that the species was only associated
with Drosophila hibisci in Australia, the species was later found in
more diverse habitats. It is now known to occur abundantly more or
less anywhere the nitidulid beetle Aethina concolor is found in
ephemeral flowers of Convolvulaceae and Hibiscus species. This includes Australia, various South Pacific islands (Lachance et al.
2001e), and Malaysia. The beetle is also a recent introduction to the
Hawaiian Archipelago, where practically every specimen contains
K. anthophila. Insects that inhabit the same flowers may also carry
the yeast, presumably as a contaminant.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 8611 (UWOPS 98-119.2), CBS
8612 (UWOPS 98-117.1), and two other strains isolated from various
Hibiscus species (Malvaceae) in Kakadu National Park, Northern
Territory, Australia; SUB 04-309.1, from an unidentified beetle in a
flower of Ipomoea hildebrandtii (Convolvulaceae), Tanzania, T.M.
Anderson; UWOPS 99-669.1, and two other strains from nitidulid
beetle (Aethina concolor, Coleoptera, Nitidulidae) in a Hibiscus sp.
flower, Nadi region, Fiji; UWOPS 05-273.1, from Epuraea sp.
(Coleoptera: Nitidulidae) in a flower of Ipomoea indica, Cameron
Highlands, Malaysia.
Ecology:
Kodamaea kakaduensis can occur in sympatry with K. anthophila.
The frequency of isolation is insufficient at this stage to allow
generalization, but the range from Africa to the south Pacific is
remarkable. The basis for the respective distribution of the two species
may have to do with differences in vector insects.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
BG 02-5-27-4-2-2 (CBS 9884, NRRL
Y-27713), and four other strains, isolated from gut of tenebrionid beetle
(Diaperis sp., Coloeptera, Tenebrionidae); BG 02-5-27-4-5-2 (NRRL
Y-27714) and one other strain (Suh and Blackwell 2005), from gut of
unidentified scarabaeid beetle (Scarabaeidae), collected on a fruit
body of a mushroom named “chicken of the woods” (Laetiporus sulphurous),
Baton Rouge, Louisiana, USA. Two additional strains came
from frass of the same mushroom species (Suh and Blackwell 2005).
Ecology:
Suh and Blackwell (2005) reported that members of the
Kodamaea clade were only infrequently isolated in their extensive
sampling of beetles associated with mushroom fruit bodies. Of these,
K. laetispori appeared to be restricted to a single mushroom species
in a single locality, in contrast to K. ohmeri, which they found once in
Panama and once in Louisiana. The closest relatives, C. fukazawae
and C. sagamina, also came from mushrooms (Nakase et al. 1999).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 8491 (UFMG 96-272), CBS 8492
(UFMG 96-394), and a few other strains were isolated from flowers
of the columnar cactus Pilosocereus arrabidae in various sea-side
localities of the State of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; UFMG 96-340 and
UFMG 96-319, from tunnels of the moth Sigelgaita sp. (Lepidoptera:
Pyralidae) in the same area.
Ecology:
Although the cultures studied were isolated from flowers
and moth frass (Rosa et al. 1999), there is a strong association
between K. nitidulidarum and an unidentified nitidulid beetle that
serves as its principal vector (Rosa et al. 1994).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-1932 (CBS 5367), NRRL Y-1925
(CBS 5368), NRRL Y-1928 (CBS 5375), isolated from cucumber brines,
USA, J.L. Etchells; NRRL Y-2078 (CBS 2037), from gooseberry jelly,
Germany, S. Windisch; NRRL Y-2079 (CBS 568), from pleural fluid,
Java, Indonesia, W. de Graaff; NRRL Y-2080 (CBS 2038), from sambalulak
(Indonesian fermented chile peppers); NRRL Y-27480, from a
mushroom on a salt cedar (Tamarix sp., Tamaricaceae), Crete, Greece,
W.J. Middelhoven; NRRL Y-27716 (BG 98-8-14-1-3-1), from gut of
nitidulid beetle (Carpophilus sp., Nitidulidae) on a mushroom (dyemaker's
puffball, Pisolithus tinctorium), Baton Rouge, Louisiana, USA;
NRRL YB-201, from a banana, Puerto Rico; UWOPS 99-403.1, from
caterpillar frass; UWOPS 01-113a2 and others strains from nitidulid
beetle from Bignonaciae flower; UWOPS 01-666b4 and other, strains
from flower of woodrose (Merremia tuberosa, Convolvulaceae), Costa
Rica; UWOPS 05-201.2, from Trigona sp. (Hymenoptera: Apidae);
UWOPS 05-207.2, strains from a muscoid fly; UWOPS 05-228.2 from
an unidentified beetle, all collected on inflorescences of bertam palm
(Eugeissona triste, Arecaceae), Malaysia.
Ecology:
The occasional recovery of K. ohmeri in flowers and associated
insects is consistent with what is known of other members of
the genus, but the fact that the species has been recovered from a
broad variety of sources for over half a century suggests that it may
have become more of a generalist. Suh and Blackwell (2005) recently
reported the isolation of two strains from mushroom associated
materials from Panama and Louisiana, USA, respectively. A general
and cosmopolitan distribution is also supported by the recent isolation
(Mancianti et al. 2001) of K. ohmeri in a small proportion of
samples of parrot droppings that otherwise contain a diverse array
of yeasts dominated by generalistic or domestic species.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y 1603 (CBS 704), isolated
from exudate of a chestnut tree (Castanea sp., Fagaceae), France, A.
Guilliermond; NRRL Y-1047, unknown substrate, A. Guilliermond
(this isolate may represent an earlier accession of the type strain);
other strains available include 31 isolates reported by Dlauchy et al.
(2003), from exudates and rotted wood obtained from Norway, and
hedge maples (Acer platanoides, A. campestre, Aceraceae), oaks
(Quercus spp., Fagaceae), European white birch (Betula pendula,
Betulaceae), European larch (Larix decidua, Pinaceae), willow (Salix
sp., Salicaceae), European hornbeam (Carpinus betula, Betulaceae)
and European beech (Fagus sylvatica, Fagaceae), all from Hungary.
Ecology:
The type strain of K. pastoris was isolated from a chestnut
tree in France (Guilliermond 1919), but the majority of K. pastoris
strains have been isolated from exudates and rotten wood from a
variety of trees growing in Hungary (Dlauchy et al. 2003). From this
work, it is seen that a major habitat for K. pastoris is in tree exudates
and decomposing wood. Whether K. pastoris is found only in
Europe is uncertain, as it is not possible to separate K. pastoris from
the presently recognized K. phaffii and K. pseudopastoris through
the use of standard fermentation and growth tests, and previous
reports of K. pastoris from other geographical regions may be
incorrect.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-7556 (CBS 26125NRRL YB-
42905UCD-FST K-239), NRRL YB-4289, both isolated from black oak
trees (Quercus kelloggii), California, USA, H.J. Phaff; NRRL Y-12729,
substrate unknown; NRRL Y-17741 (SUB 85-263.1), from sap flux,
emory oak (Quercus emoryi), Tucson, Arizona, USA, W.T. Starmer;
NRRL YB-378, from slime flux of an elm tree (Ulmus sp.), USA,
L.J. Wickerham.
Ecology:
Strains of K. phaffii have been isolated from fluxes in oaks
growing in California and Arizona USA, and from an elm tree, possibly
from Illinois, USA. M.A. Lachance (personal communication)
determined from D1/D2 LSU rRNA gene sequence analysis that the
K. pastoris strains reported by Ganter et al. (1986) to occur in sap
fluxes of Quercus emoryi (nine strains) and Populus fremontii (four
strains), as well as those associated with Drosophila brooksae (two
strains), are instead K. phaffii. Consequently, tree fluxes in the
Sonoran region are an important habitat for K. phaffii.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NCAIM Y 01541 (NRRL Y-27603, CBS
9187), NCAIM Y 01526 (NRRL Y-27602, CBS 9186), NCAIM Y 01554
(NRRL Y-27604, CBS 9188), NCAIM Y 01555 (NRRL Y-27605, CBS
9189), all isolated from rotted wood of willow trees (Salix alba),
Hungary (Dlauchy et al. 2003).
Ecology:
All known strains of K. pseudopastoris have been isolated
from rotted wood of willow trees in Hungary (Dlauchy et al. 2003).
Rotting wood possibly provides a source of methanol, which
K. pseudopastoris and other methanol assimilating yeasts can utilize
for growth. Dlauchy et al. (2003) noted that K. pseudopastoris was
never isolated from oak trees, and questioned whether the higher
tannic acid content in oaks might prevent growth of the species.
That hypothesis appears correct. K. pseudopastoris was inhibited by
0.03% tannic acid, whereas K. pastoris did grow at this concentration.
K. phaffii has not been tested for tolerance to tannic acid, but a
majority of strains of this species have been isolated from oak trees,
and it is therefore likely to be tolerant of tannic acid.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
The type strain, NRRL Y-7119 (CBS
2614), was isolated from naturally fermented apple juice, UK (Beech
1965). The second known strain, NRRL Y-17855 (CBS 2109), was isolated
by P. Scrivani (CBS website) from wine obtained near Monte Terminillo,
Italy and subsequently deposited with the CBS culture collection.
Ecology:
The two known strains of this species, as described above,
are from fermented fruit juices, which suggests that the natural habitat
of the species is on the skins of fruit (Beech 1965, Kurtzman 2006).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL YB-4273 (CBS 2287), isolated
from slime flux, black oak (Quercus kelloggii), California, USA; NRRL
Y-1615 (CBS 639), from sour wine, Europe, neotype of Candida vini;
NRRL Y-1616 (CBS 640), from wine, Europe; NRRL Y-17853 (CBS 634),
W.B. Bierberg, unidentified substrate, mating type1; NRRL Y-27901
(CBS 633), N.H. Claussen, unidentified substrate, mating type1; NRRL
Y-27902 (CBS 2099), from pear cider, Germany, mating type2; NRRL
Y-27903 (CBS 2119), from wine, Italy; NRRL Y-27904 (CBS 2122), from
beer, The Netherlands, mating type1; NRRL Y-27906 (CBS 5364),
from slime flux, black oak, USA; NRRL YB-4882, YB-4886, both from
“tea fungus”, Russia (?). The conspecificity of the preceding strains
was determined from D1/D2 LSU and ITS rRNA gene sequence analysis
(Kurtzman 2006).
Ecology:
Isolates of K. fluxuum are known from the fluxes of oaks
(Quercus rubra, Q. kellogii) (Bowles and Lachance 1983, Phaff and
Knapp 1956) in Canada and California, USA, respectively, from fir
trees (Abies concolor) in California (Phaff and Knapp 1956), and from
various types of fermented beverages and brine-preserved vegetables,
such as pickles (Walker and Ayres 1970). The food and beverage
spoilage aspects of this species are discussed below.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-5494 (CBS 10105), the only
known strain of this species, was isolated in April 1961 by
L. J. Wickerham from a fallen apple that had been sent to Peoria, Illinois,
and that had over-wintered in an orchard nearWakeman, Ohio, USA.
Ecology:
The single known strain of K. pseudodelftensis and the two
known strains of the closely related K. delftensis were isolated from
fruit and fruit products (Kurtzman 2006).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 1993 (NRRL Y-1842), isolated from
insect frass of a coniferous tree on the shore of Wabatongushi Lake,
near Franz, Ontario, Canada (Wickerham 1951); CBS 4306 from soil,
Finland; CBS 9987 (NCAIM Y.01458) from rotten wood of black pine
(Pinus nigra), Hungary; CBS 9988 (NCAIM Y.01571) from rotten wood
of Scotch pine (Pinus sylvestris), Hungary; CBS 9989 (NCAIM Y.01726)
from rotten wood of Norway spruce (Picea abies), Hungary; NRRL YB-
2236 from lichen, Wyoming, USA; NRRL YB-2512 from insect frass,
black spruce (Picea mariana), Ontario, Canada; NRRL YB-2520 from
insect frass, yellow spruce (Picea rubens), Ontario, Canada; NRRL YB-
2754 from insect frass, fir (Tsuga sp.), Tokyo, Japan; NRRL YB-2980
from insect frass, larch (Larix sp.), Germany; NRRL YB-2988 from insect
frass, larch, Germany; NRRL YB-3002 from insect frass, fir (Tsuga sp.),
Germany; NRRL YB-4665 from resin, fir, Quebec, Canada.
Ecology:
Kuraishia capsulata is often recovered from frass or tunnels
of larvae underneath the bark of certain conifers. Wickerham (1951)
is of the opinion that this yeast has become adapted to growth in the
presence of pitch, which is toxic to competitors, or that the association
of this species with the pine bark beetles or their larvae may in
some way be responsible for its survival. The extracellular polysaccharides
produced by this species cause the cells to adhere to the
bark beetles, and this adhesive characteristic probably aids dispersal
(Wickerham 1970a).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 136 (ATCC 2516, JCM 1997, NRRL
Y-2237) (type strain of Torula molischiana), from used tanning bark;
CBS 836 (NRRL Y-2238), non-slimy variant of CBS 136; CBS 837 (NRRL
Y-2234), from water, at 40 C in wood-working factory, Sweden; CBS
4683, from soil; CBS 5186, non-mucoid variant of CBS 837; CBS 7030,
from soil, Japan; CBS 9990 (NCAIM Y.01428), from fruiting body of
mushroom (Suillus sp.), Hungary; CBS 9991 (NCAIM Y.01585), from
rotten wood of black pine (Pinus nigra), Hungary; CBS 9992 (NCAIM
Y.01724), from rotten wood of black locust (Robinia pseudoacacia),
Hungary; CBS 9993 (NRRL Y-27899, NCAIM Y.01725), from rotten
wood of European beech (Fagus sylvatica), Hungary (Péter et al.
2005a); NCAIM Y.01736, from feces of domesticated rabbit, Hungary;
NRRL Y-1889, from insect frass, red pine (Pinus resinosa), Canada;
NRRL YB-2096, from insect frass, loblolly pine (Pinus taeda), Georgia,
USA; NRRL YB-2101, from insect frass, juniper (Juniperus sp.),
Montana, USA; NRRL YB-2342, from insect frass, ponderosa pine
(Pinus ponderosa), Washington, USA; NRRL YB-2441, from insect frass,
ponderosa pine (Pinus ponderosa), Washington, USA; NRRL YB-2962,
from insect frass, pine (Pinus sp.), Germany; NRRL YB-3058, from
insect frass, white pine (Pinus strobus), Wisconsin, USA.
Ecology:
Like K. capsulata, K. molischiana is also often recovered from
frass or tunnels of larvae underneath the bark of certain conifers.
According to Péter et al. (2005a) it is likely that one of the primary
habitats of the two species is the larvae of wood-boring insects. See
also “Ecology”, K. capsulata.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UWOPS 99-101.1 (CBS 8793, NRRL
Y-48386) and others, isolated from flowers, Opuntia phaeacantha
(Cactaceae); UWOPS 99-103.1 and others, flowers, Opuntia echinocarpa;
UWOPS 99-116.1, flower, Carnegiea gigantea (Cactaceae); UWOPS
99-117.1 and others, flowers, Opuntia basilaris, Sonoran desert of
Arizona and California, USA. Many other strains from Carpophilus
sp. (Coleoptera: Nitidulidae) collected in cactus flowers in the same
localities, including UWOPS 07-123.1 (CBS 10688, NRRL Y-48387).
Ecology:
The recovery of K. cleridarum from cactus flowers or from
Carpophilus sp. specimens found in these flowers is remarkably
reproducible. After the original collection in 1999, three more samplings
(2001 and 2003, J. Bowles and M.A. Lachance, unpublished
data, Lachance and Starmer 2008, C.T. Harding, unpublished data)
yielded mostly pure cultures in beetle walk plates. The consistent
exception was the material collected from flowers of cholla (Opuntia
echinocarpa) in Lost Dutchman State Park, Arizona, USA, where the
plates may also contain small numbers of Metschnikowia arizonensis.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 4575 (NRRL Y-12634) and CBS
2950 (NRRL Y-12635), both isolated from cider; UWOPS 99-808.2
and UWOPS 99-809.2, both from sap flux of a Southern beech
(Nothofagus sp., Fagaceae), Patagonia, Argentina. CBS 5666 (DBVPG
6473, NRRL Y-12621), rotten bark of Araucaria sp., J. Grinbergs.
Ecology:
In a recently study of 208 yeasts isolated from fermented
apple cider in France, Coton et al. (2006) identified 15% of isolates as
L. cidri, confirming the affinity of the species for this substrate. The
species was third in level of abundance, following Saccharomyces
bayanus and S. cerevisiae, with Dekkera anomala next most abundant.
A similar study of Irish cider (Morrissey et al. 2004) reported the
presence of quite a different array of species, but not L. cidri.
Unfortunately, the identification appeared to be based exclusively on
ribotypes and systematic counts of the various species were not
given.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 707 (NRRL Y-1559), type strain
for Zygosaccharomyces fermentati and Saccharomyces montanus, isolated
from sediment of a peppermint beverage; CBS 6544 (NRRL Y-
17054), from an oak tree (Quercus sp., Fagaceae), California, USA; CBS
6711 (NRRL Y-17055), from an orange drink, Iraq; CBS 4506 (NRRL Y-
7434), from a fruit fly (Drosophila sp.), California, USA; CBS 7004
(NRRL Y-11844), type strain of Saccharomyces astigiensis, from alpechin,
Spain, J. Santa María; CBS 7005 (NRRL Y-11847), type strain of
Saccharomyces albasitensis, from alpechin, Spain, J. Santa María; CBS
4686 (NRRL Y-12620), type strain of Saccharomyces nilssoni var. malicitensis,
from alpechin, Spain, J. Santa María; UWOPS 80-21, from a
black knot outgrowth (Dibotryon morbosum, Ascomycetes) of chokecherry
(Prunus virginiana, Rosaceae); UWOPS 82-283 and several
others, Drosophila sp. (Diptera: Drosophilidae), Pinery Provincial
Park, Ontario, Canada; UWOPS 85-304.1, from Drosophila carbonaria
collected on a sap flux of mesquite (Prosopis juliflora, Fabaceae);
UWOPS 85-318.1, from flux of a cottonwood (Populus fremontii,
Salicaceae); UWOPS 85-406.1 and other strains from a drosophilid fly
(Aulacigaster leucopeza, Diptera: Aulacigastridae), Tucson, Arizona,
USA; UWOPS 94-273.4 and another strain from a natural tequila fermentation,
Jalisco, Mexico; M.A. Lachance.
Ecology:
Lachancea fermentati is known both as a contaminant of
fruit juices, and as a relatively low frequency component of the
plant insect interface (Ganter 2006, James and Stratford 2003).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 3082 (DBVPG 6177, IFO 1685, NRRL
Y-12651, UCD-FST 51-242), isolated from a fruit fly (Drosophila pinicola),
Mather, California, USA, H.J. Phaff; CBS 2861 (DBVPG 6364, NRRL
Y-2553), syntype of Saccharomyces smittii, fromsoil, Sweden, A. Capriotti;
CBS 4104 (DBVPG 6340, NRRLY-12694), syntype of Saccharomyces smittii,
from soil, Netherlands, A. Capriotti; CBS 4569 (DBVPG 6467, NRRL
Y-4288-7D1), derived from NRRL Y-4288; CBS 5828 (DBVPG 6403), type
strain of Saccharomyces silvestris, from water-logged soil, Denmark, V.
Jensen; CBS 6545 (DBVPG 6362, NRRL Y-4288, UCD-FST 55-86), CBS
6546 (NRRL Y-2468, UCD-FST 57-79), both from slime flux of a willow
(Salix sp., Salicaceae); CBS 6548 (DBVPG 6412), from Drosophila pseudoobscura,
California, USA, H.J. Phaff; DBVPG 3103, 3108, 3109, 3452
and 3453, from soil; CBS 6626 (DBVPG 6363), from tree exudate,
Calfornia, USA, H.J. Phaff; UWOPS 79-150, from black knot disease
(Dibotryon morbosum, Ascomycetes) of chokecherry (Prunus virginiana,
Rosaceae), London, Ontario, Canada; UWOPS 80-52, from black knot of
pin cherry (Prunus pennsylvanica, Rosaceae), Mouth of Keswick, New
Brunswick, Canada; UWOPS 82-201, from Drosophila sp., Pinery
Provincial Park, Ontario, Canada; UWOPS 85-319.1 and others, from
flux of cottonwood (Populus fremontii, Salicaceae), Tucson, Arizona,
USA: UWOPS 98-117.4, from a flower of Hibiscus receae (Malvaceae),
KakaduNational Park, Australia.
Ecology:
Lachancea kluyveri is similar to most other species in the
genus in the types of natural habitats from which it is recovered. The
yeast is found at low regularity at the plant insect interface, as seen
from “Origin of the strains studied”.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 8951 (ML
3925, NRRL Y-27269), ML 3937 (CBS 9958, NRRL Y-27411), and ML
4115 (CBS 9924, NRRL Y-27762), isolated from seawater, Mangrove
Cay, Bahamas.
Other strains: In total, 14 strains were isolated at Mangrove Cay,
Bahama Bank, two from Manjack Cay, Abacos and one from Cross
Key, near Andros Island, Bahamas.
Ecology:
Fell et al. (2004) indicated that the isolation of L. meyersii
was part of a study of yeasts found in aquatic habitats surrounding
mangroves. They observed that this is the first example of a species
with a marine affinity in the genus Lachancea.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6340 (NRRL Y-8284), isolated
from plum jam, G.S. Filippov (1932); CBS 2803, type of
Kluyveromyces veronae (van der Walt 1971), from grapes, O. Verona;
