CBS 137, type of Candida dattila; UWOPS 79-110 and many others
from black knot disease (Dibotryon morbosum, Ascomycetes) of sand
cherry (Prunus pumila, Rosaceae) and chokecherry (Prunus virginiana);
UWOPS 82-204 and others from Drosophila spp. (Diptera:
Drosophilidae), Pinery Provincial Park, Ontario, Canada; UWOPS 79-
248, from frass of yellow birch (Betula alleghaniensis, Betulaceae),
Springwater Forest, Ontario; UWOPS 81-125 and one other, insect
galls of red oak (Quercus rubra, Fagaceae), Melbourne, Ontario;
UWOPS 83-1097.1 and UWOPS 83-1101.1, from a drosophilid (Gitona
Americana, Diptera: Drosophilidae) on erect prickly pear (Opuntia
stricta, Cactaceae) Cayman Islands; UWOPS 85-51.1, from fruit of bullsucker
(Opuntia cubensis), Big Pine Key, Florida, USA; UWOPS 85-
312.1, from a fruit fly (Drosophila carbonaria) on flux of mesquite
(Prosopis juliflora, Fabaceae), Tucson, Arizona, USA; UWOPS 90-1019.1
and one other, from fruit, Exumas Cays, Bahamas; UWOPS 91-902.1
and others, flux of sandalwood (Myoporum sandwicense,
Myoporaceae), Hawai'i, USA; UWOPS 94-426.2, from tequila fermentation,
Jalisco, Mexico; UWOPS 99-807.3 and one other, flux of
Southern beech (Nothofagus sp., Fagaceae), Patagonia, Argentina.
Ecology:
Lachancea thermotolerans is associated with fruit,
Drosophila species, and possibly other insects that use plants for
feeding purposes (Ganter 2006). It is so far the most frequently isolated
member of the genus.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6430 (NRRL Y-8285, UCD-FST 72-
130, isolated from exudate of holly (Ilex sp., Aquifoliaceae), Japan,
K. Kodama; UWOPS 79-160 and others from insect galls on red oak
(Quercus rubra, Fagaceae) and black knot disease (Dibotryon morbosum,
Ascomycetes) of chokecherry (Prunus virginiana, Rosaceae),
Melbourne, Ontario, Canada; UWOPS 82-227 and one other strain
from Drosophila sp., Pinery Provincial Park, Ontario.
Ecology:
Lachancea waltii is probably insect associated, having been
recovered from plant injuries or diseases known or suspected to
serve as feeding sites for Drosophila species and other insects, as
listed under “Origin of the strains studied”.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 112108, isolated from leaves of
mastic tree (Pistacia lentiscus) in Arrábida, Portugal.
Ecology:
Only one strain of L. arrabidae was isolated from leaves of a
mastic tree (Pistacia lentiscus, Anacardiaceae), in spite of a considerable
sampling effort in the yeast survey of five Mediterranean plant
species at the Arrábida Natural Park (Inácio et al. 2002), which
yielded this strain.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
PYCC 5558 (5A3.3), isolated from the
leaf of a Pyrenean oak (Quercus pyrenaica, Fagaceae), Caramulo,
Portugal; CBS 102169, from infected leaves of a hornbeam (Carpinus
betulus, Betulaceae), Slovakia.
Ecology:
There is some evidence that the yeast state of Taphrina carpini
occurs epiphytically on plants other than the respective host. In
addition to strain PYCC 5558 from Q. pyrenaica in Portugal, another
strain isolated from leaf litter of an alluvial forest in Austria (Taphrina
sp. HA 1613; Wuczkowski et al. 2005) had a D1/D2 sequence
(GenBank accession: AM039682) identical to that of PYCC 5558
(AY239198; one nucleotide substitution to CBS 102169). An ITS
sequence obtained for the same strain (M. Wuczkowski, unpublished
data) differed from PYCC 5558 (AY239215) and CBS 102169 at 2 3
nucleotide positions thus confirming that HA 1613 belongs to L. carpini.
This observation provides further support to the hypothesis that
the yeast state of T. carpini may grow saprobically on plant surfaces
and can thus be isolated in the yeast state.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 112109 (PYCC 5733), isolated from
leaves of Montpellier maple (Acer monspessulanum, Aceraceae),
Arrábida, Portugal; 3CSF12, A3CSV4, 5CVFe7, from leaves of a rock
rose (Cistus albidus), Arrábida, Portugal; 4QVF27, from leaves of
Portuguese oak (Quercus faginea, Fagaceae), Arrábida, Portugal;
6PVF11, from leaves of a mastic tree (Pistacia lentiscus), Arrábida,
Portugal; Silv 2.1A, from curled leaf of a peach (Prunus persica), Lisbon,
Portugal; 30 other strains were isolated from the four Mediterranean
plant species sampled in Arrábida (see Inácio et al. 2004).
Ecology:
Lalaria inositophila was found on leaves of different
Mediterranean plants in the Arrábida Natural Park, Portugal (Acer
monspessulanum, Quercus faginea, Cistus albidus and Pistacia lentiscus).
One additional strain was isolated from Q. faginea inflorescences. This
species may have a predominantly saprobic life style, and thus represent
a true epiphytic phylloplane colonist. Another strain (Silv 2.1A)
was collected from a peach leaf infected with the peach leaf curl fungus
Taphrina deformans while trying to isolate the latter (Inácio et al.
2004). Additional strains of L. inositophila were obtained from leaf
buds of peach trees infected with T. deformans and their identity confirmed
by PCR fingerprinting (S. Tavares and Á. Fonseca, unpublished
data). It should be noted that L. inositophila and T. deformans are
clearly distinct species (see, for example, Fig. 93.2).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 112110 (PYCC 5737), isolated from
leaves of a rock rose (Cistus albidus), Arrábida, Portugal.
Ecology:
Only one strain of L. kurtzmanii was isolated from Cistus
albidus leaves, in spite of a considerable sampling effort in the yeast
survey of five Mediterranean plant species at the Arrábida Natural
Park (Inácio et al. 2002), which yielded this strain.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 112111 (PYCC 5734), isolated from
leaves of Acer monspessulanum, Arrábida, Portugal; 6QVF8, from
leaves of Quercus faginea, Arrábida, Portugal; 6PVF29, from leaves of
Pistacia lentiscus, Arrábida, Portugal; 6AVL4, from inflorescence of A.
monspessulanum, Arrábida, Portugal.
Ecology:
Lalaria veronaerambellii was the second most abundant
Taphrina-related species in a yeast survey on Mediterranean plants in
the Arrábida Natural Park, after L. inositophila (Inácio et al. 2004). It
is noteworthy that two of the four isolates were obtained from
Montpellier maple (Acer monspessulanum); one from leaves and the
other from inflorescences.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-2156 (CBS 5644), NRRL Y-2157
(CBS 5645), NRRL Y-2158, all were isolated from frass in a Jeffrey
pine (Pinus jeffreyi), California, USA; NRRL YB-2444, NRRL YB-2452,
frass from a ponderosa pine (Pinus ponderosa), Redstone, New
Mexico, USA.
Ecology:
All currently known strains of L. americana are insect associated
and have been isolated from frass found in insect tunnels in
pine trees growing in the western and southwestern regions of the
US (Wickerham 1965b).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
Strains isolated from frass in insect
tunnels in loblolly pine (Pinus taeda): NRRL YB-1287 (CBS 7020), YB-
1289, from Piney Woods, Mississippi, USA; YB-2031, YB-2034,
YB-2125, Alexandria, Louisiana, USA; YB-2122, YB-2124, YB-2126, YB-
2128, YB-2129, YB-2132, YB-2133, Greensboro, Georgia, USA; YB-
2032, YB-2033, from frass from longleaf pine (Pinus palustris),
Alexandria, Louisiana, USA; YB-4454, frass, unidentified pine,
Indiana, USA; YB-2801, from frass, Japanese red pine (Pinus densiflora),
Tokyo, Japan; YB-3023, YB-3024, from frass from larvae of
Phaenops sp., unspecified pine, Munich, Germany; Y-11503 (CBS
5692), from J. Santa María, habitat unspecified, Spain (?).
Ecology:
The description of L. amylophila was based on a single
strain, NRRL YB-1287 (Kurtzman et al. 1980a), but with the advent
of gene sequencing, numerous unidentified strains maintained in the
ARS Culture Collection were recognized as L. amylophila and are
listed under “Origin of the strains studied”. As seen from this listing,
L. amylophila is widely distributed in southern USA and has also been
isolated from samples collected in Japan and Germany. All isolations
have been from frass in insect tunnels from various pine species.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-5343 (CBS 5642), isolated
from larva of the beetle Ergates faber in Scotch pine (Pinus sylvestris);
NRRL Y-5218, Y-5344, Y-5354, Y-5625, Y-5632, Y-5747, Y-5760, from
various beetle larvae in pine trees (Pinus spp.), Spain; Y-2805, from
frass, fir tree (Abies firma), Tokyo, Japan (Wickerham 1965b).
Ecology:
Lindnera bimundalis is known from Europe and Asia,
whereas L. americana is known only from the USA (Wickerham
1965b). If future isolations continue to show the geographical separation
of L. bimundalis and L. americana, these two closely related
species may be an example of allopatric speciation.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 8033 (NRRL Y-17232), CBS 7082
(NRRL Y-17233), CBS 7083 (NRRL Y-17757), isolated from insectinfested
spurge (Euphorbia ingens), Groblersdal area, South Africa.
Ecology:
Known strains are all from insect-infested spurge indigenous
to the Groblersdal area of South Africa (van der Walt and
Opperman 1983).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 8083 (NRRL Y-12742), isolated
from insect-infested decaying tissue of spurge (Euphorbia ingens),
Transvaal, South Africa; CBS 7912 (NRRL Y-12743) and CBS 7913
(Y-12744), which were derived from heat treatment of the type
strain.
Ecology:
Lindnera euphorbiiphila is known only from the type strain,
which was isolated from decaying tissue of a spurge plant, Transvaal,
South Africa (van der Walt 1982b).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-1871 (CBS 5640), a contaminant
isolated from a fermentor inoculated with Aerobacter aerogenes
for production of butylene glycol, USA; NRRL Y-1872, from moldy
bran, alcohol fermentation plant, USA; NRRL Y-1873 (CBS 5641),
Y-1874, Y-1875, from an alcohol fermentation plant, Cheju Island,
Korea; NRRL Y-6710 (CBS 5481) NRRL Y-6713, from rice koji,
K. Kodama, Japan; NRRL Y-12766, fermented tapioca, U. Choke, Kuala
Lumpur, Malaysia; NRRL Y-27758, Y-27932, clinical isolates, W.G.
Merz, Baltimore, Maryland, USA.
Ecology:
The primary source of L. fabianii has been as a contaminant
in industrial and food fermentations consisting of starch-based substrates
(Wickerham 1965a). The species utilizes soluble starch and
grows at 37 C, which may give it a competitive advantage in the preceding
fermentations. Additionally, two strains were received from
among a group of clinical isolates (C.P. Kurtzman, unpublished data).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-1542 (CBS 1600), isolated
from pus from a human abscess (Sartory et al. 1932); NRRL Y-900
(CBS 5609), from a yeast factory, Germany; NRRL Y-1082 (CBS 1517),
from a yeast factory, Germany; NRRL Y-1084 (CBS 841), type strain of
Torulopsis utilis var major, from a yeast factory, Germany; NRRL
Y-1427 (CBS 1516), unknown history, Wisconsin, USA; NRRL Y-1509
(CBS 567), type strain of Candida guilliermondii var. nitratophila, from
a distillery, R. Ciferri, Italy; NRRL Y-2225 (CBS 840), NRRL Y-2226
(CBS 839), from sputum, The Netherlands; NRRL Y-6756 (CBS 4885),
from a cow with mastitis, E. Parisis, Greece; NRRL Y-7586 (CBS 621),
type strain of Candida (Torula) utilis and type strain of Torula mineralis,
from a yeast factory, Germany (Wickerham 1970a).
Ecology:
The natural habitat of L. jadinii is uncertain, but because the
species grows well on pentoses and tolerates lignin by-products, it
may be associated with decomposing plant material in nature. Many
strains have been isolated from industrial fermentations, but isolates
from humans and animals are not uncommon.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL YB-2750 (CBS 7209), YB-2751
(CBS 7210), YB-2752 (CBS 7211) and YB-2753 (CBS 7212) were isolated
in 1951 by L.J. Wickerham from frass provided by the Ministry
of Agriculture and Forestry, Tokyo, Japan, that was obtained from
insect tunnels in a fir tree (Abies firma) (Kurtzman 1987a). Two other
isolates maintained in the ARS Culture Collection that were not
included in the species description were identified from D1/D2 LSU
rRNA gene sequence analysis: NRRL YB-4672, from a dead fir (Abies
sp.), Quebec, Canada; NRRL Y-17805 (CBS 7924), from an oak
(Quercus sp.) log infested with ambrosia beetles, Slovenia.
Ecology:
All known isolates of L. japonica were associated with tree boring
insects. Initially, the species was known only from Japan, but additional
isolates have been obtained from Canada and Slovenia, as noted
above, suggesting that the species is worldwide in distribution. Closely
related species of the Lindnera clade are found in similar habitats.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-27008 (CBS 8557, UCD-FST
79-9), NRRL Y-27009 (UCD-FST 79-3) and NRRL Y-27010 (UCDFST
79-4), all isolated from the rotting bark of Tetraplasandra
hawaiiensis (Araliaceae), Olaa Tract, Hawaii Volcanoes National Park,
Hawaii, USA. In addition to the preceding, Phaff et al. (1999) reported
17 additional strains of L. lachancei that were isolated from rotting
bark of T. hawaiiensis and Cheirodendron sp. and from decaying fruit
of Clermontia sp. All were from the same location in Hawaii, but
identification was from phenotype for these latter strains.
Ecology:
All known strains of L. lachancei have been isolated from
the bark of trees (Tetraplasandra hawaiiensis, Cheirodendron sp.,
Clermontia sp.) growing in the Hawaii Volcanoes National Park,
Hawaii (Phaff et al. 1999). Many of the strains failed to form ascospores or to mate with the haploid mating types. Consequently,
the identity of these strains needs to be verified from sequence analysis,
particularly because many of the strains were on trees different
from that of the type strain.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-5377 (CBS 8671) and NRRL Y-
5381 (CBS 8674), both ascosporogenous diploid strains isolated from
decaying fruits of the osage orange tree (Maclura pomifera) by L.J.
Wickerham (unpublished data), December 1960, Peoria, Illinois, USA.
Ecology:
Lindnera maclurae is known from two strains isolated from
rotting fruits of an osage orange (hedge apple) that was growing in
Peoria, Illinois. The osage orange is common in the eastern half of
the United States and Canada, consequently, L. maclurae might be
widely distributed.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7076 (NRRL Y-17236), isolated
from rotting insect-infested spurge (Euphorbia ingens), Groblersdal
district, South Africa; CBS 7077 (NRRL Y-12777) and CBS 7078 (NRRL
Y-12778), haploids from a heat-treated culture of CBS 7076 (van der
Walt 1982a).
Ecology:
Lindnera meyerae is presently known from a single strain
that was isolated from rotting, insect-infested spurge, Groblersdal,
South Africa (van der Walt 1982a).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL YB-1294 (CBS 7023), YB-1276,
YB-1288, YB-1291, YB-1292, all isolated from insect frass, loblolly
pine (Pinus taeda), Piney Woods, Mississippi, USA; YB-1270, YB-1278,
YB-1285, YB-1286, YB-1290, all from insect frass, shortleaf pine
(Pinus echinata), Piney Woods, Mississippi, USA; YB-1335, from a rotted
log, Marion, Illinois, USA; YB-2004, from insect frass, longleaf
pine (Pinus palustris), Wilma, Florida, USA; YB-1317, laboratory contaminant,
Peoria, Illinois, USA. The preceding strains were isolated in
1949 1950 by L. J. Wickerham. NRRL Y-11748 (CBS 5837), type strain,
Candida obtusa var. arabinosa, from a mushroom (Clitopilus prunulus),
France.
Ecology:
Strains of L. mississippiensis have been isolated primarily
from frass found in insect borings in pines, predominantly from the
southern US (Kurtzman et al. 1980a). One isolate was from a mushroom
growing in France (Montrocher 1967). Consequently, L. mississippiensis
seems widely distributed in the southern US, and has been
found at least once in Europe.

Lindnera misumaiensis has been isolated in Japan, Europe
and North America. Five of the seven isolates are known to be from
apples or apple products (Kurtzman 2000). Additionally, Coton et al.
(2006) isolated L. misumaiensis in cider must from France.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-1364 (CBS 1707), isolated
from soil, Papua New Guinea; NRRL YB-3257, from soil, India; NRRL
Y-17814, unknown substrate, Japan; NRRL YB-2202, from swamp
water, Laramie, Wyoming, USA; NRRL Y-6520 (UCD-FST 63-106),
from effluent from a hot spring, California, USA (Wickerham 1970a).
Ecology:
Strains of L. mrakii have been isolated worldwide and most
are from soil, but the role of this species in soil is unknown.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL YB-3808 (CBS 5555) and NRRL
YB-3807 (CBS 5556), both isolated from lung tissue of a human
cadaver preserved with embalming fluid.
Ecology:
The two known strains of L. petersonii were isolated from
an embalmed human cadaver (Wickerham 1964b), suggesting a tolerance
to toxic habitats with low oxygen levels.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-7854 (CBS 5518), NRRL Y-2380
(CBS 2142), NRRL Y-11534 (CBS 2010), NRRL Y-11535 (CBS 2518), type
strain of Endomycopsis balearica and type strain of Endomycopsis
fibuligera var. energica, all isolated from leather or tanning fluid,
France (Verona and Zardetto de Toledo 1959a); NRRL YB-3207, from
fermented canaigre (a high tannin plant product), Philadelphia,
Pennsylvania, USA; NRRL Y-11537 (CBS 5298), from palm nuts, Congo.
Ecology:
With the possible exception of NRRL Y-11537, from palm
nuts, all isolates of L. rhodanensis have been from substrates with
high concentrations of tannins such as tanning fluid and leather. The
natural habitat of this species might be the bark of trees that are
used to prepare tanning fluids.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL YB-4139 (CBS 6342), outlet of a
small lake at Camp Sargent near Peterborough, New Hampshire,
USA.
Ecology:
This species is known only from one strain, which was isolated
from the outflow of a small lake near Peterborough, New
Hampshire, USA (Wickerham and Kurtzman 1971).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 254 (NRRL Y-17396), believed to
be Klöcker's original isolate from soil, Himalayas, and obtained
through Ö. Winge; NRRL Y-1304 (CBS 5761), from soil; NRRL YB-4312
(CBS 2564), type strain of Hansenula beijerinckii, J.P. van der Walt,
from soil, South Africa; NRRL YB-4818 (CBS 4549), type strain of
Hansenula coprophila, M. Soneda, from elephant dung, Japan; NRRL
YB-3985, Hall Lake, Michigan, USA; NRRL YB-4948, from soil, Ohio,
USA; NRRL YB-4312, from soil, Chile (Wickerham 1970a). The following
strains maintained in the ARS Culture Collection were identified
from phenotype: NRRL YB-4569 (CBS 5260), K. Kodama, from fallen
leaves, Japan; NRRL Y-1667, from soil, Egypt; NRRL Y-2165, from soil,
Liberia; NRRL Y-1716, Y-1719, Y-1720, Y-1721, Y-1724, Y-1726, from
soil, Minnesota, USA; NRRL Y-7994, Y-7995, from soil, near New
Orleans, Louisiana, USA.
Ecology:
Judging from strain isolation data reported under “Origin of
the strains studied”, L. saturnus is worldwide in distribution and
common in soil, freshwater and leaf litter.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 255 (NRRL Y-17391), Klöcker's
culture from soil, Denmark; NRRL Y-1715 (CBS 1668), NRRL Y-1723
(CBS 1669), NRRL Y-838, NRRL Y-1725 (CBS 1670), all from soil,
Minnesota, USA (Wickerham 1970a).
Ecology:
Strains identified from DNA reassociation or from gene
sequencing have been isolated from soil in Denmark and from
Minnesota, USA. Consequently, the habitat and geographical range of
L. suaveolens appears similar to L. saturnus.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 5763 (NRRL YB-1657), NRRL YB-
1712, YB-1713, YB-1718, isolated from soil, Liberia; NRRL YB-3831,
from insect frass, unidentified tree, Gainesville, Florida, USA
(Kurtzman 1991a, Kurtzman et al. 2008).
Ecology:
Strains identified from molecular comparisons have been
isolated from soil in Liberia and from insect frass in Florida, USA. The
ecology of this species is likely to be the same as that of L. saturnus.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6591 (LKB-325, NRRL Y-7818), exudate
from a horse chestnut tree (Aesculus turbinate), Japan.
Ecology:
The only known strain of this species is the type culture,
which was isolated from a horse chestnut tree in Japan (Kodama and
Kyono 1974b).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7333 (NRRL Y-17921, ATCC 76360),
isolated from forest soil, South Africa, J.P. van der Walt.
Ecology:
The single known strain of L. arxii was isolated from forest
soil in South Africa (van der Walt et al. 1989d).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2516, isolated from soil, Magalies
Mountains, Transvaal, South Africa, J.P. van der Walt; CBS 7542
(NRRL Y-27504), type strain, from soil, Kwa-Mbonambi State Forest
Reserve, Natal, South Africa, J.P. van der Walt.
Ecology:
The two available strains of L. doorenjongii were isolated
from soil in South Africa (van der Walt et al. 1999).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7319 (NRRL Y-17848), type strain,
isolated from garden soil, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan, J.P. van der
Walt; CBS 7549, from uncultivated soil, Bronkhorstspruit District,
Transvaal; CBS 7550, from uncultivated soil, Frankfort, Free State,
South Africa, E.L. Jansen van Rensburg.
Ecology:
Lipomyces japonicus is known from soil in Japan and South
Africa (van der Walt et al. 1989c) and might be expected to occur in
soils from other parts of the world.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7729 (NRRL Y-27505), CBS 7731,
CBS 7732, CBS 7733, CBS 7734, isolated from forest soil, Knysna district,
Southern Cape Province, South Africa, J.P. van der Walt.
Ecology:
Lipomyces kockii is presently known only from South
African soils (van der Walt et al. 1999).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2514 (IFO 10375, NRRL Y-11553),
type strain, isolated from soil in a citrus orchard, Los Lomas,
Trinidad, J.H. Becking; CBS 7535, from soil, Magoeba’s Kloof,
Transvaal, South Africa; CBS 8113, CBS 8114, from soil, South Africa,
J.P. van der Walt.
Ecology:
The few known strains of L. kononenkoae have been isolated
exclusively from soil. Collection sites, as noted above, included
Trinidad and South Africa.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 944 (ATCC 32031, IFO 1288, NRRL
Y-2542; NRRL Y-11555), isolated from garden soil, The Netherlands,
L.E. den Dooren de Jong; CBS 2513 (IFO 10378, NRRL Y-11556), from
soil botanic garden, Leiden, The Netherlands, J.H. Becking; CBS 5841
(ATCC 10742, IFO 10379, NRRL Y-1351), A.C. Thaysen; CBS 5842 (ATCC
32371, IFO 10380, NRRL Y-6333), from soil, Wales, UK, D. Jones; CBS
7602, from cultivated podzolic soil, Biological Station of Perm
University, USSR, I.P. Bab’eva; CBS 7603, from cultivated meadow soil,
Kirghiz, Armenia, I.P. Bab’eva.
Ecology:
Lipomyces lipofer is known only from soil isolations. On the
basis of strain histories, above, the species is likely to be worldwide
in distribution.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7600, CBS 7601, isolated from
uncultivated soil, Mt-aux-Sources Plateau, Natal, South Africa; CBS
7605, from uncultivated soil, Phuthaditjhaba, Orange Free State,
South Africa, E.L. Jansen van Rensburg; CBS 7661 (NRRL Y-27506),
type strain, from soil, Drakensberg, Natal, South Africa, E.E. Pretorius;
CBS 7737, from forest soil, Nature’s Valley, Southern Cape Province,
South Africa, J.P. van der Walt.
Ecology:
All known strains of L. mesembrius have been isolated from
soil in South Africa (van der Walt et al. 1999).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7107 (NRRL Y-17247, ATCC
76359), isolated from frass of bark beetle infesting moribund fig tree
(Ficus tripoda); CBS 7406, from frass of an ambrosia beetle
(Crossotarsus externedentatus) in a tree, Macaranga capensis
(Euphorbiaceae), both strains from South Africa, J.P. van der Walt.
Ecology:
Most species of Lipomyces have been isolated exclusively
from soil, but L. oligophaga is presently known only from insect frass
from trees in South Africa (van der Walt and von Arx 1987b).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 10300 (NRRL Y-27927), CBS
10301 (NRRL Y-27928), isolated from mixed forest soil, near the
water, Bai San Island, Nha Trang; CBS 10302 (NRRL Y-27929), from
grassland soil, Cam Thuy, Thanh Hoa; CBS 10303 (NRRL Y-27930),
CBS 10304 (NRRL Y-27931), from mixed forest soil, near the water,
Cat Ba Island, Quang Ninh, all from Vietnam, V.N. Thanh.
Ecology:
The five known strains of L. orientalis were isolated from
soil in various regions of Vietnam (Thanh 2006).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7407 (NRRL Y-17922, ATCC 76360),
CBS 7408, isolated from frass of an ambrosia beetle (Crossotarus externedentatus)
in a tree, Macaranga capensis (Euphorbiaceae), South Africa,
J.P. van derWalt.
Ecology:
As with L. oligophaga, strains of L. smithiae are known only
from insect frass rather than from soil, the typical habitat for Lipomyces.
From multigene sequence analysis, the preceding two species are not
closely related to each other or to L. starkeyi, the type species (Fig. 43.1).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 5608 (ATCC 44833, NRRL
Y-7042), isolated from soil, Nigeria, E. Drouhet; CBS 7534, from soil,
Pretoria district, Transvaal, South Africa; CBS 7543, from soil,
Kwa-Mbonambi State Forest Reserve, Natal, South Africa; CBS 7681,
CBS 7682, from soil, Bronkhorstspruit District, Transvaal, South
Africa, J.P. van der Walt.
Ecology:
Lipomyces spencer-martinsiae is presently known from soil
in Nigeria and various regions of South Africa. As with other species
of Lipomyces, the role that L. spencer-martinsiae plays in soil ecology
is unknown.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 1807 (IFO 1289, NRRL Y-1388,
NRRL Y-11557), isolated from soil, USA, R.L. Starkey; CBS 1809 (ATCC
64135, IFO 10382, NRRL Y-11558), dry mutant of CBS 1807, R.L.
Starkey; CBS 2512 (IFO 10383, NRRL Y-11559), from soil, Wageningen,
The Netherlands, H.J. Becking; CBS 6047 (ATCC 64137, NRRL Y-11561),
from soil, Haren, The Netherlands, N.J.W. Kreger-van Rij; CBS 7536,
from soil, Thornton, Canada; CBS 7537, from soil, Botanic garden,
Cape Town, South Africa; CBS 7544, CBS 7545, from soil, Mount
Sheba forest reserve, Transvaal, South Africa, J.P. van der Walt; CBS
8064, from lemons, France, F. Seigle-Murandi, and 12 additional
strains isolated from soil of various locations in South Africa.
Ecology:
On the basis of the strain histories reported above, L. starkeyi
appears worldwide in distribution, and nearly all isolates are
from soil.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7251 (NRRL Y-17356, ATCC 66456),
isolated from a skin lesion on a cow, Finland, E. Tunnela.
Ecology: unknown

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 1808 (IFO 10367, NRRL Y-11564),
isolated from soil, USA, R.L. Starkey; CBS 1810 (IFO 10388, NRRL
Y-7038), from soil, Ottawa, Canada, Harmsen; CBS 2511 (IFO 10389,
NRRL Y-11565), from soil, Monaco, J.H. Becking; CBS 5607 (IFO
10390), from soil, Reunion, M. Dommerques; CBS 5910 (ATCC 32372,
IFO 10391, NRRL Y-11562), type strain, from soil, USSR, I.P. Bab'eva;
CBS 5910.1 (IFO 10392), from Schernozom soil, Orenburg district,
USSR, I.P. Bab’eva; CBS 5911, CBS 6049, CBS 6050, CBS 6051, from soil,
USSR, I.P. Bab’eva; CBS 6132, from soil, J. Pullen; CBS 7656, from
uncultivated surface soil, Transvaal, South Africa, J.P. van der Walt,
and seven additional strains from soil in various locations.
Ecology:
On the basis of strain histories, above, L. tetrasporus is
worldwide in distribution and has only been isolated from soil.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7532 (NRRL Y-27507), CBS 7533,
isolated from soil, Helspoort, Eastern Cape Province, South Africa,
J.P. van der Walt.
Ecology:
The species is known only from two strains that were isolated
from soil in South Africa (van der Walt et al. 1999).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7557, isolated from soil, near
Curepipe, Mauritius; CBS 7558, from soil, near Vacoas, Mauritius,
J.P. van der Walt.
Ecology:
The species is known only from two strains that were isolated
from soil in Mauritius (van der Walt et al. 1999).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL YB-4239 (CBS 2605), type strain
of Saccharomyces elongisporus, isolated from concentrated orange
juice (Recca and Mrak 1952); CBS 2606 (NRRL YB-4240), from soil,
South Africa, from J. P. van der Walt; CBS 5912 (NRRL Y-7681), from a
finger nail, Finland; CBS 6182 (NRRL Y-7682), from baby cream, The
Netherlands.
Ecology:
Lodderomyces elongisporus has been isolated from soft
drinks and juice concentrates (Stratford and James 2003), natural fermentations
of cocoa (Schwan and Wheals 2003), soil, an infected finger
nail, human blood infections (Lockhart et al. 2008a) and from
baby cream. The natural habitat of this species is therefore uncertain.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 197.35, mating type a, isolated
from wood pulp, E. Rennerfelt, Sweden; CBS 162.80 (CBS H-14215,
holotype of the teleomorph, holotype of Trichosporon capitatum, from
bovine mastitis milk, G.A. Pepin,Weybridge, UK; CBS 571.82 (CBS 2364,
ATCC 10663), lectotype strain of Trichosporon capitatum, from wood
pulp factory with an air-tight warming system, E. Rennerfelt; CBS
579.82 (CBS 5583) and CBS 580.82 (CBS 5584), mating type a, all
authentic for Geotrichum linkii, from sputum, L. do Carmo-Sousa; CBS
573.82, from yeast cake, A.P. Struyck; CBS 207.83 (ATCC 46132), type
strain of Blastoschizomyces pseudotrichosporon, from sputum, I.F. Salkin,
USA; CBS 716.84, from the digestive tract of swine, H. Saëz, Paris Zoo,
France; CBS 327.86, from blood culture of human patient, J.P. Manzella,
USA; CBS 328.86, from blood culture of human patient with leukemia,
E. Drouhet. Other strains examined: sputum(five); oral infections (two).
Ecology:
The species occurs worldwide in different heated habitats,
including the digestive and respiratory tracts of human and other
animals.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 518.90 (CBS 4115), isolated from
phenolic waste water, S. Windisch; CBS 519.90 (CBS 4825), CBS
520.90 (CBS 4826), CBS 521.90 (CBS 4827, NRRL Y-17630), from a
wine cellar, J.P. van der Walt, South Africa; CBS 522.90 (CBS 6057),
from an asphalt plant waste lagoon, D.G. Ahearn; CBS 523.90 (CBS
7197), unknown, M. Höfer; CBS 101346 (CBS 1971), from industrial
sulfate waste, S. Windisch.
Ecology:
Strains of the species have been isolated from a wine cellar
and from phenolic and sulfate containing waste.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 107.12, origin unknown,
P. Claussen; CBS 108.12 (NRRL Y-17563), possibly ex-holotype of the
teleomorph, P. Lindner; CBS 151.30, type strain of Oospora magnusii,
from exudate of an oak (Quercus sp., Fagaceae), W. Stautz; CBS
234.85, from exudate of an oak (Quercus alba), B.M. Wright,
Pennsylvania, USA.
Ecology:
The species is probably restricted to the slime flux of oak
trees.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 192.55 (CBS 2508, NRRL Y-17574),
isolated from tannin concentrate, C. Ramírez; CBS 634.85 (CBS 2544,
NRRL Y-1523, IFO 1201), authentic strain of Oospora sericea, from
slime flux of oak (Quercus sp., Fagaceae), W. Stautz, Germany; CBS
635.85 (CBS 4731, IFO 10827), unknown, M. Waller, Germany; CBS
749.85 ( BPI 3528), type strain of Dipodascus ambrosiae, from an
insect tunnel, L.R. Batra, California, USA.
Ecology:
The species seems to be restricted to the slime fluxes of
deciduous trees. The strain obtained from tannin concentrate initially
may have had a similar ecological niche.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 244.85 (NRRL Y-17578, IFO 10809)
from cactus rot, M.A. Lachance, Arizona, USA.
Ecology:
The type strain of M. spicifer was associated with insects on
Opuntia rots.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 780.96 (NRRL Y-17816), from rotting
saguaro cactus (Carnegiea gigantean), Southern Arizona, USA,
H.J. Phaff; CBS 781.96, from rotting cladode of Opuntia ficus-indica,
Tucson, Arizona, USA, H.J. Phaff.
Ecology:
The species is associated with necrotic tissues of cactus species
indigenous to the Americas (Starmer et al. 1990).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 765.70 (NRRL Y-7288, IFO 10810,
ATCC 22540), from a wet conveyor at a prune dehydration plant,
M.W. Miller, California, USA.
Ecology: unknown

Paragraph of Species Studied:
SUB 05-213.1 (CBS 10289, NRRL
Y-27921) and SUB 05-213.2 (CBS 10290, NRRL Y-27922), isolated from a
beetle (Mylabris tristigma, Coleoptera, Meloidae); SUB 05-212.1 and SUB
05-217.1a, from a fruit fly (Scaptodrosophila sp., Diptera, Drosophilidae); SUB 05-215.1, from a Buprestid beetle; the insects were found in a morning
glory (Ipomoea hildebrandtii, Convolvulaceae) in the Serengeti
National Park, Tanzania; UWOPS 07-204.2 and others, from clavicorn
beetles, vicinity of Kabarnet, Kenya.
Ecology:
Little is known on the occurrence of Metschnikowia
(M. aberdeeniae) or other species of the same guild in African floricolous
insects. Those insects that carried M. aberdeeniae also contained
Kodamaea kakaduensis, previously isolated from nitidulid beetles of
the Australasian biogeographic region, and Candida restingae, known
from various floricolous insects recovered in Australasia as well as
the Neotropics (Lachance et al. 2001e, 2006a, b; Rosa et al. 1999),
and single isolates of a few other species.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7744 (UWOPS 91-207.1), CBS
7745 (UWOPS 92-210.1) and several others were isolated from basal
rots of leaves of blue agave plants (Agave tequilana var. azul,
Agavaceae), Jalisco, Mexico.
Ecology:
All known strains were recovered from basal leaf rots of the
blue agave plant that is used in the production of tequila (Lachance
1993b). The rots are bright red and have a strong acetic odor. They
harbor high counts of Clavispora lusitaniae and Dekkera anomala (or
Brettanomyces anomalus), which suggests a complex association
involving multiple insects, which are attracted by volatile compounds,
such as ethanol and acetic acid.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
HA 1622, isolated from gut of a caterpillar
of a moth (Helicoverpa armigera, Lepidoptera, Noctuidae); HA
1657, frass of a caterpillar of European cornborer (Ostrinia nubilalis,
Lepidoptera, Crambidae), both collected on corn (Zea mays, Poaceae).
Ecology:
Molnár and Prillinger (2005) remarked on the abundance
of species related to M. andauensis present in caterpillars and frass of
grass moths. The potential role and specificity of the yeasts in that
ecosystem is not known.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UWOPS 99-103.3.1 (CBS 9064, NRRL
Y-27427), UWOPS 99-103.3.2, UWOPS 99-103.4 (CBS 9065, NRRL
Y-27428), and UWOPS 99-108.2.2, isolated from flowers of Silver
Cholla (Opuntia echinocarpa, Cactaceae), and UWOPS 01-307.3, h1,
from sap beetle (Carpophilus sp., Coleoptera, Nitidulidae); all from
Lost Dutchman State Park, Arizona, USA.
Ecology:
Metschnikowia arizonensis was recovered on two occasions,
2 years apart, from the same single locality, in nitidulid beetles
recovered from cholla (cylindrical prickly pear) flowers. The same
substrate collected in six localities in Arizona and southern California
yielded more or less pure cultures of Candida cleridarum. The reason
for the occurrence of M. arizonensis at only one of these localities is
not clear.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 5847 (NRRL Y-7013), CBS 5848,
UCD-FST 68-48, 68-49, 68-50 and 68-51. All strains were isolated
from Antarctic seawater in the vicinity of the South Shetland Islands
and obtained from J.W. Fell.
Ecology:
Ecology: In a study of the role of bacteria as sources of digestive
enzymes, Donachie and Zdanowski (1998) reported the presence
of M. australis in the stomach content of the Antarctic krill
Euphausia superba. Based on this observation and the origin of the
isolates recovered by Fell and Hunter (1968), the species is probably
associated with various marine invertebrates of Antarctic
waters.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS
5575, selected as neotype by L.J. Wickerham, who first isolated it in
culture from sporocysts of the parasitic strigeid trematode
Diplostomum flexicaudum inhabiting the digestive gland of the snail
Stagnicola emarginata angulata in a fresh water lake in Michigan,
USA. Sporocysts of Diplostomum flexicaudum (5); brine shrimp
(Artemia salina) (13); white pond lily (Castalia odorata,
Nympheaceae) from a lake in Wisconsin, USA (1).
Ecology:
Nine strains of the variety bicuspidata that were isolated
from diseased brine shrimp (Artemia salina) taken from salt ponds
(ca. 10% NaCl) in southern California (Lachance et al. 1976) initially
did not grow in the usual assimilation media unless they were supplemented
with 2% NaCl. Asci of these strains have been observed to
discharge their spores from the tip of the peduncle, occasionally
quite forcefully. This observation raised the possibility of active
mechanical predation for the variety bicuspidata (reported previously
as M. bicuspidata var. australis). All strains of the variety californica
came from sea water or kelp off the coast of southern and central
California, and those strains of the variety chathamia came from
freshwater ponds.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6010
(UCD-FST 67-100), isolated by Phaff from Pacific Ocean water near
Point Reyes, California. Sea water or kelp off the coast of California
from San Diego to Point Reyes in central California (23).

CBS 5980
(IMS 23-414, UCD-FST 67-2) isolated by Fell and Hunter (1968) from
a fresh water pond near the ocean on Chatham Island. Freshwater
ponds on Chatham Island, New Zealand (three).

UWOPS 96-104.2 (CBS 8431, NRRL
Y-27451), UWOPS 96 101.1 (CBS 8432, NRRL Y-27452), and several
other strains isolated from flowers of field bindweed (Convolvulus
arvensis, Convolvulaceae) or a nitidulid beetle (Conotelus obscurus,
Coleoptera, Nitidulidae) collected in these flowers, London, Ontario,
Canada; UWOPS 97-121 and several others from hedge bindweed
(Calystegia sepium, Convolvulaceae), London, Ontario; UWOPS 97-
201 and others from flowers of Calystegia sepium or Conotelus
obscurus collected from these flowers, Syracuse, New York, USA;
UWOPS 99-511.1 and several others from Conotelus obscurus in flowers
of Calystegia sepium or at the tip of Long Point, Ontario; UWOPS
99-541.1 and others from Conotelus obscurus in flowers of
Convolvulus arvensis, Maitland Valley, Ontario; SUB 99-203.2, from
Conotelus sp. in flowers of morning glory (Ipomoea purpurea,
Convolvulaceae), Smoky Mountains National Park, Tennessee, USA;
SUB 99-207.1, from Conotelus sp. in flowers of Ipomoea pandurata,
Smoky Mountains National Park, Tennessee, USA. UWOPS 04-402.1
and a few others collected in Knox County, Maine, USA; UWOPS
06-155.1 and many others collected in Huntingdon County, Québec,
Canada; from Conotelus obscurus recovered in flowers of Calystegia
sepium.
Ecology:
The ascospores of M. borealis are large, but not as large as
those of M. hawaiiensis. They are adorned with helical arrays of barbs whose function is not clear (Lachance et al. 1998b). The barbs, which
are presumed to be present also in other large-spored species, may
play a role in host penetration. M. borealis appears to be the only
member of the large-spored clade to be found in the northernmost
reaches of the Conotelus/Convolvulaceae ecosystem (Lachance et al.
2001e). So far, the range extends from Tennessee to Québec northward
and Maine eastward. Surprisingly, of all species in the clade
identified so far, M. borealis has the highest maximum growth
temperature.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UFMG 03-T67.1 (CBS 10409, NRRL
Y-48067), UFMG 03-T68.1 (CBS 10410, NRRL Y-48068), and several other
strains isolated from a nitudulid beetle (Conotelus sp., Coleoptera,
Nitidulidae) foundinflowers ofmorningglory(Ipomoeacarnea,Convolvulaceae)
or the flowers themselves, inTocantins State, Central Brazil.
Ecology:
Metschnikowia cerradonensis was isolated from flowers collected
on the banks of a small lake ("fervedouro") in the city of São
Felix do Tocantins in the region of Jalapão, Brazil. Samples from
nearby localities within the cerrado ecosystem yielded only other
species, including M. continentalis, indicating that M. cerradonensis
might be endemic to Jalapão.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-27615 (CBS 9803, Gibson-AT),
isolated from eggs of green lacewing (Chrysoperla sp., Neuroptera,
Chrysopidae), Tucson, Arizona, USA. Other strains: four other strains
were studied by Suh et al. (2004a). They came from eggs or adults of
Chrysoperla sp. or Chrysoperla comanche.
Ecology:
The discovery of M. chrysoperlae came as part of a study of
yeasts found in the gut of lacewings (Suh et al. 2004a). The 14 insects
specimens examined yielded, in addition, the new species Candida
picachoensis and Candida pimensis. These species are suspected to
engage in a symbiotic relationship with lacewings, although the
nature of the association is not known.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UWOPS 03-134.2 (CBS 9739, NRRL
Y-27629), UWOPS 03-147.2, and UWOPS 03-202.1 (CBS 9740, NRRL
Y-27630), isolated from nitidulid beetle (Conotelus spp., Coleoptera,
Nitidulidae) collected in flowers of wood rose (Merremia tuberosa,
Convolvulaceae), near Santa Cecilia, Guanacaste, Costa Rica; UFMG
Toc121.1 and UFMG Toc203.1, from morning glory (Ipomoea sp.) flowers,
Tocantins State, Brazil, received from C.A. Rosa.
Additional strains: Ten strains have been recovered from various
flowers in Sao Paulo State, Brazil, by C.C.C. Ruivo.
Ecology:
Metschnikowia colocasiae has been recovered as a rare component
of the yeast community of certain flowers and associated
insects in distant Neotropical localities. This leads one to suspect that
the species is associated with a yet unspecified insect that visits the
same flowers as those utilized by Conotelus spp.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UFMG 95-401.1 and several others
isolated from flowers of morning glory (Ipomoea sp.,
Convolvulaceae), Belo Horizonte, Minas Gerais; UFMG 96-173 (CBS
8429, NRRL Y-27449) (AF034126, AF534189), UFMG 96-179 (CBS
8430, NRRL Y-27450), h2, and many others from flowers
or associated nitidulid beetles (Conotelus spp., Coleoptera,
Nitidulidae) of Ipomoea cairica var. fistulosa, Salinas, Minas Gerais:
UFMG Toc05-3.1, from flowers or associated Conotelus spp. of
Ipomoea carnea, Tocantins State; Brazil, received from C.A. Rosa.
MH124 (CBS 9037) from nectar of common bugloss (Anchusa
officinalis, Boraginaceae), Ingelheim, Germany, received from
M. Herzberg.
Ecology:
Metschnikowia continentalis occurs in association with a
flower-associated nitidulid beetle of the genus Conotelus and has
been recovered in several localities in Brazil. The isolation of a single
strain in Germany was unexpected, especially since it was part
of an intense sampling from flowers pollinated by bees, which
yielded vast numbers of M. gruessii and M. reukaufii (Herzberg et al.
2002).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 9905 (NRRL Y-27750, BG 03-5-4-
1-15) and NRRL Y-27816 (BG 03-5-4-1-25), isolated from the gut of a
soldier beetle (Rhaxonycha sp., Coleoptera, Cantharidae), from
flowers of dogwood (Cornus drummondii, Cornaceae), Baton Rouge,
Louisiana, USA.
Ecology:
The isolation of such an unusual species as M. corniflorae
from beetles in the family Cantharidae opens the door to a new
world of possibilities. This beetle family is unusual in that some of
the species defend their food source against other conspecific individuals,
thus the common name, soldier beetle. Although many are
pollen and nectar consumers, their larvae are often carnivorous.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UWOPS 01-142b3 (CBS 9063, NRRL
Y-27430), UWOPS 01-521a4, and a few other strains isolated from
nitidulid beetles (Conotelus sp., Coleoptera, Nitidulidae) in morning
glory (Ipomoea indica) near Santa Cecilia; UWO 03-172.2 (CBS 9741,
NRRL Y-27631) and a few others from Conotelus sp. in various
Ipomoea species near Lake Arenal; Guanacaste Province, Costa Rica.
Ecology:
Metschnikowia dekortorum occurs in the same substrates
and localities as M. similis, namely a nitidulid beetle (Conotelus sp.)
found in flowers of Convolvulaceae in humid localities of northern
Costa Rica. The two species also co-exist with the moderate relatives
M. lochheadii, M. santaceciliae, and Candida ipomoeae. The significance
of these species as possible symbionts is not known.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UWOPS 83-1135.3 (CBS 8809, NRRL
Y-27458), isolated from flower of morning glory (Ipomoea sp.,
Convolvulaceae); UWOPS 83-1154.3 and UWOPS 83-1143.1 (CBS
8810, NRRL Y-27459), from fruit fly (Drosophila bromeliae) collected
from flowers of the same plant; Grand Cayman, Cayman Islands.
Ecology:
At the time of collection, the only floricolous insect examined
was Drosophila bromeliae. It remains possible that other
insects, including nitidulid beetles, act as vectors or symbionts to
M. drosophilae. Other known but unpublished members of the clade
have been isolated, one from plant leaves in Thailand (T. Nakase,
personal communication, see Fig. 46.1), and another from caterpillar
frass in Costa Rica (M.A. Lachance and D.H Janzen, unpublished
data).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 8853 (NRRL Y-27328), isolated
from table grapes, Israel.
Ecology:
The isolation of a single isolate from grapes precludes ecological
generalizations. However, the origins of other members of the
M. pulcherrima clade support the idea that these yeasts are associated
with the plant-insect interface.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7657, isolated from the nectaries
of willow leaved hebe (Hebe salicifolia, Scrophulariaceae), Oeiras,
Portugal; MH19 (CBS 8991), from nectar of fire weed (Epilobium
angustifolium, Onagraceae), Marburg, Germany; MH 41 (CBS 9029)
from nectar of comfrey (Symphytum officinalis, Boraginaceae),
Marburg, Germany; MH 53 (CBS 9033) from nectar of meadow sage
(Salvia pratensis, Lamiaceae), Ingelheim, Germany; MH 127, from
nectar of greater yellow rattle (Rhinanthus alectorolophus,
Scrophulariaceae), Ingelheim, Germany; MH 138 (CBS 9031) from
nectar of red clover (Trifolium pratense, Fabaceae), Marburg,
Germany; and several others received from M. Brysch-Herzberg.
Ecology:
Brysch-Herzberg and colleagues (2002) examined the nectar
of many herbaceous plants in Germany. Early in the season, a
broad mixture of yeast species was dominated by basidiomycetes
that are ostensibly wind-dispersed. As pollinator activity became
obvious, a larger proportion of isolates consisted of ascomycetes,
dominated by M. reukaufii or M. gruessii, depending on the samples.
Bumble bees (Bombus spp.) visiting these flowers were also examined
(M. Herzberg, personal communication) and found to harbor
strains of Candida (Metschnikowia) kunwiensis and Candida bombi,
indicating that other insect vectors may be involved with the transmission
of M. gruessii. M. gruessii has not been reported outside
Europe, in contrast to M. reukaufii, which appears to be global in
distribution.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
All strains were isolated from a nitidulid
beetle (Prosopeus cf. bidens, Coleoptera, Nitidulidae) on flowers
of plants located along the Hamakua ditch, near Waimea, Island of
Hawai’i; UWOPS 04-207.1 (CBS 10056, NRRL Y-27834) and another
from kanawao (Broussaisia arguta, Hydrangeaceae); UWOPS 04-204.1
(CBS 10055, NRRL Y-27833) and four others, Hawai’i holly (Ilex anomala,
Aquifoliaceae); two strains from lava clermontia (Clermontia
calophylla, Campanulaceae).
Ecology:
Metschnikowia hamakuensis has hitherto been isolated only
in samples from the north end of the island of Hawai'i, in a location
characterized by abundant cloud cover and precipitation as well as
cool temperatures. It is associated with insects and plants that are
endemic to Hawai'i.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UWOPS 87-2167.2 (CBS 7432), and
many others from flowers of morning glory (Ipomoea indica,
Convolvulaceae); UWOPS 87-2203.2 (CBS 7433), and many
others from a drosophilid (Exaloscaptomyza calliginosa, Diptera,
Drosophilidae); UWOPS 91-650.1 from fruit fly (Drosophila floricola);
UWOPS 00-663.2 and many others from a nitidulid beetle (Conotelus
mexicanus, Coleoptera: Nitidulidae); UWOPS 00-673.2 and many
others from a nitidulid beetle (Prosopeus subaeneus, Coleoptera,
Nitidulidae) on Ipomoeae indica in the vicinity of Kipuka Puaulu,
island of Hawai'i.
Ecology:
Metschnikowia hawaiiensis is so far confined to the island
of Hawai'i and may even be restricted to flowers and insects found
in a few small forest fragments of the southern slopes of the
Mauna Loa volcano. The species shares this habitat with other
yeasts in the Metschnikowia clade, including M. lochheadii, Candida
ipomoeae, Candida kipukae and Candida hawaiiana (Lachance et al.
2003a). These species are thought to be adventives, and may be
competing for the same niche, although some partitioning may be
occurring. M. lochheadii and Candida ipomoeae are more frequently
isolated from Conotelus mexicanus, a beetle that was introduced to
the Hawaiian archipelago in the early part of the 20th century. The
yeasts may have been vectored by this insect from the American
mainland. M. hawaiiensis and C. kipukae show an association with
Prosopeus subaeneus, another small nitidulid beetle that is endemic
to the island of Hawai'i. The last two yeast species differ from the
rest by their lower maximum growth temperature (31 33 C, compared
to 35 36 C in the introduced species), which may represent
an adaptation to the cooler temperature of the habitat. Other
Hawaiian endemic Metschnikowia species have lower maximum
growth temperatures. The lowest is 26 C, seen in strain UWOPS
04-218.3, a representative of an undescribed species (Fig. 46.1).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UWOPS 95-797.2 (CBS 8433, NRRL
Y-27453), isolated from fruit fly (Drosophila hibisci) from a flower of
native rosella (Hibiscus heterophyllus, Malvaceae); UWOPS 95-805.1
(CBS 8434, NRRL Y-27454), flower of H. heterophyllus; UWOPS
95-938.4, from a nitidulid beetle (Aethina sp., Coleoptera:
Nitidulidae), from a flower of H. heterophyllus; several other strains
were collected from Hibiscus spp. flowers and their insects in various
localities on the east and north coasts of Australia; UWOPS 98-126.4,
flower of morning glory (Ipomoea sp., Convolvulaceae), Northern
Territory, Australia.
Ecology:
Metschnikowia hibisci is a low frequency member of the
yeast community of Hibiscus flowers and associated insects (drosophilid
flies and nitidulid beetles). The community is dominated by
Kodamaea anthophila and Wickerhamiella australiensis. Samples taken
from similar substrates outside Australia (Lachance et al. 2001e) did
not yield the species, although M. orientalis, a distant relative, was
recovered, also at low frequencies, in Rarotonga (Cook Islands) and
Malaysia.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UWOPS 04-112.5 (CBS 10058, NRRL
Y-27836), UWOPS 04-109.1 (CBS 10057, NRRL Y-27835), and two
other strains, from a nitidulid beetle (Prosopeus collaris, Coleoptera,
Nitidulidae) in flowers of forest clermontia (Clermontia kakeana,
Campanulaceae) on Kamakou Mountain, Moloka'i, Hawai’i; UWOPS
04-206.1, from Prosopeus cf. bidens in a flower of Ilex anomala
(Aquifoliaceae); UWOPS 04-208.1, from P. cf. bidens in a flower of
kanawao (Broussaisia arguta, Hydrangeaceae); and UWOPS 04-217.1,
from a Drosophila sp. larva in a flower of lava clermontia (Clermontia
calophylla); Upper Hamakua ditch, island of Hawai'i.
Ecology:
Metschnikowia kamakouana has the broadest distribution
among Hawaiian endemic large-spored Metschnikowia species, being
found on both the islands Moloka'i and Hawai'i. The species also
appears to be the least specialized in terms of vector insect species.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
KCTC 7998 (CBS 8854), isolated fromflower
of lily (Lilium sp., Liliaceae) and KCTC 7828 (CBS 9066), from
flower of morning glory (Ipomoea sp., Convolvulaceae), Kyungsang
province, Korea.
Ecology:
The two known isolates came from flowers of two unrelated
plant species that are probably visited by similar vector insects.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 4823, isolated by van Uden and
Castelo-Branco (1961) from sea water off La Jolla, California, USA, and
three other strains.
Ecology:
Metschnikowia krissii is known almost exclusively from a
small number of isolates collected by van Uden off the southern
California coast. However, there are reports that the species is an important pathogen of copepods in the Strait of Georgia, British
Columbia, Canada. Seki and Fulton (1969) reported that 5% of copepods
(Calanus sp.) collected at depths of 200 m or more showed distinct
signs of infection by a yeast that formed asci with single
aciculate ascospores. On that basis, they identified the pathogen as
M. krissii. Isolates were cultured and found capable of extracellular
hydrolysis of chondroitin sulfate and proteins, which was thought to
be important in defining the pathogenicity of the yeast.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 9676 (MH275), isolated from
bumble bee (Bombus cryptarum, Hymenoptera, Apidae), Germany;
CBS 9067 (SG99 26, KCTC 17041), type strain of Candida kunwiensis,
flower of morning glory (Ipomoea batatas, Convolvulaceae), Korea;
CBS 9679 (X196.3), from Bombus pratorum; MH266, MH277, MH402,
from Bombus terrestris; MH304, from Bombus hortorum; MH394, from
Bombus lapidarius; MH397, from Bombus pascuorum; MH356, from
flower of stinking hellebore (Helleborus foetidus, Ranunculaceae), all
from Germany.
Ecology:
The isolation of M. kunwiensis from flowers or associated
bumblebees suggests an association with these pollinators.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UWOPS 87ASB2.3 (PYCC 4605, CBS
9131), isolated from flower of milkweed (Asclepias syriaca,
Asclepiadaceae), in South Bombay, New York, USA; SUB 99-220.4
(PYCC 5757), flower of larger bindweed (Calystegia sepium,
Convolvulaceae), Smoky Mountains National Park, Tennessee, USA.
Ecology:
Metschnikowia lachancei is apparently associated with
insects that visit various flowers, but the low frequency of isolation
precludes further conclusions on habitat specificity.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UWOPS 00-133.2 (NRRL Y-27457, CBS
8807), isolated from a nitidulid beetle (Conotelus sp., Coleoptera,
Nitidulidae), in a fallen flower of a “Roble de sabana” tree (Tabebuia
rosea, Bignoniaceae) and many other strains from Conotelus sp. in
flowers of various Convolvulaceae in Guanacaste Province, Costa
Rica; UWOPS99-661.1 (NRRL Y-27456, CBS 8808), from Conotelus
mexicanus in a flower of white “angel's trumpet” (Brugmansia candida,
Solanaceae), Maui, and many others from Conotelus mexicanus,
hibiscus flower beetle (Aethina concolor, both Coleoptera:
Nitidulidae), and fruit fly (Drosophila floricola) from flowers of various
Convolvulaceae and other plants in the Hawaiian Islands, USA.
Ecology:
The geographic distribution of M. lochheadii is of special
interest. The species is recovered at a high frequency in Guanacaste
Province of Costa Rica, as well as Hawaiian lowlands (Lachance et al.
2003a). In continental populations, both mating types are found in
approximately equal numbers, but all Hawaiian isolates are of the
single mating type h2. This serves as evidence that the species was
introduced from the American mainland through the importation of
material that contained the beetle Conotelus mexicanus (Lachance
et al. 2001b), resulting in a founder effect. The beetle is known to
have invaded the Hawaiian archipelago in the middle of the 20th
Century (Nishida 1957). Populations of M. lochheadii from five
Hawaiian Islands were studied, together with several Costa Rican isolates,
by sequencing of the rDNA intergenic spacers and genotyping
of polymorphic DNA markers (Lachance et al. 2008b). The Hawaiian
isolates were practically identical, but differed from continental isolates
in many of the loci examined, adding more evidence in favor of
a single introduction.
The spatial distribution of M. lochheadii in relation to other
Metschnikowia species is also worthy of attention. In Costa Rica,
M. lochheadii is the only species found in Conotelus spp. in the
warmer, drier lowlands of Guanacaste (e.g., Santa Rosa National Park
and vicinity). In the cooler uplands, situated near the volcanic rainforests
of the Guanacaste Cordillera, the same habitat is shared with
several other species, including M. dekortorum, M. santaceciliae, and
at least four other relatives. A similar partitioning is seen in the
Hawaiian Islands. Samples taken in the warm lowlands of five islands
yielded almost exclusively M. lochheadii. Sympatry with M. hawaiiensis
was observed in Kipuka Puaulu, a cooler site located at a higher
elevation, where M. lochheadii may be acting as an invasive exotic on
its way to eliminating an endemic relative (Lachance et al. 2003a).
The habitat partitioning may be linked partly to differences in the
maximum growth temperatures of these species, and partly to insect
vector specificity. In Kipuka Puaulu, Hawai'i, M. lochheadii predominates
in the introduced beetle Conotelus mexicanus, whereas
M. hawaiiensis exhibits a closer association with the endemic beetle
Prosopeus subaeneus. M. lochheadii was also absent in various
Hawaiian endemic nitidulids that harbor other large-spored
Metschnikowia species, related to M. hawaiiensis and apparently
endemic to other parts of the archipelago (Lachance et al. 2005).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 5946, isolated from a flower of
tufted vetch (Vicia cracca, Fabaceae), Russia; CBS 6798 (type of
Schizoblastosporion kobayashii), from exudate of Casuarina sp.
(Casuarinaceae), an evergreen shrub or tree, Japan. This strain produced
asci but no ascospores were observed.
Ecology:
The rare occurrence of M. lunata precludes ecological
generalizations.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UWO 04-190.1 (CBS 10060, NRRL
Y-27838) isolated from a nitidulid beetle (Prosopeus abnormalis,
Coleoptera: Nitidulidae) collected in a flower of oha wai nui (Clermontia
arborescens, Campanulacae), Waikamoi Preserve, Maui, Hawai'i, USA;
UWOPS 04-110.4 (CBS 10059, NRRL Y-27837), from Prosopeus collaris
collected in a flower of oha wai (Clermontia kakeana), Kamakou
Mountain, Moloka'i; UWO PS 04-107.4 from P. collaris collected in a
flower of C. kakeana, Kamakou Mountain, Moloka'i; Hawai'i.1
Ecology:
Metschnikowia mauinuiana was collected on Maui and
Molokai, and was named after the early pleiostocene island of Maui
Nui, based on the speculation that the species may have been endemic
to that island before its break-up approximately 0.3 0.4 million years
ago. On Molokai, the species is sympatric with M. kamakouana, which
is thought to be more ancient (Lachance et al. 2005).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 9907 (NRRL Y-27753) and one
other strain, isolated from the gut of a lacewing (Ceraeochrysa lineaticornis,
Neuroptera, Chrysopidae), caught at lights, Walker, Louisiana.
Ecology:
Metschnikowia noctiluminum is restricted in occurrence to the
gut of a particular species of lacewing, which suggests a strong symbiosis.
However, the nature of the association is not known. As indicated in
Fig. 46.24, culturing asci in the presence of the filamentous fungus
Cladosporium gossypiicola causes asci to appear thin-walled and to
release their ascospores terminally, presumably due to the action of lytic
hydrolases produced by this fungus (Nguyen et al. 2006). A similar apical
ascospore release was reported for M. bicuspidata by Lachance et al.
(1976), when the asci were observed in situ in infected brine shrimp. In
the presence of nematodes (Panagrellus sp.) and their endogenous bacteria,
mature asci of M. hawaiiensis disappeared completely, giving way to
abundant free ascospores (M.A. Lachance, unpublished data). Taken
together, these observations suggest that interactions between yeasts
and non-yeast species within a community may be integral to the
yeasts' life history. Analogous conclusions have been drawn recently on
the role of ascospores in the interaction between Saccharomyces and
Drosophila species (Coluccio et al. 2008, Reuter et al. 2007).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UWOPS 99-745.6 (CBS 10331, NRRL
Y-27991), isolated from nitidulid beetle (Aethina concolor, Coleoptera,
Nitidulidae) in flower of unidentified species of Rubiaceae; UWOPS
99-733.2, from A. concolor in flower of hibiscus (Hibiscus sp.,
Malvaceae), Rarotonga, Cook Islands; UWOPS 05-269.1 (CBS 10330,
NRRL Y-27992), from Epuraea (Haptoncurina) motschulskyi, a nitidulid
beetle (Coleoptera, Nitidulidae) in flower of morning glory (Ipomoea
cairica, Convolvulacae), Cameron Highlands, Malaysia.
Ecology:
Compatible mating types of M. orientalis were recovered 6
years and 11,000 km apart, and yet this species can be considered
rare, as the substrates from which it has been recovered have been
intensively sampled. As with many other nitidulid-associated species
in the Metschnikowia clade, the maximum growth temperature is low
and might play an important role in the distribution of the species.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 5833, isolated by Mrak and
McClung (1940) from grapes; UWOPS 79-111 and many others from
black knot of cherry (Prunus spp.) and fruitfly (Drosophila spp.) in
southwest Ontario, Canada; UWOPS 83-1136.4, from flower of morning
glory (Ipomoea sp., Convolvulaceae), Grand Cayman; flowers
from NW Canada (9); flowers and spoiled fruit in California, USA
(11 strains); Drosophila spp. (4 strains); from exudates of buckeye
(Aesculus), birch (Betula), and willow (Salix) spp. in Japan and the
Pacific Northwest (4 strains).
Ecology:
Metschnikowia pulcherrima and close relatives occur regularly
in nutrient-rich plant materials that serve as feeding and breeding
sites for a variety of insects. This habitat distribution includes tree
sap fluxes and fruit, as listed under “Origin of the strains studied”.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 5834 (UCD-FST 62-311) diploid, isolated
by J.F.T. Spencer from flower of fireweed (Epilobium angustifolium,
Onagraceae), Fort Smith, NWT, Canada. The strains studied by Miller and
Phaff (1998) were obtained from flowers over a wide geographic area:
near Fort Smith, North West Territory, Canada (17); Saskatoon,
Saskatchewan, Canada (5); Davis, California, USA (1); Japan (1); State of
Washington, USA (1). More recent isolates whose identity has been confirmed
by sequencing include SUB 99-213.2, flower of morning glory
(Ipomoea sp., Convolvulaceae), and SUB 99-221.2, flower of larger bindweed
(Calystegia sepium, Convolvulaceae), Smoky Mountains National
Park, Tennessee, USA; UWOPS 03-342o2, from milkweed beetle
Tetraopes tetraophthalmus (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae), collected in a
flower of Calystegia sepium, Long Point, Ontario, Canada; UWOPS 06-29.1
and UWOPS 06-32.1, Azalea sp. flower, Statesboro, Georgia, USA;MH396,
proboscis of bumble bee (Bombus sp., Hymenoptera, Apidae); MH 412
and MH 421, nectar of stinking hellebore (Helleborus foetidus,
Ranunculaceae),Marburg, Germany.
Ecology:
Metschnikowia reukaufii appears to be cosmopolitan in distribution,
unlike many other species associated with flowers or
insects that feed or breed in flowers, which would support an association
with the common bumblebee Bombus terrestris, which has also
become more or less ubiquitous in range

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UWOPS 01-517a1 (CBS 9148, NRRL
Y-27475) and others, isolated from nitidulid beetles (Conotelus sp.,
Coleoptera, Nitidulidae); UWOPS 01-520a1 (CBS 9149, NRRL
Y-27476), from fruit fly (Drosophila sp., Diptera, Drosophilidae);
UWOPS 01-634e2, from mite (Acaria) in flowers of morning glory
(Ipomoea indica), vicinity of Santa Cecilia; UWOPS 01-655c1, from
Conotelus sp. in flower of I. indica near Estación Santa Maria; UWOPS
01-579.1, from halictid bee; UWOPS 03-167a1 and UWOPS 03-167b1,
from Conotelus sp. in flowers of Ipomoea alba, north shore of Lago
Arenal. All are localities in Guanacaste Province of Costa Rica.
Ecology:
Metschnikowia santaceciliae has been isolated in wetter and
cooler parts of Guanacaste Province, in Costa Rica, where it co-occurs
with another large-spored species, M. lochheadii. The latter is also
found in the drier, warmer lowlands of the region. This is the exact
reverse of what one would expect based only on the temperature
maxima of the species (ca. one degree warmer for M. santaceciliae).
A similar situation exists with M. borealis, which, in spite of its northern
range, is the only large-spored species capable of growth at 37 C.
The underlying reason for the strong biogeography of these species
is not known, but is worthy of further investigation. It should also be
of interest to determine whether or not a limited amount of gene
flow is possible through the intermediary of a hybrid zone.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
XY801 (CBS 10359, AS
2.3112), isolated from fruit of jujube fruit (Zizyphus jujuba,
Rhamnaceae), Jiaocheng, Shanxi Province, China.
Ecology:
The presence of yeasts in the M. pulcherrima clade on the
surface of fruit is not unusual, but the selective factors favoring this
distribution are not known.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
All strains were recovered from nitidulid
beetles (Conotelus sp., Coleoptera, Nitidulidae) collected in
flowers of morning glory (Ipomoea sp., Convolvulaceae), Guanacaste
Province, Costa Rica; UWOPS 03-192.2 (CBS 9737, NRRL Y-27627) and
two others, from Ipomoea batatas (Convolvulaceae), Rincón de la
Vieja volcano near El Gavilán; UWOPS 01-138a3, from I. batatas near
Santa Cecilia; UWOPS 03-133.4A (CBS 9738, NRRL Y-27628) and
UWOPS 01-518a6, from I. indica, near Santa Cecilia; three other
strains from I. batatas near Sangregado, on the shore of Lago Arenal.
Ecology:
Metschnikowia similis occurs sympatrically with M. dekortorum
in nitidulid beetles found in morning glories growing in the
wet highlands of northern Costa Rica. As these cryptic species have
the ability to form hybrid asci that often contain ascospores, albeit
nonviable, it will be of interest to determine whether or not the two
species are capable of limited gene flow through a hybrid zone.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
XY103 (CBS 10357, AS
2.3110), Jiaocheng, Shanxi Province; XY102, from jujube fruit
(Zizyphus jujuba, Rhamnaceae), Shandong Province, China (Xue et al.
2006).
Ecology:
The presence of yeasts in the M. pulcherrima clade on the
surface of fruit is not unusual, but the selective factors favoring this
distribution are not known.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UWOPS 86AW4.1 (PYCC 4650, CBS
9134, NRRL Y-17036), isolated from muscoid fly (Diptera, Muscidae)
isolated from common milkweed (Asclepias syriaca, Asclepiadaceae),
Ontario, Canada; UWOPS 86A1.1 and three others, from nectar of
A. syriaca, Québec, Canada.
Ecology:
Metschnikowia vanudenii may be fairly common in the nectar
of milkweeds in the Great Lakes region, although many of the isolates
mentioned by Eisikowitch et al. (1990) were lost before they
could be identified by genome-based approaches.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NCAIM3 Y.01705 (CBS
9950, JCM 12561) and NCAIM Y.01706 (BS 9949, JCM 12562), isolated
from berries of grape (Vitis vinifera, Vitaceae), red cultivar, Hungary.
Ecology:
As stated by Péter et al. (2005b), generalizations on the
ecology of M. viticola would be premature in view of the availability
of only two isolates, both from the same grape sample.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
XY201 (CBS 10358, AS 2.3111) and
three others from Jiaocheng, Shanxi Province; XY204 from Shandong
Province, China, all isolated from jujube (Zizyphus jujuba,
Rhamnaceae).
Ecology:
The presence of yeasts in the M. pulcherrima clade on the
surface of fruit is not unusual, but the selective factors favoring this
distribution are not known.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 4821 and two others, isolated
from sea water and kelp near La Jolla, California, USA, N. van Uden
and R. Castello-Branco. Other strains studied by Miller and Phaff
(1998) included those from gut contents of fish, La Jolla, southern
California (one) and sea water of the Clyde estuary, Scotland (four).
Ecology:
Metschnikowia zobellii shares common habitats with
M. krissii. However, van Uden and Castello-Branco (1961) also found
large cell counts of M. zobellii in the gut content of two fish species
and on the surface of giant kelp.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
DBVPG 4519 (CBS 9966, NRRL
Y-27274), isolated from sugar cane, Cuba; DBVPG 4552, from a
patient with Crohn’s disease who had contracted a yeast infection,
possibly during a visit to the Caribbean; NRRL Y-27220 (CBS 2022),
type strain, Candida fermentati, from the atmosphere, Japan; NRRL
Y-17842 (CBS 5674), type strain, Candida kestonii, from air, sugar
refinery, UK; NRRL YB-186, from soil, Mexico; NRRL YB-198, from
corn-derived starch granules, Illinois, USA; NRRL Y-309, from soil,
USA.
Ecology:
As listed above, M. caribbica has been isolated from a variety
of substrates that include soil, corn-derived starch, sugar cane
and an apparent human infection. These isolates have been from various
locations in the Western Hemisphere (C.P. Kurtzman, unpublished
data, Vaughan-Martini et al. 2005), which suggests that M.
caribbica is widely distributed geographically.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-2075 (CBS 2030), isolated
from insect frass in an American elm (Ulmus americana), USA,
L.J. Wickerham; NRRL Y-324 (CBS 566), type strain, Candida guilliermondii,
from sputum, A. Castellani; NRRL Y-2081 (CBS 1909), type
strain, Candida melibiosi, from a flower of the seboth plant (Gentiana
imbricata), J. Grüss; NRRL Y-2076 (CBS 2031), from an alcohol fermentation
plant, Argentina, L.J. Wickerham; NRRL Y-2086 (CBS
2077), from lung infection, The Netherlands, A. Pondman; NRRL Y-
2082 (CBS 2082), from human source, M. Langeron; NRRL Y-2083
(CBS 2083), type strain, Blastodendrion arztii, from blood, M. Ota;
NRRL Y-2084 (CBS 2084), from sputum, F.L. Niño; NRRL Y-2085 (CBS
2086), air, N. van Uden; NRRL Y-7572 (CBS 6557), type strain,
Candida parapsilosis var. tuxtlensis, pozol, Mexico, T. Herrera; NRRL Y-
17140 (CBS 7232), type strain, Candida amidovorans, soil, Italy, W.
Balloni; NRRL Y-17904 (CBS 2024), from an ulcer on a horse,
Germany; NRRL Y-12853, from bubod, a rice wine starter culture,
Philippines; NRRL Y-17818, from a grape, Israel; NRRL Y-17819, from
a grapefruit, Israel; NRRL Y-17820, from an orange, Israel; NRRL Y-
27821, NRRL Y-27844, clinical isolates, Johns Hopkins Mycology
Laboratory, Baltimore, Maryland, USA, W.G. Merz.
Ecology:
Separation of the closely related species M. caribbica,
M. guilliermondii and C. carpophila is unreliable from phenotype,
resulting in some uncertainty about the ecology of M. guilliermondii
because of the difficulty of species recognition. The strains listed
under “Origin of the strains studied” were identified by molecular
means, and it is apparent that M. guilliermondii is widely distributed
in nature. Isolates have been obtained from insect frass, flowers,
fruits and other food products, and as opportunistic pathogens of
humans and animals. Distribution of M. guilliermondii appears worldwide.
Examples of diverse habitats include isolation from insect frass
in the USA (Wickerham 1966) and from the mud of estuaries in
Brazil (Soares et al. 1997), as well as the sources listed above.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 5656 (NRRLY-7117, CSIR Y-448), isolated
from frass of Buprestidae beetle larvae infesting acacia (Acacia
nilotica var. kraussiana), South Africa; CBS 5985 (NRRL Y-7773), from
tunnels of the beetle Sinoxylon ruficorne in red bushwillow(Combretum
apiculatum, Combretacaea), South Africa (van derWalt 1966b).
Ecology:
The two known strains of M. acaciae were isolated from the
frass of tree infesting beetle larvae in South Africa (van der Walt
1966b).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 185 (NRRL Y-7553), isolated from
“Jopenbier”, Poland, P. Lindner; CBS 2020 (NRRL Y-17649), type strain
of Candida cacaoi, fermenting cocao, Trinidad, J. Lodder; CBS 4548
(NRRL YB-4821), type strain of Pichia minuscula, dung of a giraffe
(Giraffa camelopardalis), Japan, M. Soneda; CBS 4709 (NRRL YB-4568,
IFO 0991), from miso, Japan, K. Kodama; CBS 5730 (NRRL YB-3323),
type strain of Zygosaccharomyces tikumaensis, from miso, Japan, M.
Mogi; CBS 5949 (NRRL Y-7478), type strain of Debaryomyces halotolerans, soy mash, Japan; CBS 7064 (NRRL Y-12695), type strain
of Pichia sorbitophila, from a 70% sorbitol solution, Germany, K.
Appel; CBS 8045 (NRRL Y-17249), from sorbitol stock solution, South
Africa, J.P. van der Walt; NRRL Y-2060, from stored rice, New Orleans,
Louisiana, USA, D. Teunisson; NRRL Y-7084, from wheat flour,
Midwest USA; NRRL Y-11953 (CBS 7911), type strain of Pichia petrophila,
from petroleum, northwestern China, C.-J. Mu; NRRL Y-11954,
from the same source as NRRL Y-11953.
Ecology:
Millerozyma farinosa is widely distributed, with strains isolated
from such diverse substrates as agricultural products, foods,
animal dung, petroleum and human infections, as indicated under
“Origin of the strains studied”.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7219 (NRRL Y-17252), CBS 7037
(NRRL Y-17246), isolated from soil, Transvaal, South Africa, J.P. van
der Walt; NRRL Y-27492 (UOFS Y-1768), from soil, Madagascar.
Ecology:
The few known strains of M. geophila are from soil in South
Africa and Madagasgar.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7332 (NRRL Y-17277), CBS 7405
(NRRL Y-17359), isolated from soil, Transvaal, South Africa, J.P. van
der Walt; NRRL Y-27491 (UOFS Y-1767), from soil, Mt. Sheba, South
Africa.
Ecology:
All known strains of M. kluyveri have been isolated from
soil in South Africa.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7038 (NRRL Y-17253), isolated
from a tree-inhabiting lichen, Transvaal, South Africa.
Ecology:
The single known strain of M. lipomycoides was isolated
from a tree-inhabiting lichen (van der Walt et al. 1987c).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2102 (NRRL Y-11781), CBS 2667
(NRRL Y-17360), isolated from the beetle Dendroctonus monticola in
ponderosa pine (Pinus ponderosa, Pinaceae), California, USA.
Ecology:
Known strains of M. melibiosi were isolated from beetles
that tunneled into ponderosa pine trees (Shifrine and Phaff 1956).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7790 (NRRL Y-17725), isolated
from flux of an oak (Quercus sp., Fagaceae), South Africa; CBS 7806
(NRRL Y-17726), from soil, South Africa, J.P. van der Walt.
Ecology:
Of the two known strains of M. monticola, one was from a
sap flux on an oak tree and the other was from soil, both from South
Africa.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7071 (NRRL Y-11823, UCD-FST 76-
236C), CBS 7070 (NRRL Y-17361, UCD-FST 76-234C), isolated from rotting
agria cactus (Stenocereus gummosis), Baja California Sur, Mexico.
Ecology:
Most strains of M. mucilagina have been isolated from agria
cacti, Baja California Sur, Mexico (Phaff et al. 1980). In addition, Rosa
et al. (1994) reported M. mucilagina to inhabit necrotic tissue of the cactus
Pilosocereus arrabidae, which was growing in southeastern Brazil.

The single known strain of M. neglecta was isolated from a
decaying cladode of prickly pear cactus in South Africa (Spaaij et al.
1998). The species is most closely related to M. mucilagina, which
has been isolated from agria cacti in Mexico (Phaff et al. 1980).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
Two strains were reported in the
description of M. neotropica (Spaaij et al. 1992b), and both were isolated
from grassland soil collected in Costa Rica. Living cultures of
these strains are not available. Later, CBS 7953 (NRRL Y-17859) was
received from the Centraalbureau voor Schimmelcultures, where it
had been identified as M. neotropica. This strain had been isolated
from soil, Sardinia, Italy, by E. Berardi.
Ecology:
The two strains cited in the description of M. neotropica
(Spaaij et al. 1992b) were isolated from grassland soil in Costa Rica.
Strain CBS 7953 was isolated from soil in Sardinia, Italy.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
Two strains were reported in the
description of M. nipponensis (Spaaij et al. 1993a), and both had been
isolated from larval frass of the bark beetle Ips typgraphus f. japonicus,
collected in Hokkaido, Japan. Living cultures of these strains are
not available. Later, UOFS Y-2051 (NRRL Y-27625), identified as
M. nipponensis, was received from the University of the Free State,
Bloemfontein, South Africa. The origin of this strain is uncertain.
Ecology:
The species is known from two bark beetle larvae collected
in Japan (Spaaij et al. 1993a).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
Three strains were reported in the
description of M. sirexii by Spaaij et al. (1992a), which had been isolated
from frass of the wood wasp Sirex javencus. The frass was collected
from a Norway spruce (Picea abies, Pinaceae) in the forested
area Schönbuch near Hildrizhausen, Germany. Living cultures of
these strains are not available. Later, UOFS Y-2054 (NRRL Y-27626),
identified as M. sirexii, was received from the culture collection of
the University of the Free State, Bloemfontain, South Africa. This
strain was isolated from the same habitat as the preceding strains,
but it is not clear if it represents one of them.
Ecology:
All known strains of M. sirexii were isolated from frass of
the wood wasp Sirex juvencus, which inhabitated Norway spruce in
Germany.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7439 (NRRL Y-17387), isolated
from soil around the roots of a mango tree (Mangifera indica,
Anacardiaceae), Miami, Florida, USA; NRRL Y-27490 (UOFS Y-0681),
from soil, Madeira, Spain.
Ecology:
Myxozyma udenii is known from just two strains, and both
are from soil.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7793 (NRRL Y-17727), isolated
from a flower of the sugarbush (Protea repens, Proteaceae) South
Africa; CBS 6048 (NRRL Y-11567), from soil, Germany.
Ecology:
The two strains reported to be M. vanderwaltii, above, are
from different habitats, resulting in uncertainty concerning the ecology
of this species.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6640 (ATCC 58437, IFO 10029,
NRRL Y-7950, VKM Y-1573), isolated from field soil, East Falkland
Island (South Atlantic Ocean); W.I. Golubev; VKM Y-2610 from soil,
Carpathian Mountains, Eastern Europe.
Ecology:
Nadsonia commutata is presently known only from soils of
the Carpatian Mountains in eastern Europe and the East Falkland
Island (Golubev 1973, Golubev et al. 1987).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2596 (ATCC
24236, NRRL Y-12810), received by CBS from G.A. Nadson and A.G.
Konokotina in 1913, from oak sap (Quercus sp.), St Petersburg,
Russia; VKM Y-2618 and VKM Y-2619, from the All-Union Institute of
Agricultural Microbiology, Russia, origin unknown.
Ecology:
The two varieties of N. fulvescens have been found in slime
fluxes of various trees (Golubev et al. 1977, 1989, Phaff et al. 1972).
Steiman et al. (1997) reported the occurrence of the variety elongata
in dry soil from a Dead Sea Oase (Israel).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2593 (ATCC 10646,
NRRL Y-1617) labeled Nadsonia richteri, isolated from hornbeam sap
(Carpinus betulus) in Brno, Czechoslovaki, G. Kostka; CBS 2594 (ATCC
10644, NRRL Y-1568), isolated by A.G. Konokotina in 1913 from birch
(Betula sp.) exudates in the Smolensk area of Russia; CBS 2595,
received by CBS in 1927 from G.A. Nadson labeled N. fulvescens; CBS
6008 (NRRL Y-12792) from exudate of birch (Betula sp.), Russia, I.P.
Bab’eva; additional isolates from exudates of the following trees in
Japan: buckeye (Aesculus sp.) (1), alder (Alnus sp.) (3), birch (Betula
sp.) (18), hornbeam (Carpinus sp.) (2), dogwood (Cornus sp.) (1),
Eurya sp. (1), beech (Fagus sp.) (1), Prunus sp. (5), bamboo
(Sinoarundinaria sp. ) (1) (Phaff et al. 1972).

CBS 7720 (NRRL Y-17846) and two
other strains isolated from exudate of Emory oak (Quercus emoryi,
Fagaceae), Arizona, USA.
Ecology:
The species is known from only three strains recovered
from exudates of Emory oak (Quercus emoryi) in the vicinity of
Tucson, Arizona, USA. The trees were sympatric with cottonwoods
(Populus fremontii, Salicaceae) and various species of prickly pear
cacti (Opuntia spp., Cactaceae), and were visited by Drosophila carbonaria
(Diptera: Drosophilidae) that also carried yeasts (Lachance
et al. 1993). The precise habitat is therefore uncertain.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2170, isolated from dried figs,
South Africa.
Ecology: The ecology of N. delphensis is not known

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-2155 (CBS 4140), isolated by
Wickerham (1960) from frass of an apparent yellow spruce (Picea
rubens) from the Gaspé Peninsula, Canada; NRRL Y-2154 (CBS 4141),
