from an insect tunnel in a white spruce (Picea glauca), Gaspé
Peninsula, Canada; NRRL Y-2448 (CBS 4069), a diploid formed from
mating NRRL Y-2154 and NRRL Y-2155; NRRL Y-7178 (CBS 6477),
from a cadaver in embalming fluid; NRRL Y-27093 (CBS 4263), from
cider, UK; NRRL Y-7914, from a bark beetle tunnel in Douglas fir
(Pseudotsuga menziesii, Pinaceae) USA; NRRL Y-2329 (CBS 2091),
NRRL Y-2330 (CBS 2117), from wood products, Sweden, E. Rennerfelt;
NRRL YB-2110, from insect frass, lodgepole pine (Pinus contorta),
USA; NRRL YB-3558, from a rotting apple attached to the tree,
Angola, Indiana, USA.
Ecology:
Nakazawaea holstii seems to be primarily associated with
bark beetles infesting pine, spruce and fir trees (Wickerham 1960),
but it is also isolated from other substrates, such as cider and apples,
as seen from strain histories above. In addition, L.J. Wickerham (unpublished data) characterized an additional ca. 100 strains of
N. holstii that had been isolated from insect frass, streams and lichens.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 4309 (DBVPG 6298, IFO 1992,
NRRL Y-12630) and DBVPG 6361 (CBS 4310), both strains isolated by
A. Capriotti from soil in Finland; DBVPG 6352 (CBS 3007), DBVPG 6353
(CBS 2913, NRRL Y-17050), and DBVPG 6356 (CBS 3006), from fermenting
cucumbers, USA; DBVPG 6410 (CBS 1579), from buttermilk, The
Netherlands; DBVPG 6751 (CBS 7188), from ensiled maize, The
Netherlands; DBVPG 6758 (CBS 2248), from soil, South Africa; DBVPG
6759 (CBS 4906), from contents of cecum of baboon, Mozambique.
Ecology:
The two first described strains of N. castellii are from the
same Finnish soil sample collected by Capriotti (1966). Later the species
was shown to have a wider distribution, as other strains were
isolated in Africa, The Netherlands and the USA (CBS database).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 421 (DBVPG 6366, IFO 1168, NRRL
Y-1353), isolated from dry fruit of persimmon (Diospyros sp.), probably
from Japan (Naganishi 1917).
Ecology:
The type strain was isolated from dried fruit, probably in
Japan, but other strains were found associated with whole-crop
maize ensiled for 2 weeks together with strains identified as Candida
holmii, C. lambica, C. milleri and Wickerhamomyces anomalus
(Middelhoven et al. 1990).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NCAIM Y.01822 (CBS 10576, NRRL
Y-48267), isolated from leaf of a European hornbean (Carpinus betulus,
Betulaceae); NCAIM Y.01823, from leaf of an oak (Quercus sp.,
Fagaceae); NCAIM Y.01824, from leaf of an ash (Fraxinus sp., Oleaceae),
all three isolates from the Pilis Mountains, Hungary (Péter et al. 2007a).
Ecology:
Ogataea allantospora is known only from leaf surfaces of
ash, hornbeam and oaks growing in Hungary. Péter et al. (2007a)
raised the possibility that O. allantospora utilizes the methanol that
escapes from metabolizing leaves.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
PT44 (BCC 21227, NBRC 101965, CBS
10363), isolated from soil, Chonburi Province, Thailand (Limtong
et al. 2008a).
Ecology:
The single known strain of O. chonburiensis was isolated
from soil in Thailand (Limtong et al. 2008a).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NBRC 1794, isolated from tree bark,
Japan.
Ecology:
The single known isolate of O. corticis was isolated from
tree bark in Japan (Nagatsuka et al. 2008).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NCAIM Y-01539 (CBS 9260, NRRL
Y-27599), NCAIM Y-01613 (CBS 9261), both isolated from rotted railroad
ties, Dorog, Hungary, G. Péter.
Ecology:
The two known strains of O. dorogensis were isolated from
rotted railroad ties, suggesting that rotted wood may be an important
habitat for this species.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UFMG-T264.1 (CBS 9814, NRRL
Y-27756) and five other strains, all isolated from tree sap exudates of
Sclerolobium sp. in a natural forest fragment (ipuca), Lago Verde
Estate, Tocantins, Brazil; UWOPS 00-186.3 and six other strains, all
from tree sap exudates of Hymenaea courbarail from Guanacaste
Conservation Area, Santa Rosa Sector, Costa Rica (Morais et al. 2004).
Ecology:
Ogataea falcaomoraisii is known from tree sap exudates collected
in Brazil and Costa Rica (Morais et al. 2004).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
SHS 2.1 (CGMCC AS 2.3435, CBS
10646), SHS 2.2, SHS 2.3, all three strains isolated from basidiocarps
of Ganoderma sp., collected from a tree trunk, Mangshan Mountain,
Hunan Province, China (Ji and Bai 2008).
Ecology:
Ogataea ganodermae is known only from basidiocarps of
Ganoderma sp. growing on a tree trunk in Hunan Province, China
(Ji and Bai 2008).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 5766 (NRRL YB-2185), was isolated
from frass in an Engelmann spruce (Picea engelmannii, Pinaceae)
growing in the Medicine Bow Mountains, Wyoming, USA; CBS 5779
(NRRL Y-11836), isolated from southern beech (Nothofagus sp.,
Nothofagaceae), Chile, J. Grinbergs, identification from phenotype.
Ecology:
The ecology of O. glucozyma is poorly known because only
two isolates have been reported. The type strain was from an
Engelman spruce growing in Wyoming, USA (Wickerham 1969b),
and a second strain isolated from Nothofagus sp. in Chile was provided
by J. Grinbergs.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL YB-2194 (CBS 5765), isolated from
bird (?) feces collected in the Medicine Bow Mountains, Wyoming,
USA; NRRL YB-2259, from frass from a lodgepole pine (Pinus contorta)
collected near Markleeville, California, USA; NRRL YB-2224, from soil,
Medicine Bow Mountains, Wyoming, USA. All collected by L.J.
Wickerham. The latter two strains were identified from phenotype.
Ecology:
The few known strains of O. henrici are from soil, bird (?)
feces and insect frass from forested areas in the western US.
(Wickerham 1969b).

Based on the single known isolate, the species appears to
be associated with insects.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6515 (NRRL Y-7685), CBS 6513
(NRRL Y-17235), isolated from soil, Japan, K. Makiguchi; CBS 8002
(NRRL Y-11993), type strain, Pichia cellobiosa, soil, Japan (Lee and
Komagata 1980b); NRRL Y-8159, NRRL Y-8160, NRRL Y-8161, NRRL
Y-8162, Pichia aganobii, from soil, Japan (Urakami and Michimi
1977); NRRL YB-4198, from soil, Marion, Illinois, USA, L.J. Wickerham.
Ecology:
All known strains of O. methanolica have been isolated from
soil in either the US or Japan, but it would not be surprising if the
species is worldwide in distribution.

Both available strains of O. methylivora have been isolated
from decayed wood, as noted above.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-411 (CBS 1708), isolated from
a fermenting mushroom (Mycena pura) by A. T. Henrici; NRRL
Y-10948 (CBS 6502), type strain of Pichia lindneri, from forest soil,
Germany (Henninger and Windisch 1975a).
Ecology:
The two known strains of O. minuta, one from a mushroom
and the other from soil, reveal little of the ecology of this species.
However, Hutchison and Hiratsuka (1994) reported O. minuta to be
common on wood of trembling aspen (Populus tremuloides).
Biotechnology: As with certain other methylotrophic yeasts,

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6429 (NRRL Y-7654), isolated
from exudate from a camellia (Camellia japonica, Theaceae), Japan;
NRRL YB-1340, rotted log, Marion, Illinois, USA: NRRL YB-5026, damaged
fruit of an osage orange tree (Maclura pomifera, Moraceae),
Peoria, Illinois, USA. The latter two strains were collected by L.J.
Wickerham.
Ecology:
Two of the known isolates of O. naganishii were from plant
exudates and a third from a rotted log, as noted under “Origin of the
strains studied”.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
S051 (BCC 21228, NBRC 101966, CBS
10362), isolated from a tree exudate, Nakhon-Phanom Province,
Thailand.
Ecology:
The single known strain of O. nakhonphanomensis was isolated
from the exudate of a tree in Thailand.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
ATCC 28781, type strain, isolated from
frass in a loblolly pine (Pinus taeda), collection site unknown; NRRL
YB-1305, from frass in a short leaf pine (Pinus echinata), Piney
Woods, Mississippi, USA, L.J. Wickerham.
Ecology:
The two known strains of O. neopini were isolated from
insect frass in pine trees. One isolate was from Mississippi, USA
(Kurtzman and Robnett 2010), and the other was of unknown origin
(Nagatsuka et al. 2008).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NCAIM Y.01837 (CBS 10796, NRRL
Y-48449), isolated from the leaf of a beech tree (Fagus sylvatica,
Fagaceae), Pilis Mountains, Hungary; NCAIM Y.01832, from rotted
wood, alder tree (Alnus glutinosa, Betulaceae), Pilis Mountains,
Hungary; NCAIM Y.01839, from rotted wood, beech tree (F. sylvatica),
Bükk Mountains, Hungary (Péter et al. 2008).
Ecology:
Of the three known strains of O. nitratoaversa, one was isolated
from the leaf of a tree and the other two from rotted wood.
Consequently, the habitat of this species is tree-associated.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL YB-2203 (CBS 5764), the only
known strain of this species was isolated from Libby Creek near
Laramie, Wyoming, USA, L.J. Wickerham.
Ecology:
Little is known of the ecology of O. nonfermentans. The only
known strain of this species was isolated from a creek in Wyoming,
USA.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NBRC 100261 (CBS 10978), isolated
from insect (Xyleborus sp.) galleries of a Tabu-no-ki tree (Machilus
thunbergii, Lauraceae), NBRC 100260, isolated from insect (Xyleborus
sp.) galleries in Japanese beech (Fagus crenata, Fagaceae), both from
Kagoshima Prefecture, Japan (Nakase et al. 2008a).
Ecology:
The two known strains were associated with insect galeries
in trees growing in Japan.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6075 (NRRL Y-7210), CBS 6088
(NRRL Y-7209), isolated from frass from tunnels of the Bostrichid beetle
(Xylion adustus), which was infesting a moribund fig (Ficus sycomorus,
Moraceae); CBS 6111 (NRRL Y-10992), from tunnel of a beetle (Platypus
externedentatus) in the tree Macaranga capensis (Euphorbiaceae);
CBS 6156 (NRRL Y-10993), from tunnel of P. externedentatus; CBS 6218
(NRRL Y-10994), from tunnel of P. externedentatus in a sweet thorn acacia
tree (Acacia karroo, Fabaceae), all from Natal, South Africa, D.B. Scott.
Ecology:
Known strains of O. phylodendri have been isolated from
tree boring beetles in South Africa.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NCAIM Y.01509 (CBS 9259, NRRL
Y-27598), isolated from rotted oak wood (Quercus sp., Fagaceae), Pilis
Mountains, Hungary (Péter et al. 2003).
Ecology:
Typical of many species of Ogataea, O. pilisensis was isolated
from rotted wood (Péter et al. 2003).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 744 (NRRL Y-11528), isolated from
the bark beetle Dendroctonus brevicomis, USA, C.A. Richards; CBS
2613 (NRRL Y-11529), from larva of Dendroctonus monticola in
Western white pine (Pinus monticola, Pinaceae), California, USA, H.J.
Phaff; CBS 5096 (NRRL Y-11530), from a curculionidae larva on a
monkey-puzzle tree (Araucaria araucana, Araucariaceae); CBS 5097
(NRRL Y-11531), CBS 5098 (NRRL Y-11532), from Hylurgonotus brunneus
on a monkey-puzzle tree, the preceding three strains from
Chile, J. Grinbergs; CBS 5434 (NRRL YB-1278), from frass, short-leaf
pine (Pinus echinata); CBS 5435 (NRRL YB-2023), from frass, loblolly
pine (Pinus taeda); CBS 5436 (NRRL YB-2503), from frass; CBS 5437
(NRRL YB-2258a), from frass; CBS 5439 (NRRL YB-2258c), from frass;
CBS 5440 (NRRL YB-3655), from larva of Dendroctonus monticola in
ponderosa pine (Pinus ponderosa); CBS 5441 (NRRL YB-3706), from
frass, pine (Pinus sp.); CBS 5442 (NRRL Y-6031), from frass, lodge
pole pine (Pinus contorta); CBS 5484 (NRRL YB-2758), CBS 5485
(NRRL YB-2759), CBS 5486 (NRRL YB-2771), from frass, fir tree (Abies
firma), Japan; CBS 5487 (NRRL YB-3339), from a dead birch tree
(Betula sp., Betulaceae), USA; the preceding strains isolated by L.J.
Wickerham; CBS 6275 (NRRL Y-7341), from tunnel of a pine-borer
beetle (Xyleborus torquatus), South Africa, J.P. van der Walt; numerous
other strains from similar habitats.
Ecology:
On the basis of strain isolation histories listed under
“Origin of the strains studied”, O. pini is worldwide in distribution
and commonly occurs in the frass of various pines as well as in frass
from fir, beech and monkey-puzzle trees.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-5445 (CBS 4732), isolated
from soil, Brazil (Falcão de Morais & Dália Maia 1959), type strain of
Hansenula polymorpha; NRRL Y-1798 (CBS 1976), from spoiled Florida
orange juice, D. Teunisson; NRRL Y-2423 (IFO 1071, JCM 3636), from
intestinal tract, swine, Portugal, N. van Uden; NRRL Y-6005, from
alpechin, Spain, J. Santa María; NRRL Y-27293, from a human knee
infection, Worcester, Massachusetts, USA, J.S. Daly; NRRL Y-27863,
catheter related infection, Chicago, Illinois, USA (Bar-Meir et al.
2006); NRRL YB-179, from soil (?), Costa Rica; NRRL YB-2605, from a
mix of sugar cane bagasse and soil, Louisiana, USA. All of the preceding
strains were identified from gene sequence analysis of D1/D2
LSU rRNA and ITS.
Ecology:
Phaff (1985) reported “Hansenula” angusta to be common
in rotting opuntia cacti. The cactus isolates show G1C contents about
1 mol% higher than non-cactus strains, but reduced (ca. 65 70%)
nDNA complementarity with these strains. The cactus isolates differ
phenotypically by slow, weak growth on methanol but grow at elevated
temperatures (45 46 C). Because of the recently recognized
diversity in the Ogataea polymorpha/“Hansenula” angusta clade, the
identity of the species isolated from rotting opuntia cacti is
uncertain.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NCAIM Y.01853 (CBS 11363, NRRL
Y-48632), and 18 other strains, all isolated from exudates of white
poplar trees (Populus alba, Salicaceae) growing in various areas of
Hungary (Péter et al. 2009b).
Ecology:
Ogataea populialbae is known from 19 isolates, all of which
were isolated from exudates of white poplar trees that were growing
in various area of Hungary (Péter et al. 2009b).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL YB-1272 (mating type a), isolated
from frass, tunnel of an unidentified insect in loblolly pine
(Pinus taeda, Pinaceae), NRRL YB-1297 (a), NRRL YB-1298 (?), from
frass, tunnel of an unidentified insect in shortleaf pine (P. echinata),
all three from Piney Woods, Mississippi, USA; NRRL YB-1507 (a),
frass, tunnel of western pine beetle (Dendroctonus brevicomis),
Coulter pine (P. coulteri), Santa Barbara County, California, USA; NRRL
YB-1985 (CBS 8699) (?), insect frass, longleaf pine (P. palustris),
Wilma, Florida, USA; NRRL YB-1986 (a), insect frass, white pine (P.
strobus), Duluth, Minnesota, USA; NRRL YB-3540 (?), NRRL YB-3561
(?), insect frass, red pine (P. resinosa), Angola, Indiana, USA; NRRL
YB-3728 (a), NRRL YB-3730 (a), NRRL YB-3731 (a), NRRL YB-3735 (a),
NRRL YB-3821 (?), NRRL YB-3826 (a), NRRL YB-3828 (?), NRRL
YB-3835 (CBS 8700) (a), NRRL YB-3836 (a), NRRL YB-3837 (a), NRRL
YB-3838 (a), NRRL YB-3839 (a), NRRL YB-3840 (?), NRRL YB-3841 (a),
NRRL YB-3842 (?), all from insect frass, unidentified pine (Pinus sp.),
near Gainesville, Florida, USA; NRRL YB-3833 (a), insect frass,
unspecified location (Kurtzman 2000b).
Ecology:
Ogataea ramenticola is known from 24 strains, all isolated
from insect frass from various pine trees, such as loblolly pine, shortleaf
pine, Coulter pine, longleaf pine and white pine. The species has
been isolated only in the US, with collection sites in Mississippi,
Florida, Indiana, Minnesota and California, but it would be surprising
if the species were not found outside the US.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 8071 (NRRL Y-12834) and three
additional strains, isolated from the brackish water of a salt spring
near Château-Salins, France (Hinzelin et al. 1991).
Ecology:
Ogataea salicorniae is known from four strains that were
isolated from brackish water. This habitat contrasts with that of
many species of Ogataea, which have been isolated from leaves, rotted
wood and insect frass in trees.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
FS101 (TISTR 5818, JCM 12264), isolated
from flower of grape jasmine (Ervatamia coronaria,
Apocynaceae), Kanchanaburi Province; FS96, flower of water willow
(Justicia fragilis, Acanthaceae), Kanchanaburi Province; MS2, flux of a
mango tree (Manaifera indica, Anacardiaceae), Kalasin Province, all
from Thailand (Limtong et al. 2004).
Ecology:
The three known strains of O. siamensis were isolated from
flowers and a tree flux in Thailand, suggesting a preference for highsugar
tropical habitats.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
PT31 (BCC 16875, JCM 12984, CBS
10098), NP69, both were isolated from soil, Pathalung Province;
N002, isolated from soil, Saraburi Province, all from Thailand
(Limtong et al. 2005).
Ecology:
The three known isolates of O. thermomethanolica were isolated
from soil in Thailand. This habitat is in contrast to many species
of Ogataea, which have been associated with insects and rotted
wood.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NCAIM Y.01537 (CBS 9256, NRRL
Y-27595), isolated from exudate of an oak (Quercus sp., Fagaceae);
NCAIM Y.01578 (CBS 9257), from exudate of a European hornbean
(Carpinus betulus, Betulaceae); NCAIM Y.01580 (CBS 9258), from exudate
of a sessile oak (Q. petrea), all from Pilis Mountains, Hungary
(Péter et al. 2003).
Ecology:
The three known strains of O. trehaloabstinens were isolated
from exudates from oak and hornbeam trees in Hungary. This suggests
that, as for many of the other Ogataea species, the primary habitat
is tree exudates and rottting wood.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 5361 (NRRL Y-6781), CBS 5488
(NRRL Y-11550), isolated from slime flux of cottonwood (Populus trichocarpa,
Salicaceae), California, USA, H.J. Phaff.
Ecology:
The two known strains of O. trehalophila were isolated from
slime fluxes on cottonwood trees growing in California, USA (Phaff
et al. 1964b).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 4307 (NRRL YB-4943), Capriotti’s
strain 241-A, which he designated as the type of Hansenula wickerhamii;
CBS 4308 (NRRL YB-4944, Capriotti 241-D). Both strains were
isolated from soil from a swamp in which spruce and broad-leafed
trees were growing, Hÿÿttiala Province of Tavastia Australis, Finland,
A. Capriotti.
Ecology:
The two known strains of O. wickerhamii were isolated
from soil in a swamp in Finland (Capriotti 1961c).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NCAIM Y.01540 (CBS 9262, NRRL
Y-27601), isolated from a rotted railroad tie, Dorog, Hungary (Péter
et al. 2003).
Ecology:
The single known strain of O. zsoltii was isolated from a rotted
railroad tie in Hungary.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-2460 (IRIC 145, CBS 4044),
isolated from extract of chestnut (Castanea vesca); NRRL Y-2461 (IRIC 146), NRRL Y-2462 (IRIC 152), NRRL Y-6704 (IRIC 164, CBS 4045),
from extracts of mimosa (Acacia mollissima). All four strains were
from Ludwigshafen, Germany. NRRL Y-2463 (IRIC 153), from tanned
shoe leather, Strasbourg, France. NRRL Y-6704 was designated as the
type strain of Pachysolen pelliculatus by Boidin and Adzet (1957).
Ecology:
The only known isolates of P. tannophilus are from the study
of Boidin and Adzet (1957). All isolates were from leather tanning
fluids or from leather, and had been isolated in Strasbourg, France
and Ludwigshafen, Germany. The cities are relatively close to one
another, so perhaps the natural habitat of P. tannophilus is to be
found in this geographical area.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL YB-4247 (NRRL Y-11548, CBS
2504), isolated from tanning fluid, Europe (Socias et al. 1954b); NRRL
Y-11549 (CBS 5457, UCD-FST 62-403), from a diseased fir tree (Abies
nobilis), California, USA, H.J. Phaff; NRRL YB-5293, from an amorphous
fungus growth, Mt Constitution, Washington State, USA,
L.J. Wickerham; NRRL YB-4780, NRRL YB-4896, from a mixture of
horse dung and sawdust, Bonaventure Island, Quebec, Canada,
L.J. Wickerham; NRRL YB-2508, from insect frass, white spruce (Picea glauca), Grand Riviere, Ontario, Canada, L.J. Wickerham; NRRL YB-
674, from frass of a bark beetle, USA, L.J. Wickerham.
Ecology:
Nearly all strains of P. toletana have been isolated from
insect frass in fir and spruce trees or from wood products (Socias
et al. 1954b, C.P. Kurtzman, unpublished data), which suggests the
primary habitat of the species is in association with wood-boring
insects and their larvae. Strains have been isolated in Europe and
North America.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-12939 (CBS 2286), isolated by
Phaff et al. (1956) from a fruit fly (Drosophila miranda), California,
USA; NRRL Y-5987, from J. Boidin, possible subculture of the type
strain; NRRL Y-5416, from flux from a conifer, Cierra Leonidas,
Mexico; NRRL 5673 (strain 55C, J. Santa María), Spain; NRRL YB-1491,
NRRL YB-1492, from insect frass, white pine (Pinus strobus), near
Blind River, Sault St. Marie, Ontario, Canada, L.J. Wickerham; NRRL
YB-2151, from insect frass, spruce tree (Picea sp.), Laramie, Wyoming,
USA, L.J. Wickerham; NRRL YB-2308, NRRL YB-2309, NRRL YB-2347,
NRRL YB-2348, NRRL YB-2349, from insect frass, ponderosa pine
(Pinus ponderosa), Twisp, Washington, USA, L.J. Wickerham; NRRL
YB-3884 (CBS 7206) and NRRL YB-3887 (CBS 7207), isolated by
L.J. Wickerham from, respectively, the Tuolumne River, Yosemite
National Park, California, and a river near Lake Tahoe, California,
USA.
Ecology:
Although the original description of P. xylosa is based on a
strain isolated from a fruit fly (Phaff et al. 1956), the species is primarily
associated with wood-boring insects, as indicated by strains
listed under “Origin of the species studied”.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
Isolated from necrotic tissue of the
columnar cactus Cephalocereus royenii from the Virgin Islands: CBS
7111 (UCD-FST 82-651A, NRRL Y-12881), CBS 7113 (UCD-FST 82-
628B, NRRL Y-12883), Prickly Pear Island, Virgin Gorda; CBS 7112
(UCD-FST 82-604B, NRRL Y-12882), NRRL Y-17719 (SU 82-550A), Beef
Island, Tortola (Starmer et al. 1984, W.T. Starmer, unpublished data).
Ecology:
At present, P. antillensis is known only from the West
Indies, P. opuntiae from Australia and P. thermotolerans from Mexico.
Starmer et al. (1984) found P. antillensis to occur almost exclusively
in rots of the columnar cactus Cephalocereus royenii, with one exception;
a strain isolated from Turk’s cap cactus (Melocactus intortus)
growing on Virgin Gorda. The 20 strains compared by Starmer et al.
(1984) were relatively evenly distributed among the West Indian
islands of Montserrat, Tortola and Virgin Gorda.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
77-42, NRRL Y-11708), both isolated
from rotted prickly pear cactus (Opuntia inermis), Yarrawonga,
Australia (Starmer et al. 1979). The following additional strains were
received from W.T. Starmer (unpublished data) that had been isolated
from rots of prickly pear cacti in areas around Yarrawonga and
Brisbane, Australia: NRRL Y-17721 (SU 84-860), NRRL Y-17737 (SU
84-821), NRRL Y-17746 (SU 84-677.2), NRRL Y-17747 (SU 84-833.1)
and NRRL Y-17748 (SU 84-853.3).
Ecology:
At present, P. opuntiae is known only from Opuntia cacti
growing in the Yarrawonga, Martindale and Brisbane areas of
Australia (Starmer et al. 1979, W.T. Starmer, unpublished data).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7012 (UCD-FST 76-211, NRRL
Y-11709), isolated from senita cactus (Lophocereus schottii), Rancho
Cuñaño, Baja California Sur, Mexico; CBS 7013 (UCD-FST 76-385B,
NRRL Y-11710), from soil under cardon cactus (Pachycereus pringlei),
Mulegé, Baja California Sur, Mexico; NRRL Y-17744 (SU 83-505.1) and
NRRL Y-17745 (SU 83-510.1), both from Drosophila nigrospiracula,
Tucson, Arizona, USA (W.T. Starmer, unpublished data).
Ecology:
Strains of P. thermotolerans have been isolated only from
several sites in Baja California Sur, Mexico, and on the opposite shore
of the Gulf of California in Guaymas, Sonora, Mexico (Starmer et al.
1979). The isolates have been from rots in cardon and senita cacti,
both members of the subtribe Pachycereinae. Lachance et al. (1988b)
and Starmer et al. (1990) reviewed the genetics and biogeography of
the cactus yeasts, including species of Phaffomyces.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7256 (NRRL Y-17350), isolated
from rotting cladodes of prickly pear cactus (Opuntia stricta) from
Discovery Bay, Jamaica; CBS 7257 (NRRL Y-17351), from Cayman Brac,
Caribbean Sea. Additional strains were compared by Phaff et al.
(1987a).
Ecology:
The work of Phaff et al. (1987a) showed the habitat of
P. barkeri to be restricted to rotting cladodes of prickly pear cactus
(Opuntia stricta), and that P. barkeri had been isolated only from
O. stricta growing on several islands of the Caribbean Sea and from a
small area in New South Wales, Australia. However, Rosa et al. (1994)
reported P. barkeri to be common on the cactus Pilosocereus arrabidae
found in the sandy coastal plains of southeastern Brazil.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6926 (UCD-FST 76-243A, NRRL
Y-10963), isolated from organ pipe cactus (Stenocereus thurberi),
Baja California, Mexico; CBS 6927 (UCD-FST 76-900B, NRRL
Y-10964), from Opuntia megacantha, island of Hawaii, USA; CBS
6928 (UCD-FST 77-320A, NRRL Y-10965), from Mitla, Oaxaca,
Mexico; NRRL Y-17722 (SU 85-201), from Opuntia phaecantha,
Tucson, Arizona, USA. Numerous additional strains were compared
by Starmer et al. (1978a).
Ecology:
Pichia cactophila has been isolated from a wide variety of
cactus species (Starmer et al. 1978a, 1990), which contrasts with the
more specific niche requirements of many other cactophilic Pichia
species.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
The only known strain (YS16, CBS
10445, JCM 13873, NRRL Y-27985) of this species was isolated from a
rotten papaya fruit (Carica papaya) collected in Hyderabad, Andhra
Pradesh, India, in 2005.
Ecology:
The single known strain was isolated from a rotted papaya
fruit in India.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7273 (UCD-FST 82-555B, NRRL
Y-17225), isolated from rot of columnar cactus (Cephalocereus royenii),
island of Montserrat, West Indies, and the listed mating types.
Phaff et al. (1987b) compared additional strains.
Ecology:
This species, which does not have killer activity against
Candida glabrata, was isolated from columnar cacti on the Caribbean
island of Montserrat (Phaff et al. 1987b).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7119 (UCD-FST 83-467.3, NRRL
Y-12918), isolated from prickly pear cactus (Opuntia phaeacantha),
Santa Catalina Mountains, Arizona, USA; CBS 7120 (UCD-FST 81-403B,
NRRL Y-12919), from O. phaeacantha, Tucson Mountains, Arizona, USA;
CBS 7121 (UCD-FST 76-355A, NRRL Y-12920), type strain of Candida
deserticola, from columnar cactus (Stenocereus gummosus), Mulegé,
Baja California, Mexico; CBS 7122 (UCD-FST 82-451A, NRRL Y-12921),
from columnar cactus (Stenocereus hystrix), Gonnaïves, Haiti; IFO 0162
(CBS 637), type strain of Mycoderma tannica, tanning liquor, leather
factory, Japan, T. Asai
Ecology:
Pichia deserticola occurs in species of prickly pear cacti
whereas C. deserticola is almost exclusive to columnar cacti (Phaff
et al. 1985).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7272 (UCD-FST 83-466.1, NRRL
Y-17224), isolated from rot of prickly pear cactus (Opuntia phaeacantha),
southern Arizona, USA; CBS 7271 (UCD-FST 76-202B, NRRL
Y-17226), type strain of Candida eremophila, from rotting organ pipe
cactus (Stenocereus thurberi), Baja California, Mexico.
Ecology:
Phaff et al. (1987b) reported P. eremophila to be found
almost exclusively on Opuntia cactus rots in southern Arizona and Texas. Strains of P. eremophila show killer activity against Candida
glabrata.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-10920 (CBS 6836, UCD-FST
68-979B1), isolated from insect boring in sitka spruce (Picea sitchensis),
State of Washington, USA; NRRL Y-11604 (UCD-FST 68-914B),
from slime flux of black cottonwood (Populus trichocarpa), British
Columbia, Canada; NRRL Y-11605 (UCD-FST 68-930), from slime flux
of willow (Salix sp.), British Columbia, Canada.
Ecology:
Pichia exigua is known only from the western US and adjacent
areas of Canada. US isolates are from insect borings in sitka
spruce, but Canadian isolates are from fluxes of cottonwood and willow
(Phaff et al. 1976).

Pichia fermentans is widely distributed in nature and often
found in foods and fruit juice, as well as being associated with
humans and animals.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6930 (NRRL Y-10967, UCD-FST 76-
356), isolated from soft rot of senita cactus (Lophocereus schottii),
Baja California Sur, Mexico; CBS 6933 (NRRL Y-10970), from saguaro
cactus (Carnegiea gigantea), Arizona, USA.
Ecology:
Phaff et al. (1978b) reported P. heedii to be isolated only
from two species of cacti belonging to the subtribe Pachycereinae,
senita (Lophocereus schotti) and saguaro (Carnegiea gigantea), and
their associated Drosophila species, D. pachea and D. nigrospiracula,
respectively. It was later found (Holzschu and Phaff 1982, Starmer
et al. 1980b) that the strains from senita utilize citrate whereas those
isolated from saguaro do not. The two metabolic types show greater
that 95% nDNA complementarity and matings between the two types
produces four-spored asci that segregate 2:2 with respect to citrate
utilization, including control by a single genetic locus.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 188 (NRRL Y-11519), type strain,
isolated from olives, California, USA, C.L. Bedford; CBS 1358 (NRRL
Y-11520), type strain of P. belgica var. microspora, from P. Negroni;
CBS 1362 (NRRL Y-11521), from a “tropical product”; CBS 1525 (NRRL
Y-11523), from fermenting cacao, Trinidad; CBS 7274 (SU 84-670.2,
NRRL Y-17228), from prickly pear cactus (Opuntia stricta), W.T.
Starmer, New South Wales, Australia; CBS 7275 (NRRL Y-17227, UCDFST
83-1123), from prickly pear cactus, H.J. Phaff, Grand Cayman
Island; CBS 7907 (SU 84-670.2B, NRRL Y-17734); CBS 7908 (SU 84-
670.2C, NRRL Y-17752).
Ecology:
Pichia kluyveri is widely distributed in nature and is commonly
isolated from rotted fruit and the fleshy parts of plants (Phaff
et al. 1987b).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-5396 (CBS 5147), isolated from fruit
juice or berries, V.I. Kudryavtsev, Russia; NRRL Y-134, from sake, Japan;
NRRL Y-301, unknown source; NRRL Y-420, from human heart blood;
NRRL Y-870, from champagne; CBS 573 (NRRL Y-7179), from sputum, Sri
Lanka, type strain of Candida krusei; CBS 2050 (NRRL Y-309), type strain of
Mycoderma chevalieri, from ginger beer, A. Guilliermond; CBS 2053 (NRRL
Y-96), type strain of Mycoderma monosa, from human feces, H.W.
Anderson; CBS 2911 (NRRL Y-7550), from tea beer, Netherlands; CBS 5148
(NRRL Y-6668), type strain of Endoblastomyces thermophilus, from beer
wort, V.I. Kudryavtsev; CBS 5590 (NRRL Y-7724), from baker’s yeast,
Finland, H. Suomalainen; CBS 5687 (NRRL Y-10940), type strain of
Candida requinyii, frombaker’s yeast, Hungary; NRRL Y-10930, from swine
waste, Illinois, USA; NRRL YB-593, from chicken egg, USA.
Ecology:
Pichia kudriavzevii and its anamorph Candida krusei are
widely distributed in nature often occurring in soil, on fruits and in
various natural fermentations. As noted below, P. kudriavzevii is also
a common clinical isolate.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 209 (IFO 10726, NRRL Y-27978),
type strain of P. manshurica, isolated from Manshurian sorghum
spirits; CBS 7324 (NRRL Y-17349), type strain of P. galeiformis, from
feces, Japan; CBS 190 (NRRL Y-1576), neotype strain of P. punctispora;
CBS 763 (NRRL Y-17348), from A. Guilliermond via P. Negroni; CBS
1367 (NRRL Y-1040), type strain for both Zygosaccharomyces bisporus
and Zygopichia chevalieri var. andersonii; CBS 4043 (NRRL Y-2473),
type strain of P. indica, from palm wine, Pakistan.
Ecology:
Pichia manshurica appears to be common in natural fermentations,
including rotting plant material. Because P. manshurica is
difficult to resolve from P. membranifaciens, past ecological studies
that reported the occurrence of P. membanifaciens may have also
included P. manshurica.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 107 (NRRL Y-2026), type strain of
P. membranifaciens; CBS 184 (NRRL Y-1627), type strain of Willia belgica;
CBS 191 (NRRL Y-1575), authentic strain of P. membranifaciens var.
acidifaciens, from wine, Italy: CBS 207 (NRRL Y-1574), type strain of
P. alcoholophila var. naganishii; CBS 244 (NRRL Y-1771), type strain of
Endomyces chodati, from fruit of banana (Musa sapientum); CBS 598
(NRRL Y-1513), type strain of Mycoderma vanlaeriana, from lambic
beer, Belgium; CBS 636 (NRRL Y-936), type strain of Mycoderma lafarii,
from lager beer tank; CBS 1329 (NRRL Y-7554), type strain of P. alcoholophila,
from soil, Denmark; CBS 1363 (NRRL Y-1620), authentic strain
of P. neerlandica, beer, The Netherlands; CBS 2763 (NRRL YB-4326),
type strain of P. membranifaciens var. sicereum, from cider.
Ecology:
Pichia membranifaciens is widely distributed in nature and
is often found in the rots of spoiled fruit and other plant materials as
well as a contaminant of fermented beverages, as noted under
“Origin of the strains studied”, above.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 5141 (NRRL Y-7686), isolated
from apple must, Chile; CBS 6374 (NRRL Y-17248), the type strain of
Candida citrea, from a lemon (Citrus sp.) fruit, Japan; CBS 6737 (NRRL
Y-17237), from the fruit of a banana (Musa sapientum), Japan; CBS
6738 (NRRL Y-17238), from a lemon fruit, Japan.
Ecology:
Pichia nakasei is known only from fruits and fruit products
(Barnett et al. 1983).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6564 (NRRL Y-7687), isolated from
the vagina of a pregnant woman, UK, B.G.S. Leask; NRRL Y-12804,
clinical isolate, Virginia, USA; NRRL Y-27195, wine?; NRRL YB-3899
(CBS 1953), type strain of Candida mycoderma var. annulata, from
sputum, Norway, E. Dietrichson; NRRL YB-3904 (CBS 1911), type
strain of Candia trigonopsoides, from sputum, Norway, E. Dietrichson.
Ecology:
Guého and Phaff (1983) noted that in addition to its clinical
association, P. norvegensis is commonly isolated from rots of Opuntia
cactus.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-7552 (CBS 5459), diploid
strain, isolated from spoiled figs?, H.J. Phaff, USA, originally identified
as a citrate-negative strain of Pichia kudriavzevii (Kreger-van Rij
1970c); NRRL Y-7767 (CBS 1910), type strain of Candida sorbosa, from
feces of a fly (Drosophila crucigera), L. Hedrick, Hawaii, USA; NRRL
Y-7768 (CBS 2107), from “tea fungus”, K.B. Boedijn, Indonesia; NRRL
Y-6545, from grape (Vitis sp.), source unknown; NRRL YB-282, origin
unknown, NRRL YB-3389, from coffee bean pulp.
Ecology:
Pichia occidentalis is most often associated with fruit and
natural fermentations of food products, as seen from strain isolation
histories, above. Hierro et al. (2006a) reported P. occidentalis to be
relatively common in wine fermentations.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6929 (UCD-FST 77-427, NRRL
Y-10966), isolated from hecho cactus (Pachycereus pecten-aboriginum),
Navojoa, Sonora, Mexico. Additional strains were characterized
by Holzschu et al. (1983).
Ecology:
Although P. cactophila is common to many species of cacti,
P. pseudocactophila is generally recovered only from cardon cactus
and its near relatives. Shen and Lachance (1993) identified a strain of
P. cactophila by restriction fragment mapping that was initially classified
as P. pseudocactophila because it produced four-spored asci and
was isolated from senita cactus. This report suggests that accurate
identification of cactus yeasts will require molecular methods.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-7663 (CBS 6670, UCD-FST
71-102), NRRL Y-11602 (UCD-FST 71-145), NRRL Y-11603 (UCD-FST
72-135), NRRL Y-11759   NRRL Y-11762, all isolated from slime flux
of sandalwood (Myoporum sandwicense), Hawai’i, USA, collected by
H.J. Phaff and W.T. Starmer.
Ecology:
Known isolates of P. scutulata are from slime fluxes of sandalwood
trees in Hawai’i.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NCAIM Y. 01078 (NRRL Y-27347, CBS
8806), type strain of P. sporocuriosa, isolated from a rotted fruit of
the rambutan tree (Nephelium lappaceum, Sapindaceae), Malaysia;
HB1.3.13 (NRRL Y-27509, CBS 9198), type strain of Issatchenkia
hanoiensis, TH1.2.47 (NRRL Y-27486, CBS 9199), TH1.2.61 (NRRL Y-
27485, CBS 9200), the latter two strains also described as I. hanoiensis,
all three from frass of the litchi fruit (Litchi chinensis) borer
(Conopomorpha cramerella), collected in Hanoi, Vietnam.
Ecology:
All four known strains of P. sporocuriosa have been isolated
from tropical fruit as noted in the listing of strain histories above.
The three isolates described as I. hanoiensis were from the frass of
litchi fruit borers. Thanh et al. (2003) noted that a sampling of 23
litchi fruits yielded I. hanoiensis from just three and suggested that it
is unlikely that this yeast is a symbiont of the fruit borer.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2617 (NRRL YB-4310), isolated from
soil, South Africa, J.P. van derWalt; CBS 4713 (NRRL Y-7548), fromWest
Indian cherry juice, K. Kodama; CBS 4714 (NRRL Y-7726), from garden
soil, Italy, K. Kodama; CBS 4715 (NRRL Y-7727), from dregs, pressed
grapes, Italy, K. Kodama; CBS 5259 (NRRL Y-7549), from seawater,
N. van Uden: CBS 5376 (NRRL Y-7728), from spoiled figs, California,
USA, H.J. Phaff; CBS 5517 (NRRL Y-7729), from wine, Italy, A. Martini;
NRRL Y-8218, soil, near New Orleans, Louisiana, USA, C.P. Kurtzman.
Ecology:
A primary habitat has not been found for P. terricola, but
the species has been isolated in Africa, Europe and North America
from soil, fruit and water.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2285 (NRRL YB-4275), type strain
of Pichia carsonii, isolated from slime flux of a black oak (Quercus kelloggii),
California, USA, H.J. Phaff; NRRL YB-4276 (UCD-FST K-157),
same source as NRRL YB-4275; CBS 810 (NRRL Y-1459), type stain of
Debaryomyces vini, from slimy wine, Germany, J. Zimmermann; CBS
5254 (NRRL Y-7125), type strain of Pichia vini var. melibiosi, from
alpechín, Spain, J. Santa María. The following strains were identified
as P. carsonii from phenotype: CBS 4050 (NRRL Y-7543), from wine,
South Africa, J.P. van der Walt; CBS 4328 (NRRL Y-7544), from
orchard soil, Japan, K. Kodama; CBS 5463 (NRRL Y-7545), from the
dipterian insect Aulacigaster sp., H.J. Phaff; NRRL Y-10937, NRRL
Y-10938, NRRL Y-10947, all from pulque, Mexico, M. Ulloa Sosa.
Ecology:
Isolates listed under “Origin of the strains studied” are from
a variety of habitats, including spoiled wine, agricultural processing
wastes and an insect.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6053 (NRRL Y-7501), isolated from
frass of insects infesting a Kentucky coffee tree (Gymnocladus canadensis,
Leguminosae), Spain, J. Santa María.
Ecology:
Only one strain is known for P. castillae, and that is from
insect frass collected from Gymnocladus canadensis growing in Spain
(Santa María and García Aser 1970).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2028 (NRRL Y-7860, UCD-FST 52-
11), isolated from the bark beetle Dendroctonus jeffreyi in jeffrey pine
(Pinus jeffreyi), California, USA, H.J. Phaff; CBS 4329 (NRRL Y-11518),
orchard soil, Japan, K. Kodama; NRRL YB-3647 (UCD-FST 52-151),
NRRL YB-3648 (UCD-FST 52-12), from insect frass of Ips emarginatus
and D. jeffreyi, respectively, in jeffrey pine, California, USA (Shifrine
and Phaff 1956).
Ecology:
With the exception of one Japanese soil isolate, strains of
P. haplophilus are known only from insect frass in jeffrey pines growing
in northern California, USA (Shifrine and Phaff 1956).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 5521 (NRRL Y-7122, LY 325), CBS
5520 (NRRL Y-11524, LY 324), both isolated from larvae of wood-boring
insects, France, J. Boidin.
Ecology:
The two known strains of P. medius were isolated from larvae
of tree-boring insects, which suggests that this is the natural
habitat of this species (Boidin et al. 1964).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6344 (NRRL Y-7585, JCM 1707),
type strain of Pichia melissophila, isolated from the gut of a honey
bee (Apis mellifera var. adansonii), South Africa, J.P. van der Walt; CBS
6694 (NRRL Y-7772), from soil, South Africa, J.P. van der Walt.
Ecology:
The type strain of P. melissophilus was isolated from the gut
of a honey bee, but two other isolates were from soil and another
was from a lichen on a tree (CBS website), all from South Africa. In
view of strain sources, the habitat of this species is uncertain.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-17093, isolated from giant ragweed
(Ambrosia trifida), Arkansas, USA.
Ecology:
Reddy and Kramer (1975) reported P. gravidus
to be pathogenic on species of ragweed (Ambrosia spp.) and beggar
ticks (Bidens spp.) with diseased plants found in New York State,
USA, Wisconsin, USA and Finland. Infection leads to large hypertrophic
galls on stems, and occasionally on petioles and midribs.
Protomyces spp. have been examined as plant biocontrol agents.
Cartwright and Templeton (1988) tested P. gravidus as a mycoherbicide
for control of giant ragweed (Ambrosia trifida), a major weed
plant in some areas. However, biocontrol of giant ragweed was only
moderately successful in the reported field tests.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-6347, from L.R.G. Valadon,
England; NRRL YB-4354, from K. Tubaki, parasitic on hawk’s beard
(Crepis japonica), Japan.
Ecology:
Protomyces inouyei is known as a pathogen of
Crespis japonica in Japan (Tubaki 1957).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-6349, NRRL Y-6802, NRRL
Y-6803, from L.R.G. Valadon, England, parasitic on wild celery (Apium
nodiflorum).
Ecology:
Protomyces inundatus is reported to form
small blister-like warts on the leaves of various species of wild celery
(Apium spp.), wild carrot (Daucus spp.) and water parsnip (Sium spp.)
(Reddy and Kramer 1975). P. inundatus has been isolated in England,
France, Germany and Switzerland.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL YB-4353, received from
K. Tubaki, Japan.
Ecology:
Protomyces lactucaedebilis is reported to cause
swellings and galls on stems, buds and leaves of a wild lettuce (Lactuca
debilis) growing in Japan and Taiwan (Reddy and Kramer 1975).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-12879, isolated from a leaf gall
of hedge parsley (Torilis japonica), Arkansas, USA (Valverde and
Templeton 1984).
Ecology:
Protomyces macrosporus is reported to form
galls on the stems, petioles, leaves and fruits of many genera
assigned to the Umbelliferae (Reddy and Kramer 1975). These
authors reported collections of P. macrosporus from throughout Asia,
Europe and North Africa. In addition, NRRL Y-12879, which was
received as P. macrosporus, was isolated from hedge parsley in
Arkansas, USA. Economic losses are seldom great from plant infections
caused by Protomyces, but P. macrosporus infection of coriander
(Coriandrum sativum) was reported to have damaged up to 11% of
the crop during one growing season in India (Tripathi et al. 2003).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL YB-4355, from K. Tubaki, Japan;
NRRL Y-6348, from L.R.G. Valadon, England.
Ecology:
Protomyces pachydermus is reported to cause
swellings on petioles and leaf veins of numerous plant genera
including pig-salad plant (Aposeris sp.), hawk’s beard (Crepis sp.) and
dandelion (Taraxacum sp.) (Reddy and Kramer 1975). P. pachydermus
has been found in Asia, Europe, North Africa and North America.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
H-6T (CBS 10644) was isolated from the
bark of an oak tree (Quercus fabri), Qinling Mountains, Shaanzi
Province, China; ZX-15 and ZX-20 were both isolated from the bark of
the tree Castanopsis orthacantha, Yunnan Province, China (Wang and
Bai 2008).
Ecology:
The three known strains of the species were found associated
with the bark of two tree species of the family Fagaceae in different
regions of China (Wang and Bai 2008).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
DBVPG 6032 (CBS 378),
origin unknown; DBVPG 6171 (CBS 380), isolated from beer, received
by CBS from the Central Laboratory of the South Manchuria Railway
Company; DBVPG 6259 (CBS 1604), from perry; DBVPG 6260 (CBS
1505), type strain of S. intermedius var. valdensis, from grape must;
DBVPG 6347 (NCYC 374), unknown.
Ecology:
While strains of this species are normally found in habitats
associated with the production of alcoholic beverages (Gonzáles et al.
2006, Naumov et al. 2002b), an ecological study by Naumov et al. (2003a)
reported the presence of S. bayanus in an unspecified natural habitat in
Far East Asia togetherwith strains of S. cerevisiae and S. paradoxus.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
DBVPG 6115 (CBS 424)
type strain of S. globosus, isolated from pear juice; DBVPG 6131 (CBS
431), from fermenting juice of Marx pears, type strain of S. tubiformis;
DBVPG 6179 (CBS 395), from juice of black currant (Ribes
nigrum), The Netherlands.

DBVPG 6859 (UFRJ 50791, UCD-FST
01-166), isolated from a fruit fly (Drosophila sp.), Catalao point, Rio
de Janeiro, Brazil; DBVPG 6860T (CBS 7995, IGC 5301, IMUFRJ 50816,
CBS 8841, NCYC 2890), from a fruit fly (Drosophila sp.), Tijuca forest,
Rio de Janeiro, Brazil (Naumov et al. 2000).
Ecology:
Strains of this species have been found to be associated
with Drosophila species in Brazil (Naumov et al. 2000), or in pulqué
(a fermented drink derived from agave juice) in Mexico (from CBS
database).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
DBVPG 1357 and DBVPG 1360, isolated
from vineyard soil, Italy; DBVPG 1722, from grape must treated
with sulfur dioxide, Spain; DBVPG 1776, DBVPG 1789 and DBVPG
1793, from soil, Finland; DBVPG 1948 and DBVPG 1950, from cavern
soil, Italy; DBVPG 6029 (CBS 1907), type strain of Candida robusta;
DBVPG 6037 (CBS 2980), from Drosophila; DBVPG 6039 (CBS 1395),
origin unknown, type strain of S. ellipsoideus; DBVPG 6042 (CBS 403),
type strain of S. lindneri, from ginger wine, West Africa; DBVPG 6043
(CBS 382), type strain of S. logos, from a brewery, Brazil; DBVPG 6046
(CBS 422), type strain of S. odessa, from beer, Poland; DBVPG 6048
(CBS 423), type strain of S. steineri, from wine, Switzerland; DBVPG
6173 (ATCC 18824, CBS 1171, NCYC 505, NRRL Y-12632), neotype
strain of S. cerevisiae, top yeast used in the Oranjeboom Brewery at
Rotterdam, The Netherlands; DBVPG 6220 (CBS 6503), brewery killer,
UK; DBVPG 6248 (CBS 2354, NCYC 74) used for assay of pyridoxine
and pantothenic acid; DBVPG 6249 (CBS 2444), from distillery, USA;
DBVPG 6250 (CBS 4734), from juice of sugar cane; DBVPG 6251 (CBS
1250), type strain of S. cheresiensis, sherry, Spain.
Ecology:
Saccharomyces cerevisiae, “The Yeast”, the model of cellular
organization, and the first sequenced eukaryotic genome, is rarely
isolated in natural environments. On the occasions in which it has
been isolated (Capriotti 1954, Parle and di Menna 1966, Redzepovic
et al. 2002, Sampaio and Gonçalves 2008, Sniegowski et al. 2002),
enrichment culture was routinely used favoring the growth of this
species, which has been shown to be present in extremely low numbers
with respect to the dominating microbiota (Davenport 1976,
Martini et al. 1996, Phaff et al. 1978a). On the contrary, S. cerevisiae
massively colonizes artificial fermentation environments where it
persists, reproduces, evolves and can be dispersed (Mercado et al.
2007, Rosini 1984).
This genetic isolation in technological islands (wineries, breweries,
bakeries) may have originated a kind of “winery drift” favoring
highly fermenting cells in sugar rich habitats. Accordingly, a selection
was imposed towards a catabolic pathway with low energy efficiency
and negligible respiration (Crabtree effect) (Merico et al. 2007).
These peculiar physiological characteristics could be the reason for
the scarce presence of this species in natural environments (Martini
et al. 1996, Phaff et al. 1978a) due to an inability to compete with
other microorganisms, which are more adapted to those habitats.
At this point, a scenario could be proposed in which a progenitor
strain/species associated with the few sugar-rich natural substrates
(e.g., tree exudates, fruits) was involved in the first episodes of natural
fermentation of sugary juices. It could be possible that through
time the process was recognized as useful, and the procedure was
continued and improved upon by humans. A suitable candidate for
this primeval starter/progenitor is S. paradoxus, which is still the only
highly fermenting Saccharomyces species isolated exclusively in
nature (Liti et al. 2006, Naumov and Nikonenko 1988). S. paradoxus
is for the most part phenotypically indistinguishable from S. cerevisiae
with which it shares about 50% of its nucleotide sequences
(Vaughan-Martini 1989) and which has been shown to mate with
the domesticated species, although generally without producing fertile
progeny (Naumov 1986b). It may be possible that sometime in
the past S. paradoxus occupied and persisted in man-made environments
(e.g., brewery/winery/bakery) and through genetic changes
evolved into S. cerevisiae (Vaughan-Martini and Martini 1995).
Fernandez-Espinar et al. (2003) discuss the feasibility of the two
conflicting hypotheses regarding the origin of S. cerevisiae: (a) a “natural”
yeast species of plant origin (Mortimer and Polsinelli 1999), or
(b) a domesticated species originating from the natural species
S. paradoxus (Martini and Vaughan-Martini 1990). While not
confirming either of the theories, results of a RAPD-PCR study
(Fernandez-Espinar et al. 2003) indicate: (1) a close relationship
between S. cerevisiae and S. paradoxus as also demonstrated by other
studies (Liti et al. 2006, Naumov 1986b, Vaughan-Martini 1989),
(2) that S. cerevisiae strains of different origin form a monophyletic
group with a single origin (compatible with both a natural speciation
process and a single domestication event), and (3) that S. paradoxus
shows a higher degree of genetic diversity with respect to
S. cerevisiae, indicating a more ancient origin of the former species,
which is compatible with its possible parental role in the origin of
S. cerevisiae as originally suggested by Vaughan-Martini and Martini
(1990).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
DBVPG 7790 (NCYC 1379), isolated
from a brewery, New Zealand; DBVPG 7267 (CBS 8840, IFO 1802,
NCYC 2889); DBVPG 7268 (IFO 1803, NCYC 2969), both from decaying
leaves, Japan (Naumov et al. 2000).
Ecology:
Saccharomyces kudriavzevii is apparently a naturally occurring
species since most of the known strains have been isolated from
natural environments in Japan and in Portugal (Naumov et al. 2000,
Sampaio and Conçalves 2008). Nevertheless, strains of the species
have also been isolated in commercial fermentations in New Zealand
and in Europe (Gonzáles 2006, Lopandic et al. 2007).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
DBVPG 7269 and DBVPG 7991 (CBS 8839,
IFO 1815, IFO 1815-2A, NCYC 2888, NRRLY-27342); DBVPG 7270 (IFO 1816,
NCYC 2970), all strainswere isolated fromsoil, Japan (Naumov et al. 2000).
Ecology:
In contrast to some species of the genus Saccharomyces, with
the exception of S. arboricolus, S. paradoxus and S. kudriavzevii, strains
of S. mikatae were isolated in natural environments (from soil and from
decaying leaves, respectively) in Japan (Naumov et al. 2000).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
DBVPG 6045 (CBS 406, IFO O259,
NRRL Y-1548), type strain of S. mangini var. tetraspora, from exudate
of an oak tree (Quercus sp.), The Netherlands; DBVPG 6303 (UCD-FST
52-153) and DBVPG 6304 (UCD-FST 51-186), from Drosophila sp.,
USA; DBVPG 6411 (CBS 432, NRRL Y-17217), of unknown origin;
DBVPG 6466 (CBS 5829), type strain of S. cerevisiae var. terrestris,
from moor soil, Denmark; DBVPG 6487, DBVPG 6490, DBVPG 6491,
DBVPG 6493 and DBVPG 6494, from tree exudates, Russia.
Ecology:
Strains of S. paradoxus have been isolated from natural
environments usually associated with tree exudates, the phylloplane
or with an unidentified species of Drosophila (Glushakova et al. 2007,
Naumov et al. 1997, 1998, Phaff et al. 1956).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
DBVPG 6033 (CBS 1513), type strain of
S. carlsbergensis, brewery yeast; DBVPG 6047 (ATCC 12,752, CBS 1538, IFO 0613, NCYC 392, NRRL Y-1551), probably isolated from
beer; DBVPG 6257 (CBS 1260), unknown; DBVPG 6258 (CBS 1486),
beer; DBVPG 6261 (CBS 1503), type strain of S. monacensis, from
beer; DBVPG 6284 (Carlsberg AJL 248) and DBVPG 6285 (Carlsberg M
1563), probably from beer, Denmark.
Ecology:
No studies are known that demonstrate the presence of
strains of this species in nature.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 821(ATCC 11313, NRRL
Y-12793) isolated by M.W. Beijerinck; CBS 2624, type strain of
Saccharomycodes bisporus; UCD-FST 72-128, from exudate of Gambel
oak (Quercus gambelii, Fagaceae), Arizona, USA; UCD-FST 77-13, from
exudate from a swamp chestnut oak (Quercus primus5Q. michauxii),
Virginia, USA. Additional strains: CBS 5928, from garden soil, South
Africa; CBS 7780, from bottled cider, Belgium; CBS 8338, from white
wine, the Netherlands; seven strains from Carlsberg Laboratory,
Copenhagen, Denmark: two diploids (UCD-FST 55-104 and 55-106),
three short-celled haploids (UCD-FST 57-52, 52-54 and 52-57), and
three long-celled haploids (UCD-FST 57-53 and 57-55).
Ecology:
Isolates of S. ludwigii have been reported from soil (Barnett
et al. 2000), fruits and fruit juices (Beech and Davenport 1970),
insects (Lachance et al. 1995), fermented beverages (Mayser et al.
1995, Thomas 1993) and also associated with oak trees (Miller and
Phaff 1998). However, isolates in fermented beverages are likely to
have originated from fruit juices and hence from fruits. The number
of S. ludwigii cells found on fruits is reported to be low (Beech and
Davenport 1970). Therefore, from the pattern of isolation, the ecology
of S. ludwigii may be primarily associated with oak trees and the
slime fluxes and insects associated with oak trees (Beech and
Davenport 1970, Lachance et al. 1995, Miller and Phaff 1998).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7075 (IFO/NBRC 10111), isolated
from soil in China.
Ecology:
The single known strain of S. sinensis was isolated from forest
soil, Mount Chienfeng, Hainan Island, China.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2519 (NRRL Y-17639), originally
received from H. Schnegg, Germany, and designated as neotype by
Lodder and Kreger-van Rij (1952), substrate unknown; CBS 5063
(NRRL Y-7486), Harden’s strain 127 originally from the National
Collection of Type Cultures (UK), but received by CBS from the
University of Hiroshima; CBS 5638 (NRRL Y-7487), from pollen on a
carpenter bee (Xylocopa caffra), South Africa, J. P. van der Walt.
Ecology:
Strain histories are incomplete for most available isolates of
S. capsularis, resulting in little ecological information. CBS 5638 was
isolated from pollen on a carpenter bee in South Africa.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-5902 (CBS 6447), NRRL
Y-5903, NRRL Y-5904 (CBS 6448), NRRL Y-5910, isolated from fallen
hawthorne (Crataegus sp.) fruits; NRRL YB-192, from Concord grapes
(Vitis labrusca), all preceding strains from Peoria, Illinois, USA; NRRL
YB-440, from a pineapple of unknown source, L.J. Wickerham.
Ecology:
Saccharomycopsis crataegensis and S. vini have similar habitats
and may co-occur on the fruits of grapes and hawthorne trees
(Kurtzman and Wickerham 1973).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7830 (CCRC 22530, NRRL Y-17710),
isolated from soil in a papaya orchard, Taiwan; CBS 7831, CBS 7832,
from soil from carambola orchards, Taiwan (Lee et al. 1994a).
Ecology:
Saccharomycopsis fermentans is known from three strains, all of
which were isolated fromfruit orchard soil in Taiwan (Lee et al. 1994a).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2521 (NRRL Y-2388), type strain,
isolated from chalky rye bread, Germany; CBS 2523 (NRRL Y-3),
authentic strain of Endomyces lindneri, from Chinese yeast; CBS 2525
(NRRL Y-2385), from a yeast cake, The Netherlands, A.P. Struyk; CBS
2527 (NRRL Y-2386), China; CBS 5190 (NRRL Y-7488), from ragi; CBS
6266 (NRRL Y-7170), type strain, Candida lactosa, from ragi-tapi,
Indonesia; CBS 7434, type strain, Botryoascus cladosporoides, from air
in a chicken coop, Spain, A. Martínez; NRRL Y-1058-NRRL Y-1062 (CBS
6310), NRRL Y-1063, from flour, USA; NRRL Y-1064-NRRL Y-1072, from
macaroni, USA, N.C. Laffer; NRRL Y-5395, from thumba, a starchy
drink, India; NRRL Y-7061, from chica, a native South American drink;
NRRL Y-7324-NRRL Y-7326, from Tibetan beer starter; NRRL Y-11983,
from ragi, Indonesia; NRRL Y-12848, from bubod, Philippine Islands;
and many other strains from sources as above.
Ecology:
Saccharomycopsis fibuligera has been isolated worldwide
from high starch substrates as seen under “Origin of the strains studied”,
and from studies of the microbiota of cereal-based fermented
foods and beverages (Cronk et al. 1977, Nout 2009).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2555 (NRRL Y-1483), from
A. Guilliermond and attributed to be Klöcker’s original strain from
soil, Java, Indonesia.
Ecology:
The single known strain of S. javanensis was isolated from
soil in Indonesia.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6267 (NRRL Y-7175), the type
strain of Hansenula malanga, isolated from ragi-tape, Indonesia, by
Dwidjoseputro and Wolf (1970); NRRL Y-6948, from a yeast ball,
Hong Kong, China; NRRL Y-7063-NRRL Y-7066, from ragi, Indonesia;
NRRL Y-7067, from lao chao, Taiwan; NRRL Y-11946, from ragi, West
Java, Indonesia.
Ecology:
Known strains of S. malanga are from starchy fermented
foods isolated throughout Asia. As discussed under S. fibuligera,
S. malanga and the former species are closely related and occur in
similar food products.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-7404 (CBS 6393), type strain of
Pichia microspora, isolated from a beetle (Crossotarsus wollastoni)
found in a wood oil tree (Dipterocarpus indicus, Dipterocarpaceae),
India, L.R. Batra.
Ecology:
The single known strain of S. microspora was isolated from a
beetle that had made a tunnel in a wood oil tree in India (Batra 1971).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7223 (VKM 1073, NRRL Y-17595),
isolated from exudate of oak (Quercus sp., Fagaceae), Russia; CBS
2556 (NRRL Y-2389), from slime flux of oak (Quercus sp.), H.J. Phaff;
CBS 6423 (IFO 1579), type strain of Pichia nonfermentans, from a soybean
protein factory, Japan, T. Nakase; CBS 6449, from a rotted tree
trunk, Japan, K. Kodama; CBS 7048, from slime flux of oak (Quercus
sp.), Russia, I.P. Bab’eva; CBS 7425, from a nematode (Panagrellus
zymosiphilus) on grapes with sour rot, Italy, C. Shann; NRRL YB-1542,
from soil, apple orchard, Peoria, Illinois, USA; NRRL YB-2401, NRRL
YB-2404, from rotted apples, Carbondale, Illinois, USA, the latter
three strains isolated by L.J. Wickerham.
Ecology:
Saccharomycopsis schoenii appears widely distributed in the
Northern Hemisphere. About half of known isolates are from slime
fluxes of oaks and the remainder from rotted apples or soil in
an apple orchard. The apple-associated isolates have D1/D2 LSU
rRNA gene sequences that are identical to that of the type strain
(C.P. Kurtzman, unpublished data), which was isolated from an oak flux.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2562 (NRRL Y-1357), originally
from A. Guilliermond, but the source of isolation is unknown; CBS
2563 (NRRL Y-17724), isolated from tanning fluid in France and originally
supplied by J. Boidin.
Ecology:
Little is known of the ecology of S. selenospora. Of the two
extant strains, the source for one is unknown and the other is from
tanning fluid in France.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6161 (NRRL Y-7466), isolated
from the tunnel of an ambrosia beetle (Platypus externedentatus),
South Africa, J.P. van der Walt; CBS 6186, from the tunnel of a pinborer
beetle (Xyleborus sp.), South Africa, J.P. van der Walt; CBS 7763,
from a scolytid beetle (Anisandrus dispar), Italy, C. Pucci.
Ecology:
The few available strains of S. synnaedendra have been isolated
from insect tunnels in trees growing in South Africa and Italy.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 4110 (NRRL Y-7126, NRRL
Y-7290), CBS 4109 (NRRL Y-7127), isolated from grapes, Chile; CBS
4097 (NRRL Y-7289), CBS 4376 (NRRL Y-7291), CBS 4377 (NRRL
Y-7292), from grape must, Brazil; NRRL Y-5905-Y-5909, NRRL Y-5911-
Y-5916, from hawthorne (Crataegus sp.) fruits, Peoria, Illinois, USA,
L.J. Wickerham.
Ecology:
Saccharomycopsis vini may be distributed throughout North
and South America and has been isolated from grapes in Chile, grape
must in Brazil and hawthorne fruits in Illinois, USA.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
IAM 12963 (BCRC 22490, CBS 7301,
IFO 10748, JCM 7358, NBRC 10748), and IAM 12964 (BCRC 22488,
CBS 7427, IFO 10749, JCM 7359, NBRC 10749), both isolated from soil,
Laya, Bhutan.
Ecology:
Saitoella complicata is presently known from soil collected
in Laya, Bhutan.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 197.35, mating type a, isolated
from wood pulp, E. Rennerfelt, Sweden; CBS 162.80 (CBS H-14215,
holotype of the teleomorph, holotype of Trichosporon capitatum, from
bovine mastitis milk, G.A. Pepin,Weybridge, UK; CBS 571.82 (CBS 2364,
ATCC 10663), lectotype strain of Trichosporon capitatum, from wood
pulp factory with an air-tight warming system, E. Rennerfelt; CBS
579.82 (CBS 5583) and CBS 580.82 (CBS 5584), mating type a, all
authentic for Geotrichum linkii, from sputum, L. do Carmo-Sousa; CBS
573.82, from yeast cake, A.P. Struyck; CBS 207.83 (ATCC 46132), type
strain of Blastoschizomyces pseudotrichosporon, from sputum, I.F. Salkin,
USA; CBS 716.84, from the digestive tract of swine, H. Saëz, Paris Zoo,
France; CBS 327.86, from blood culture of human patient, J.P. Manzella,
USA; CBS 328.86, from blood culture of human patient with leukemia,
E. Drouhet. Other strains examined: sputum(five); oral infections (two).
Ecology:
The species occurs worldwide in different heated habitats,
including the digestive and respiratory tracts of human and other
animals.
The species seems to be associated with rotten wood.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 425.71 (NRRL Y-17570, IFO 10824),
isolated from human lung tissue, D.G. Ahearn, Atlanta, Georgia USA;
CBS 576.82 (CBS 2465), from human patient with asthma, N.G.M. Orie,
Netherlands; CBS 758.85, from cactus rot, M.-A. Lachance, Arizona,
USA; CBS 969.87, from human blood, E. Guého, France; CBS 970.87,
isolated from condensation droplets brewery, A. Siernicki, Belgium;
CBS 489.88, from human liver abscess E. Guého, France.
Ecology: unknown

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 625.85, isolated from Nectria
cinnabarina (Nectriaceae, Hypocreales), Russia.
Ecology:
The single strain of this species was isolated from ascocarps
of Nectria cinnabarina.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 140.25, type strain of Oospora gigas,
isolated from juice of a sugar palm (Arenga saccharifera, Arecaceae),
J. Smit; CBS 126.76, type strain of Geotrichum rectangulatum, from oily
debris, S. Goto, Japan; CBS 10312, from surface of fishfly (Chauliodes rastricornis),
Louisiana, USA, S.-O. Suh (Nguyen et al. 2007).
Ecology: unknown

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 517.90 (CBS 4603), type culture of
Candida ingens, isolated from wine cellar, J.P. van der Walt, South
Africa; CBS 524.90 (CBS 6787, NRRL Y-10929), type strain of Pichia
humboldtii, mutant of CBS 517.90.
Ecology: The type strain was isolated from a wine cellar.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 100158 (JCM 2451), isolated from
exudate of tree.
Ecology: The single strain was isolated from exudates of tree.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 107.12, origin unknown,
P. Claussen; CBS 108.12 (NRRL Y-17563), possibly ex-holotype of the
teleomorph, P. Lindner; CBS 151.30, type strain of Oospora magnusii,
from exudate of an oak (Quercus sp., Fagaceae), W. Stautz; CBS
234.85, from exudate of an oak (Quercus alba), B.M. Wright,
Pennsylvania, USA.
Ecology:
The species is probably restricted to the slime flux of oak
trees.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 765.85 (CBS H-13669, holotype),
isolated from slime flux of a ponderosa pine (Pinus ponderosa,
Pinaceae), H.S. Whitney, USA.
Ecology:
The single strain was isolated from the slime flux of ponderosa
pine, USA.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 750.85, CBS 751.85 and CBS
752.85, all isolated from slime flux of red oak (Quercus rubra,
Fagaceae), M.-A. Lachance, Ontario, Canada.
Ecology:
Strains have been isolated from the slime flux of a red oak
in Canada.
The species seems to occur in aquatic habitats.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 192.55 (CBS 2508, NRRL Y-17574),
isolated from tannin concentrate, C. Ramírez; CBS 634.85 (CBS 2544,
NRRL Y-1523, IFO 1201), authentic strain of Oospora sericea, from
slime flux of oak (Quercus sp., Fagaceae), W. Stautz, Germany; CBS
635.85 (CBS 4731, IFO 10827), unknown, M. Waller, Germany; CBS
749.85 ( BPI 3528), type strain of Dipodascus ambrosiae, from an
insect tunnel, L.R. Batra, California, USA.
Ecology:
The species seems to be restricted to the slime fluxes of
deciduous trees. The strain obtained from tannin concentrate initially
may have had a similar ecological niche.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 152.25 (NRRL Y-17571, IFO
10825), type strain of Oidium suaveolens, isolated from water in
brewery, A. Krzemecki; CBS 127.76, type strain of Geotrichum fici,
from fig (Ficus sp.) S. Goto, Japan; CBS 188.38, from effluent milk factory,
T.G. Tomlinson; CBS 194.34, from mash of maize, W.E. Burns;
CBS 610.85 and CBS 326.86, from human pulmonary infections,
H.S. Randhawa, India; CBS 380.94, from process-water from wheatstarch
production plant, Belgium. Other isolates: one strain from
extracted soybean flakes and three strains of unknown origin.
Ecology:
The species seems to occur worldwide and is regularly
found in nutrient-rich liquid substrates, particularly in industrial
waste water.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-7555 (CBS 6121) is the only
known strain of S. ahearnii, and was isolated from muddy water in
the rhizosphere of oyster grass (Spartina alterniflora) growing in the
salt marshes of Barataria Bay in southeastern Louisiana, USA
(Kurtzman 1991b). Received from D.G. Ahearn, USA.
Ecology:
The only known strain of S. ahearnii was isolated from a
salt marsh (Kurtzman 1991b). The closely related species S. besseyi
was also from a marsh, suggesting that marshes, perhaps salt
marshes, may prove to be the natural habitat for both species.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL YB-4711 (CBS 6343) is the only
known strain of this species and was isolated by L. J. Wickerham in
August 1959 from shallow water in a marsh, perhaps a salt marsh,
near Bonaventure, Gaspé Peninsula, Quebec, Canada.
Ecology:
The only known strain of this species was isolated from a
salt (?) marsh. Because the closely related species S. ahearnii was
isolated from a salt marsh, the primary habitat for both species may
be in marshes (Kurtzman 1991b, Kurtzman and Wickerham 1972).

The ecology of this species can be inferred as arboreal
because the two known strains were isolated from exudates of hardwood
trees (Beijerinck 1908, Kodama and Kyono 1974a).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-27828 (CBS 10007, UFMG-55)
isolated from the crop of Drosophila cardinae, Rio de Janeiro State,
Brazil. In addition to the type strain, Morais et al. (2005) reported
isolation of five additional strains from the same geographical
region: UFMG-56, -57 and -58, also from crops of D. cardinae, UFMG-59 from the external parts of D. cardinae and UFMG-60 from
the external parts of D. fascioloides.
Ecology:
Saturnispora hagleri has been collected multiple times from
crops and external parts of two species of Drosophila in the Ilha
Grande State Forest Park, Rio de Janeiro State, Brazil. Morais et al.
(2005) suggested that the yeast may colonize fruits and other substrates
visited by these flies.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-11515 (CBS 5620), NRRL
Y-11516 (CBS 5621) and NRRL Y-11517 (CBS 5622) are the only known
strains and all were isolated from sauerkraut, The Netherlands.
Ecology:
The three known strains of this species were isolated from
sauerkraut, which suggests that the natural habitat may be in acidic,
high salt environments (Kurtzman 2006b).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-6671 (CBS 4910), isolated
from exudate of hornbeam (Carpinus sp.) (Kodama et al. 1962); NRRL
Y-7655, NRRL Y-7820   NRRL Y-7826, from various hardwood trees,
K. Kodama, Japan.
Ecology:
Saturnispora saitoi is associated with trees. The type strain
was isolated from the exudate of a hornbeam (Kodama et al. 1962),
and Kodama and Kyono (1974a) reported isolating the species from
different deciduous trees in Japan.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 5799 (NRRL Y-7008), isolated
from exudate of an oak (Quercus serrata complex), Japan; NRRL
Y-7009 (AJ 4143), from soil, Japan; NRRL Y-17640 (CBS 8055), type
strain of Candida agrestis, from wild grape (Vitis coignetiae), Japan.
Ecology:
The three known isolates of this species are from plants
and soil (Nakase and Komagata 1966).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6857 (NRRL Y-11571, MCYC 701),
isolated from an adult larva of the insect Calcophora mariana massiliensis
in Scotch pine (Pinus silvestris), Spain, J. Santa María. The following
additional strains of S. segobiensis were received from J. Santa
María and had been isolated from insect larvae and insect frass from
pine trees growing in Spain: NRRL Y-5550 (Strain 32C), NRRL Y-5551
(Str. 32D), NRRL Y-5570 (Str. 38D), NRRL Y-5614 (Str. 122), NRRL
Y-11588 (MCYC 790), NRRL Y-11589 (MCYC 861), NRRL Y-11590
(MCYC 991). The identity of NRRL Y-5550, Y-5551, Y-5570 and Y-5614
was verified from D1/D2 LSU rRNA gene sequence analysis (C.P.
Kurtzman, unpublished data).
Ecology:
Scheffersomyces segobiensis has been repeatedly isolated
from insect larvae and their resulting frass in pine trees that were
growing in Spain (Santa María and García Aser 1977). The closely
related S. stipitis is geographically widely distributed in the guts of
insects (Suh et al. 2003), suggesting that S. segobiensis may be more
common than is currently known. Mansfield and Kuldau (2007)
reported the presence of S. segobiensis in ensiled corn from
Pennsylvania, USA, but the method of species identification was
unclear.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-7322 (CBS 6059), NRRL
Y-7557 (CBS 6077), NRRL Y-7664 (CBS 6684), NRRL Y-7665 (CBS
6665), NRRL Y-7666 (CBS 6685), NRRL Y-7667 (CBS 6661), NRRL
Y-7668 (CBS 6664), NRRL Y-7669 (CBS 6686), NRRL Y-7670 (CBS 6687), NRRL Y-7872, all isolated from oyster grass (Spartina alterniflora)
marshes, Barataria Bay, Louisiana, USA, D.G. Ahearn. NRRL Y-7689 (CBS
6688, PRL 316-71), NRRL Y-7690 (CBS 6689, PRL 328-71), NRRL Y-7691
(CBS 6690, PRL 331-71), NRRL Y-7692 (CBS 6691, PRL 475-71), NRRL
Y-7693 (CBS 6692, PRL 476-71), all from water, Canada, N.R. Gardner.
For the Canadian strains, the type of water and the geographical location
were not provided. Of these latter strains, the D1/D2 LSU rRNA
gene sequence of NRRL Y-7689 was identical with the type strain of
S. spartinae.
Ecology:
Scheffersomyces spartinae is known only from water environments.
Many of the available strains were isolated from the brackish
waters of Barataria Bay, Louisiana, USA, in association with marsh
grass. Strains from Canada were from a water environment as well,
but other details of their habitat were unavailable. Gillings et al.
(2006) reported S. spartinae to be common in biofilms that clogged a
water treatment plant near Botany Bay in New South Wales,
Australia. One of the major contaminants in the treatment water was
1,2-dichloroethane.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 5773 (NRRL Y-7124, LY 1321), CBS
5774 (NRRL Y-11542, LY 1322), CBS 5775 (NRRL Y-11543, LY 1323),
CBS 5776 (NRRL Y-11544, LY 1324), isolated from insect larvae,
France, J. Boidin; CBS 6054 (NRRL Y-11545), J. Santa María; NRRL
Y-27535 (KS-42-W2), from gut of a Passalid beetle, Kansas, USA,
R. Lichtwardt. The following strains were received from
M. Blackwell: NRRL Y-27547 (BG 01-5-4-2-1), Passalid beetle
(Odontotaenius disjunctus), Shell Bluff, Georgia, USA; NRRL Y-27548
(GA 012-1-1), Passalid beetle (O. disjunctus), Lake Herrick Park,
Georgia, USA; NRRL Y-27549 (BG 02-7-16-1), beetle, Orangeburg Co.,
South Carolina, USA; NRRL Y-27550 (BG 02-2-11-6-5), NRRL Y-27551
(BG 02-4-1-3-1), both from Passalid beetles (O. disjunctus), Baton
Rouge, Louisiana, USA; NRRL Y-27552 (BG 02-7-14-003-1-1), NRRL
Y-27553 (BG 02-7-14-003-2-1), both from beetles (Verres stembergianus),
Barro Colorado Island, Panama; NRRL Y-27554 (BG 03-3-25-1-3),
NRRL Y-27555 (BG 03-3-25-1-5), both from Passalid beetles (O. disjunctus),
Oxford, Pennsylvania, USA. The following strains were isolated
by C.P. Kurtzman: NRRL Y-8209, NRRL Y-8220, NRRL Y-8271,
from rotted trees, near New Orleans, Louisiana, USA. The following
were isolated by L.J. Wickerham: NRRL YB-1337, rotted log, NRRL
YB-1338, water oak (Quercus nigra), NRRL YB-4200, rotted maple
(Acer sp.), all from Marion, Illinois, USA; NRRL YB-1355, from canned
peppers, NRRL YB-1551, rotted oak tree (Quercus sp.), NRRL YB-1582
and NRRL YB-1611, shagbark hickory (Carya ovata), all from Peoria,
Illinois, USA; NRRL YB-1762, rotted log, Brownfield Woods, Illinois,
USA; NRRL YB-3713, dead oak tree (Quercus sp.), NRRL YB-3756, dead
pine tree (Pinus sp.), both from Gainesville, Florida, USA; NRRL
YB-4122, tree frass, Wabatongushi Island, Canada; NRRL YB-2048,
frass, blackjack oak (Quercus marilandica), NRRL YB-2051, dead black
oak (Quercus velutina), NRRL YB-3619, frass, American elm (Ulmus
americana), all from the USA.
Ecology:
Scheffersomyces stipitis is frequently isolated in Europe,
North America and Central America, as seen from strain histories
given under “Origin of the strains studied” and from the publications
of Pignal (1967) and Suh et al. (2003). Strains were isolated from
wood infesting insect larvae and their frass, from the guts of beetles
and from rotted wood. Suh et al. (2003) raised the possibility of a
symbiotic relationship between S. stipitis and the beetles that they
inhabit, perhaps with the yeast metabolizing D-xylose to the benefit
of the insects.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2159 (NRRL YB-3963, ATCC 24615,
IFO 10842), isolated from soil in a peat bog, Denmark, A. Lund; CBS
2914, from forest soil, New Zealand, M.E. di Menna; CBS 6297 (IFO
10843), from soil, Germany, S. Windisch, and three additional strains
isolated from soil, New Zealand, M.E. di Menna (1965).
Ecology:
Schizoblastosporion starkeyi-henricii was isolated mainly
from soils in different countries, e.g., Denmark (Lund 1954), New
Zealand (di Menna 1957) and Norway (Roberts 1960). The predominance
of this species in some marsh soils in the USSR was mentioned
by Babjeva and Blagodatskaya (1972) and the occurrence in ginseng
cultivation fields in Korea was reported by Hong et al. (2006).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
DBVPG 6274 (CBS 354), isolated from
strawberry wine, Japan; DBVPG 6351 (CBS 103, DBVPG 4207), type
strain of Schiz. japonicus var. versatilis, from grape must, USA; DBVPG
6371 (CBS 5679), from slime flux of a smooth leaf elm (Ulmus carpinifolia);
DBVPG 6416 (CBS 102), from grape juice, USA.
Ecology:
Strains of Schiz. japonicus are usually found in high sugar
habitats.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
DBVPG 4091 and DBVPG 4092, both
isolated from honey, Ethiopia; DBVPG 4093 and DBVPG 4094, both
from dried figs, Iraq; DBVPG 6276 (ATCC 4206, CBS 371, NRRL Y-855),
from currants, Greece, M. Beijerinck, and selected as the type by
Lodder and Kreger-van Rij (1952); DBVPG 6278 (CBS 6207), DBVPG
6443 (CBS 6209) and DBVPG 6472 (CBS 6206), all from honey, India;
DBVPG 6471 (CBS 373), from honey, Canada; DBVPG 6434 (CBS
2632), origin unknown.
Ecology:
Strains of this species are usually found in high sugar habitats
such as honey and dried fruits

Paragraph of Species Studied:
DBVPG 6277 (CBS 356), isolated from
arak mash, received at CBS from the Král collection in 1922, and designated
as the type by Lodder and Kreger-van Rij (1952); DBVPG
6280 (CBS 357), from cane sugar molasses, Jamaica; DBVPG 6373
(CBS 352), from arak mash, South Africa; DBVPG 6374 (CBS 358),
DBVPG 6418 (CBS 374), both from molasses; DBVPG 6448 (CBS
5680), from apples, Poland; DBVPG 6450 (CBS 1063), from cane
sugar molasses.
Ecology:
Strains of this species are usually found in high sugar habitats.
See also the agriculture and food section below.Agriculture and food: During a study of the yeast ecology of
Kombucha, a traditional fermentation of sweetened tea involving a
symbiosis of yeast species and acetic acid bacteria, it was found that
Schiz. pombe was present together with other yeast species such as
Brettanomyces bruxellensis, Candida stellata, Torulaspora delbrueckii
and Zygosaccharomyces bailii (Teoh et al. 2004).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2923, isolated from soil, Sweden,
A. Capriotti.
Ecology: unknown

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2011 (NRRL Y-7121), NRRL Y-7546
(CBS 2012), NRRL ETC FFLY-540, NRRL ETC FFLY-543, NRRL ETC
NY-287, all isolated from cucumber brines, USA, J.L. Etchells; NRRL
Y-7547 (CBS 5519), from a fruit fly (Drosophila pseudoobscura), USA,
H.J. Phaff; NRRL Y-11505 (CBS 5603), type strain of Kloeckera faecalis,
from human feces, Brazil, A.C. Batista.
Ecology:
The majority of known strains of S. etchellsii have been isolated
from pickle fermentations, which demonstrated that the species
is tolerant of high salt substrates with low pH.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 819 (NRRL
Y-10), isolated from soil, A. Klöcker; CBS 2863 (NRRL Y-2477), type
strain of Schwanniomyces castellii Capriotti, isolated from soil, Spain,
A. Capriotti; CBS 4516 (NRRL Y-2469), type strain of Schwanniomyces
alluvius, isolated from soil, USA, H.J. Phaff.
Ecology:
The habitat of this species may be soil, because all known
strains have been isolated from soil.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
The variety persoonii
does not assimilate cellobiose, galactose, D-xylose and salicin, or
grow on 7.5% NaCl/5% glucose. These differences allow it to be separated
from the variety occidentalis using standard growth tests. The
morphology of the two varieties is similar, as are their life cycles.

CBS 6741 (JCM 7443),
CBS 6742 (JCM 7442), isolated from soil collected near Graskop,
South Africa, J.P. van der Walt.
Ecology:
Known strains of both varieties of S. polymorphus are isolated
exclusively from soil, suggesting that soil is the natural habitat
of the species.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 186 (JCM 3647,
NRRL Y-2022) and CBS 1359 (JCM 3648, NRRL Y-5), isolated from soil,
Denmark; CBS 4346 (JCM 3664, NRRL Y-7428), type strain of
Debaryomyces phaffii, isolated from soil, Finland, A. Capriotti; CBS
4349 (JCM 1628, NRRL Y-7958), type strain of Debaryomyces cantarellii,
CBS 4350 (JCM 6180, NRRL Y-7422), isolated from soil, Finland,
A. Capriotti; CBS 5067 (JCM 6181, NRRL Y-7421), isolated from a
“toadstool”, Japan, K. Kodama; CBS 6456 (JCM 6182), CBS 6457 (JCM
6183), isolated from an ant hill, Russia, I.P. Bab’eva; CBS 6453 (JCM
6194), isolated from soil in The Netherlands, J.A.B.A.F. Bonnet.

CBS 2008 (JCM 3652, NRRL YB-4229),
CBS 2009 (JCM 6184, NRRL YB-4228), isolated from tanning liquor,
France, J. Boidin.
Ecology:
The two available strains of S. pseudopolymorpha were isolated
from tanning fluid in France (Ramírez and Boidin 1953a).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 3024 (JCM 3657,
NRRL Y-7430), isolated from soil, South Africa, J.P. van der Walt; CBS
4072 (NRRL Y-6664), type strain of Debaryomyces konokotinae, from
slime flux of an oak (Quercus sp.), former USSR, V.I. Kudryavtsev; CBS
5458 (JCM 6185, NRRL Y-7431), isolated from exudate of a slippery
elm (Ulmus rubra), USA, H.J. Phaff; CBS 6454 (JCM 6187, NRRL Y-7533),
type strain of Debaryomyes formicarius, CBS 6455 (JCM 6188), isolated
from an ant hill, Russia, I.P. Bab’eva; CBS 5709 (JCM 6186), J.P. van der
Walt; CBS 6756 (JCM 6189, NRRL Y-7856), J. Santa María.
Ecology:
All known strains of S. vanrijiae var. vanrijiae have been isolated
from soil, exudates of trees and ant hills. Strains of the variety
yarrowii have been isolated from excrement of insects and soil
(Golubev and Bab’eva 1972).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6246 (JCM 6190,
NRRL Y-7535), isolated from excrement of insects on an empress tree
(Paulownia imperialis, Paulowniaceae), Spain, J. Santa María; CBS
6755 (JCM 6192, NRRL Y-7855), isolated from soil, South Africa, J.P.
van der Walt.

CBS 7035, isolated from soil in South
