Africa; CBS 7036, isolated from a lichen in South Africa, both from
J.P. van der Walt.
Ecology:
Of the two known strains, one was isolated from soil and
the other from a lichen, both from South Africa (van der Walt and
Johannsen 1980).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-27907 (CBS 10155), isolated
from the gut of Odontotaenius disjunctus (Coleoptera: Passalidae).
Ecology:
This species has only been isolated once from the gut of
the wood-boring beetle Odontotaenius disjunctus, and it is not
nearly so common as the Scheffersomyces (Pichia) stipitis-like
yeasts that are almost always associated with the beetle (Nardi
et al. 2006, Suh et al. 2003). It is most likely an inhabitant of
xylose-rich environments.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UCD-FST 72-313 (CBS 6644), isolated
from stem rot of a giant saguaro cactus (Carnegiea gigantea,
Cactaceae), Arizona, USA, is among the many strains isolated from
various species of columnar cacti belonging to the subtribe
Pachycereinae. Numerous strains are from stem rots of columnar
cacti in the subtribe Stenocereinae, e.g., UCD-FST 76-214C, Baja
California, Mexico; from cladode rots of prickly pears (Opuntia spp.,
Cactaceae), e.g., UWOPS 87-2411.2, Hawai’i, USA; and from necrotic
somatic tissue of other cacti, e.g., UCD-FST 76-406C, Sonora, Mexico.
Ecology:
The strongest factor bearing on the distribution of phylotypes
(Fig. 69.1) in the S. cereana species complex appears to be
geography. The strains assigned to the “australis” group originated
from Argentina, Brazil, and Venezuela. The “brasiliensis” phylotype is
so far confined to Brazil. Strains labeled “centralis” came from
Honduras and Mexico. The many confirmed members of S. cereana
in the narrowest sense are restricted to Arizona and Hawai’i where
they were ostensibly introduced together with cacti. The variant
of the species termed “oaxacaensis” consists of several strains collected
in southern Mexico. The phylotype “obscura” seems more
widespread, with isolates in the Caribbean, Mexico, and Venezuela.
Most strains designated as “opuntiana” were spread across the
Caribbean region, Florida and Texas (USA), Peru, and with occasional
isolates from Australia that were probably introduced. The phylotype
“pachycereana” is known from a single isolate collected in Baja
California, Mexico, and the designation “trichocereana” applies to two
strains recovered in large columnar cacti in Argentina. The eventual
discovery of additional biotypes cannot be discounted, as evidenced
from a preliminary analysis conducted on material obtained in other
Neotropical localities by P.F. Ganter (personal communication).
The absence of members of the S. cereana species complex in
cactus fruit samples has been attributed in part to the abundance in
cactus fruit of yeasts capable of producing killer toxins to which certain
strains of S. cereana are sensitive (Starmer et al. 1987). Moreover,
a negative correlation exists between the presence of S. cereana in
individual samples of prickly pear somatic tissue and the occurrence
in each sample of strong killer strains of Pichia kluyveri.
In a study of the diversity of soil fungi by whole community DNA
analysis, Anderson et al. (2003a) reported the presence of an ITS
sequence whose best match was with the “australis” phylotype. A
recent examination of the sequence in question (AY324163), however,
revealed that the highest sequence identity was with Nadsonia
species. The previous misidentification was in all probability due to
the small number of yeast ITS sequences deposited at the time that
the study was performed.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 5771 and CBS 5772, isolated from
two distinct samples of sea water near the Antarctic Peninsula, J.W.
Fell; CBS 6058, from waste lagoon of an asphalt plant, Georgia, USA;
CBS 6192, from the mouth of a patient, Finland; CBS 6989, diploid
strain selected from a mixture of strains CBS 5771, CBS 5772, and CBS
6192, L. Rodrigues de Miranda.
Ecology:
The infrequent isolation of S. lactativora precludes the formulation
of extensive hypotheses about its ecology, although the
species appears to be cosmopolitan in distribution. Because of its
high maximum temperature of growth (37 C or more) in contrast to
the sea water temperature from which some strains were isolated
(ca. 0 C), Fell and Phaff (1967) suggested that its source in sea water
could be the feces of several species of large birds that are common
in Antarctica.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UWOPS 80-118 (CBS 8070, ATCC
56629), UWOPS 80-141(ATCC 56630), and other strains were collected
from slimy exudates of red oaks (Quercus rubra, Fagaceae),
Ontario, Canada.
Ecology:
The presence of S. quercuum in the sap fluxes of red oaks
has been confirmed in three distinct localities where native red oak
populations remain in Ontario, Canada (Pinery Provincial Park,
Bacchus Woods, Long Point National Wildlife Area).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6940 (UCD-FST 76-401B, NRRL
Y-10978), isolated from cina cactus (Rathbunia alamosensis), Guaymas,
Sonora, Mexico; UCD-FST 76-217C (NRRL Y-11598), UCD-FST 76-266A
(NRRL Y-11599), from agria cactus (Macherocereus gummosus), Baja
California Sur, Mexico (Starmer et al. 1978b).
Ecology:
Starmera amethionina and the closely related S. pachycereana
were isolated from rotted tissue in several cactus genera predominantly
in Baja California Sur, Mexico, and less frequently in Baja
California Norte, the western Sonora desert, Mexico, and southern
Arizona, USA. S. amethionina occurs predominantly on cacti of the
subtribe Stenocereinae, whereas S. pachycereana predominates in
cacti of the subtribe Pachycereinae (Starmer et al. 1978b). Morais
et al. (1994) also reported isolating S. pachycereana from the sand
dune ecosystem of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7692 (UCD-FST 81-62, NRRL
Y-17468) isolated from rotting prickly pear cactus (Opuntia stricta),
Exuma chain, Bahamas; CBS 7695 (UCD-FST 82-570C, NRRL Y-17469),
from rotting columnar cactus (Cephalocereus royenii), Island of
Montserrat, West Indies; CBS 7696 (UCD-FST 83-711.2, NRRL
Y-17472), from prickly pear cactus, Conception Island, Bahamas.
Ecology:
The host range of P. caribaea and its geographical distribution
throughout the Caribbean were well documented by Phaff et al.
(1992). Isolates of S. caribaea were obtained from seven genera of
cacti geographically ranging from southern Texas, USA to Venezuela

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6154 (NRRL Y-10990) and CBS
6155 (NRRL Y-10991), both isolated from tunnels of the pin hole
borer (Platypus externedentatus) infesting various figs (Ficus spp.),
Natal, South Africa. J.P. van der Walt.
Ecology:
Strains of S. dryadoides are known only from figs in South
Africa that were infested by insect borers (Scott and van der Walt
1971a).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6943 (UCD-FST 76-384A, NRRL
Y-10981), isolated from rotted cardon cactus (Pachycereus pringlei),
Mulegé, Baja California Sur, Mexico; UCD-FST 76-227A (NRRL Y-11600),
from rotted cardon cactus, San Pedro, Baja California Sur, Mexico; UCDFST
76-247B (NRRL Y-11601), rotted tissue, agria cactus (Macherocereus
gummosus), Isla San Jose, Baja California Sur, Mexico (Starmer et al.
1978b); NRRL Y-17779 (SU 80-314.1), from a fly (Drosophila nigrospiracula),
Ironwood, Tucson Mountains, Arizona, USA,W.T. Starmer.
Ecology:
Starmera amethionina and the closely related S. pachycereana
were isolated from rotted tissue in several cactus genera predominantly
in Baja California Sur, Mexico, and less frequently in Baja
California Norte, the western Sonora desert, Mexico, and southern
Arizona, USA. S. amethionina occurs predominantly on cacti of the
subtribe Stenocereinae, whereas S. pachycereana predominates in
cacti of the subtribe Pachycereinae (Starmer et al. 1978b). Morais
et al. (1994) also reported isolating S. pachycereana from the sand
dune ecosystem of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2283 (NRRL YB-4281), from the
slime flux of a black oak (Quercus kelloggii), Mather, California, USA
(Phaff and Knapp 1956).
Ecology:
The single available strain of S. quercuum was isolated from
the flux of a black oak (Quercus kelloggii) in California, USA.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6009, isolated from the honey of
bumble bee (Bombus sp.); CBS 7267, from concentrated grape juice, South
Africa; the following from flowers of Calystegia sepium (Convolvulaceae):
UWOPS 97-118 (CBS 8451, NRRL-Y-27359) and several other strains in various
localities in Ontario, Canada; UWOPS 97-211.1, Syracuse, New York,
USA; UWOPS 97-105 and others, from the obscure sap beetle Conotelus
obscurus on Calystegia sepium; UWOPS 99-542.1 and other strains, from
Conotelus obscurus and other insects from Convolulus arvensis; UWOPS
00-502.1, from an unidentified beetle from Calystegia spithamea; UWOPS
401.1, from solitary bee from a flower of cranesbill (Geranium sp.,
Geraniaceae), various localities in Ontario, Canada. UWOPS 99-686.3,
from a sap beetle (Aethina concolor, Coleoptera: Nitidulidae) collected
from a flower of beach morning glory (Ipomoea pes-caprae,
Convolvulaceae) on Mana Island, Fiji; UWOPS 00-141.1, from a small nitidulid
beetle found in a flower of morning glory (Ipomoea trifida); UWOPS
00-153b1, from a cucumber beetle (Diabrotica sp., Coleoptera:
Chrysomelidae) found in a flower of wood rose (Merremia tuberose,
Convolvulaceae); UWO00-227.2, from a stingless bee (Trigona fulviventris,
Hymenoptera: Apidae), Guanacaste Province, Costa Rica.
Ecology:
The association of S. bombicola with bees and flowers visited
by bees is quite clear, but the nature of the association is not.
The yeast is also an occasional and minor component of the community
associated with other floricolous insects, indicating that bees act
as principal vector. Whether a specific selection mechanism exists at
the level of the bee is not known. Osmotolerance may play a role,
but the latter is a common property of floricolous yeasts as well.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UFMG 01-J26.1 (CBS 9117), and many
other strains from Tetragonisca angustula (Hymenoptera, Apiidae:
Meliponini), its honey, pollen provisions, and refuse; UFMG 01-J74.1,
from honey of Melipona quadrifasciata and Melipona rufiventris
adults, in various localities in Brazil; UWOPS 98-132.2, from a flower
of Hibiscus fallax (Malvaceae), Nitmiluk Park, Northern Territory,
Australia; UWOPS 00-227.1, from a flower of rock rosemary (Merremia quinquefolia, Convolvulaceae) in Guanacaste Province,
Costa Rica; UWOPS 05-278.3, from a stingless bee (Trigona sp.), from
a flower of Hibiscus tiliaceus, Perak, Malaysia.
Ecology:
Starmerella meliponinorum is thought to play an important
role in the nutrition of meliponine (stingless) bees with which it is
associated (Teixeira et al. 2003). The yeast is found in adult workers
as well as pollen provisions, honey, propolis, and refuse pellets. In
hives the cell density is high, often reaching 106 cfu/g in pollen provisions,
which suggests that the yeast grows on simple nutrients that
are found in bee forage. From this, it may be inferred that the yeast
causes enrichment in the nutritional value of the forage for the bee.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
This species is known from two strains.
NRRL YB-2067 (CBS 10352) was isolated in 1950 by L. J. Wickerham
from frass in a black oak (Quercus kelloggii), Salem, Missouri, USA.
NRRL YB-4197 (CBS 10353) was isolated in 1956 by L. J. Wickerham
from frass in an unidentified oak (Quercus sp.), Marion, Illinois, USA.
Ecology:
The two known strains of this species were isolated from insect
frass from oak trees in Illinois andMissouri, USA (Kurtzman 2007b).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
This species is known from four
strains: NRRL Y-17643 (CBS 8169), from rotted wood of the southern
hemisphere beech (Nothofagus dombeyii), Chile, collected 1980, type
strain of Candida bertae var. bertae; NRRL Y-17646 (CBS 8168), from
rotted wood of the ulmo tree (Eucryphia cordifolia), Chile, 1980, type
strain of Candida bertae var. chiloensis; NRRL Y-27087 (CBS 4605),
from a cerambycid larva in wood of N. dombeyii, Chile; NRRL Y-27101
(CBS 5927), from a rotten tree trunk, Chile, 1968 (Ramírez and
González 1984c).
Ecology:
All presently known strains were isolated from rotted wood
or larva infested trees in Chile, South America (Ramírez and
González 1984c).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
All five known strains, NRRL YB-2756,
YB-2764 (CBS 10355), YB-2788 (CBS 10354), YB-2798, YB-2799 (CBS
10356) were isolated by L. J. Wickerham from insect frass in Japanese
red pines (Pinus densiflora) that had been collected near Tokyo,
Japan, 1951.
Ecology:
All known strains of S. japonica were obtained from the
frass of unidentified insect larvae that had bored into Japanese red
pines near Tokyo, Japan (Kurtzman 2007b).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
PTCC 4646 (NRRL Y-17849, CBS
7522.1) and PTCC 4647 (NRRL Y-17850, CBS 7522.2), complementary
mating types derived from heat treatment of soil isolates collected in
Rio de Janeiro, Brazil (Giménez-Jurado et al. 1994); NRRL Y-17083
(CBS 5657), from insect tunnel in Sclerocarya caffra, South Africa,
type strain of Candida edax; and the following eight strains isolated
by L. J. Wickerham, 1950 1951, and since identified from LSU D1/D2
sequences as S. smithiae: NRRL YB-1393, from an elm tree (Ulmus sp.)
stump, Peoria, Illinois, USA; NRRL YB-1994 and YB-1995, frass, slash
pine (Pinus elliottii), Wilma, Florida, USA; NRRL YB-2052, frass, white
oak (Quercus alba), Salem, Missouri, USA; NRRL YB-2062, frass, loblolly
pine (Pinus taeda), Alexandria, Louisiana, USA; NRRL YB-2766,
soil under Quercus serrata, near Tokyo, Japan; NRRL YB-2777, frass,
Japanese red pine (Pinus densiflora), near Tokyo, Japan; NRRL
YB-3095, frass, dead maple tree (Acer sp.), Big Lake, Wisconsin USA.
Ecology:
Nearly all known strains of S. smithiae have been isolated
from insect frass. Invaded trees included pines as well as various
hardwoods, and the geographic distribution may be worldwide in
temperate as well as tropical zones (Giménez-Jurado et al. 1994,
C.P. Kurtzman, unpublished data, van der Walt and Nel 1968).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 683.93 (HA 872, PYCC 5700),
isolated from grey alder (Alnus incana), collected by H. Prillinger
(isolate Pr 1986/62) in Tirol, Austria; CBS 111108 (HA 1364), from
alder-tongues on grey alder (A. incana), collected by K. Bacigálová
in Slovakia; FO 35624, from unknown origin, collected by
F. Oberwinkler, Germany (?); RJB 13181A, from grey alder (A. incana),
collected by R.J. Bandoni, British Columbia, Canada. Strains HA 857,
from A. incana, Germany (?) and HA 859, A. incana, Austria were
studied by Bacigálová et al. (2003).
Ecology:
The strains examined were all isolated from grey alders in
Europe (Austria, Slovakia) and Canada. Mix (1949) and Gjaerum
(1964) list other alder species as hosts of T. alni, namely A. glutinosa,
A. hirsuta, A. hybrida, A. rubra. The geographic range of the species
probably corresponds to that of the hosts. Mix (1949) mentions
Europe (Germany, Norway, Poland), Japan, Alaska and North
America. There have also been several recent reports of the fungus in
the UK and Ireland (British Mycological Society’s Fungal Records
Database of Britain and Ireland: http:/194.203.77.76/fieldmycology/
FRDBI/FRDBI.asp).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 331.55 (PYCC 5701), isolated from
river birch (Betula fontinalis5B. occidentalis), USA.
Ecology:
The species is known for occasionally causing witches’
brooms on several birches native to North America. The
strain examined was isolated from river birch (B. occidentalis) in
the USA. Other hosts listed by Mix (1949) include yellow
birch (B. lutea5B. alleghaniensis) and paper or canoe birch
(B. papyrifera).

The strains examined were isolated from
B. nana3pubescens, dwarf birch (B. nana) or silver birch (B. pendula)
in Scandinavia. The other host listed by Bacigálová (1997a), Gjaerum
(1964) and Mix (1949) is downy birch (B. pubescens; including subsp.
carpatica). Geographic locations listed by the same authors include
Germany, Scotland, Poland and Slovakia, besides Scandinavia.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 351.35 (PYCC 5703), isolated from
white oak (Quercus alba), USA(?); NRRL T-411, from blackjack oak (Q.
marilandica), Kansas, USA; NRRL T-878, from bur oak (Q. macrocarpa),
Kansas, USA; RJB 13067(2), from Northern red oak (Q. rubra), collected
by R.J. Bandoni in Vancouver, BC, Canada.
Ecology:
The strains examined were isolated from four different
Quercus species native to North America, namely white oak (Q. alba),
blackjack oak (Q. marilandica), Northern red oak (Q. rubra) and burr
oak (Q. macrocarpa). More than 50 host species are listed by
Mix (1949, 1954b), the majority of which are from the USA and
Canada. Other geographic locations include countries around the
Mediterranean and in central/Northern Europe (Mix 1949, 1954b;
Gjaerum 1964). Nagao and Katumoto (1998) found T. caerulescens
causing leaf blister on Ubame oak (Q. phillyraeoides) in Japan.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 102169 (HA 1307, PYCC 5706), isolated
from European hornbeam (Carpinus betulus), Slovakia.
Ecology:
The species occurs on hornbeam trees in central and
Northern Europe. The strain examined was isolated from European
hornbeam (Carpinus betulus) in Slovakia. Other geographic locations
mentioned by Mix (1949) and Gjaerum (1964) include the UK,
Germany and Norway. Mix (1949) also lists Oriental hornbeam
(C. orientalis) as host of T. carpini in Russia and Sweden.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 352.35 (PYCC 5707), isolated from
American plum (Prunus americana), USA?; NRRL Y-17786 (CBS
352.35), from American plum (P. americana), USA?; NRRL T-842, from
American plum (P. americana), USA?; NRRL T-755, from black or
Canada plum (P. nigra), USA?; CBS 358.35 (labeled as T. pruni), from
European plum (P. domestica), USA?; NRRL YB-3638 (labeled as
Taphrina sp.), from green plum (P. salicina?), USA?
Ecology:
The strains examined were isolated from American plum
(P. americana) and black or Canada plum (P. nigra). Other hosts listed
by Mix (1949) are P. hortulana, P. lanata, P. maritima, P. munsoniana
and P. umbellata (besides P. angustifolia and P. salicina). Mix was convinced
that T. communis occurred only in North America and that it
could also attack P. domestica cultivated in the USA, although this
host appeared to be less susceptible (see also “Additional comments”).
On this subject Mix (1949) stated that: “Plum pockets found
on ‘domestica’ plums in [the USA] should be ascribed to
T. communis”.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 375.39 (PYCC 5708), isolated from
chokecherry (Prunus virginiana), USA; NRRL T-417, from chokecherry
(P. virginiana), USA.
Ecology:
The species is known for deforming mainly flowers and
fruits of chokecherry (P. virginiana) in the USA and Canada. Mix
(1949) also included the two varieties of P. virginiana (namely, var.
demissa and var. melanocarpa) in the host list. A form producing similar
symptoms on P. alabamensis was also tentatively placed in
T. confusa by Mix (1949).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 334.55 (NRRL Y-17793, PYCC
5709), isolated from red maple (Acer rubrum), USA; NRRL T-796 (CBS
334.55), from red maple (A. rubrum), USA.
Ecology:
Taphrina dearnessii is known for causing spots on leaves of
a single host, red maple (A. rubrum), in the Eastern USA and Canada
(Mix 1949).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 356.35 (ATCC 11124, IFO 8474, IMI
108563, MUCL 30957, PYCC 5710), isolated from fruit of peach (Prunus
persica), The Netherlands; CBS 353.35, from dormant bud of peach
(P. persica), Canada; CBS 355.35, from peach (P. persica), Canada; CBS
102167 (HA 1304), from leaf curl on peach (P. persica), Slovakia; NRRL
T-857, from peach (P. persica), USA (?); NRRL T-470, from almond
(P. communis5P. dulcis), Europe (?); NRRL Y-17787 (IFO 8996), from
peach (P. persica), Japan; PYCC 5894 (isolate AX1), from leaf curl on
peach (P. persica), Portugal; PYCC 5896 (isolate PSoure3a), from peach
leaves, Portugal; CBS 119539 (PYCC 5908; isolate DulcisAlg2b), from
leaf curl on almond (P. dulcis), Portugal; PYCC 5909 (isolate CCd1B),
from leaf curl on almond (P. dulcis), Portugal; PYCC 5910 (isolate CBa),
from leaf curl on almond (P. dulcis), Portugal.
Ecology:
Taphrina deformans is found worldwide wherever peaches
are cultivated, and appears to have accompanied its host (Mix 1949,
Ogawa et al. 1995). Other hosts mentioned in the literature include
almond and apricot, but, as mentioned above, leaf curl on these trees
may be due to different forms of the fungus (e.g., Ogawa et al. 1995).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 111109 (HA 1439, PYCC 5711),
isolated from grey alder (Alnus incana), Slovakia; HA 1440, from grey
alder (A. incana), Slovakia. Strain HA 1334 (from A. incana, Slovakia)
was studied by Bacigálová et al. (2003).
Ecology:
The strains examined were both isolated from grey alders
in Slovakia, one from a witches’ broom infection (HA 1439) and the
other from a spot-type infection (HA 1440). Other locations mentioned
by Mix (1949) and Bacigálová (1994a) include Germany,
Norway, Poland, Slovakia and the Caucasus.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 377.39 (NRRL Y-17795, PYCC
5712), isolated from fruit of susquehana sand cherry (Prunus
susquehanae5P. pumila var. susquehanae?), Ithaca, NY, USA; NRRL
T-882, from susquehana sand cherry (P. susquehanae), USA. Strain IFO
9245 (origin not reported) was studied by Sjamsuridzal et al. (1997).
Ecology:
The strains examined were isolated from susquehana sand
cherry (P. susquehanae). Other hosts listed by Mix (1949, 1954) are
Prunus pumila, P. besseyi (5P. pumila var. besseyi) and P. depressa
(5P. pumila var. depressa). Mix examined specimens from all across
the USA, mainly the northern states, from east to west.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 378.39 (PYCC 5713), isolated from
quaking aspen (Populus tremuloides), North America(?); NRRL T-740,
from quaking aspen (P. tremuloides), USA.
Ecology:
This species is known to occur mainly in central and
Northern Europe on trembling aspen (Pop. tremula Gjaerum 1964,
Bacigálová 1994b), and in eastern North America on American or
quaking aspen (Pop. tremuloides, Mix 1949). The strains examined
were isolated from the latter host. Other hosts listed by Mix (1949)
are Populus canescens (Russia), Pop. grandidentata (USA), Pop. pendula
(Europe) and Pop. sieboldii (Japan).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 335.55 (PYCC 5714) and NRRL
T-791 (CBS 335.55), isolated from mountain maple (Acer spicatum),
North America.
Ecology:
The strains examined were isolated from moose or mountain
maple (Acer spicatum) in North America. Mix (1949) examined
specimens from the Eastern states.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 357.35 (PYCC 5715), isolated from
chickasaw plum (Prunus angustifolia), USA (?); NRRL T-335, from
chickasaw plum, USA (?).
Ecology:
The strains examined were both isolated from chickasaw plum
in North America. Mix (1936b, 1949) also mentions hortulan plum
(Prunus hortulana) as a possible host of T. mirabilis in North America.

The strains examined were isolated from European bird
cherry (Prunus padus) in Germany and Slovakia, and Prillinger et al.
(2000) state that T. padi occurs only in Europe. Mix (1949) examined
material collected in Sweden, and Gjaerum (1964) reported the species
in Norway.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 337.55 (MUCL 30958, PYCC 5718),
isolated from Lombardy poplar (Populus nigra), Sweden; NRRL T-497
(CBS 337.55), from Lombardy poplar, Sweden; HA 1343, from
Lombardy poplar, Slovakia; NRRL Y-17788 (ATCC 34560), from
Lombardy poplar, Switzerland; NRRL T-208, from Fremont’s cottonwood
(Pop. fremontii), North America (?); NRRL Y-6300, from
Lombardy poplar, Canada. Strains NRRL Y-6301, Y-6302, Y-6303, and
RJB 13177A, from Lombardy poplar were collected by R.J. Bandoni in
Canada.
Ecology:
Taphrina populina is a common species on different poplar
species and hybrids, but most notably on Lombardy poplar (Populus
nigra). It is widely distributed in Europe, locally throughout eastern
North America and occasionally in western North America, and has
also been reported in India, China and Japan (Mix 1949, Bacigálová
1994b). Mix (1949) was convinced that T. populina was introduced in
America along with its host (see “Additional comments”). The strains
examined were isolated from Lombardy poplar and Fremont’s cottonwood.
Other possible hosts include Populus balsamifera,
Pop. ciliata, Pop. deltoides, Pop. laurifolia and many hybrids
(Bacigálová 1994b, Gjaerum 1964, Mix 1949, 1954b).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 419.54 (NRRL T-812, PYCC 5719),
isolated from black cottonwood (Populus trichocarpa), USA; RJB
13178A, from black cottonwood (Pop. trichocarpa), collected by R.J.
Bandoni in Canada.
Ecology:
Taphrina populi-salicis appears to be restricted to the Pacific
Coast States of USA and Canada (Mix 1949). The strains examined
were isolated from black cottonwood (Pop. trichocarpa). Other hosts
listed by Mix (1949) are Populus fremontii and Salix laevigata,
although the former may actually be susceptible to infection by
strains of T. populina (see also the discussion of the latter species).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 119537 (HA 1306, PYCC 5892),
from European plum (Prunus domestica), Slovakia; HA 1340, from
sloe or blackthorn (P. spinosa), Slovakia.
Ecology:
The strains examined were isolated from European plum
(P. domestica) and sloe or blackthorn (P. spinosa) in Slovakia. Other
hosts listed by Mix (1949) are cherry plum (Prunus cerasifera var.
divaricata), bullace or damson plum (P. insititia5P. domestica subsp.
insititia) and Ussurian plum (P. ussuriensis5P. salicina var. mandshurica).
Gjaerum (1964) also listed Japanese plum (P. salicina) as a host.
According to both authors the geographic distribution of the species
comprises Northern and Central Europe, although Mix also examined
specimens obtained in Japan.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 381.39 (PYCC 5721), isolated from
Klamath or Pacific plum (Prunus subcordata), USA(?).
Ecology:
The species appears to be restricted to a single host
(P. subcordata). According to Mix (1949), the geographic distribution
includes the Rocky-Mountain and Pacific Coast areas of the USA.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 382.39 (PYCC 5723), isolated from
speckled or swamp alder (Alnus rugosa), North America; HA 850 (CBS
382.39), from speckled or swamp alder (A. rugosa), North America;
NRRL T-732 (PYCC 5888), from hazel alder (Alnus serrulata), North America.
Ecology:
Taphrina robinsoniana occurs on North American alders,
mainly in the eastern USA and Canada (Mix 1949). The strains examined
were isolated from speckled or swamp alder (Alnus rugosa5A.
incana subsp. rugosa) and hazel alder (A. serrulata), the host species
established by Mix (1954), but which he had previously ascribed to
A. incana and A. rugosa, respectively (Mix 1949).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 119538 (NRRL T-210, PYCC 5724),
isolated from sugar maple (Acer saccharum), North America.
Ecology:
This species occurs on sugar maple (A. saccharum) in eastern
and central North America (Mix 1949).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 102170 (HA 1308, PYCC 5725),
isolated from black alder (Alnus glutinosa), Bavaria, Germany; HA
1326, from black alder (A. glutinosa), Bavaria, Germany; HA 1345,
from black alder (A. glutinosa), Malé Karpaty Mountains, Slovakia;
NRRL T-713, from speckled alder (Alnus rugosa), Sweden (?).
Ecology:
This species has been found predominantly in Northern and
Central Europe on black alder (Alnus glutinosa) and only infrequently on
grey alder (A. incana) (Bacigálová 1994a). The strains examined were isolated
from black alder and speckled alder. The presence of T. sadebeckii
on the latter host seems odd since A. rugosa is native to North América,
but it is mentioned by Mix (1949) in his discussion of T. sadebeckii. He
commented on its occurrence in Sweden on the American alder: “The
trees were heavily infested, indicating that if Taphrina sadebeckii were
introduced in eastern North America a susceptible host would be waiting.”
According to Mix (1949) this species may also occur on
Manchurian alder (Alnus hirsuta) in Europe and Japan.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 339.55 (NRRL T-283, PYCC 5727),
isolated from common or dwarf cinquefoil (Potentilla canadensis),
North America; NRRL T-422, from common or dwarf cinquefoil,
North America; CBS 332.55 (as T. carnea, see “Additional
comments”).
Ecology:
Besides common or dwarf cinquefoil (Potentilla canadensis)
the following herbs may also be host species (Mix 1949,
1954b, Bacigálová 1992a): Potentilla arguta, Pot. corsica, Pot. erecta,
Pot. flabellifolia, Pot. geoides, Pot. glandulosa, Pot. recta, Pot. rupestris,
Pot. silvestris, Pot. simplex, Pot. tormentilla and Geum (Parageum)
montanum. T. tormentillae has been identified in Europe
(Bacigálová 1992a, Gjaerum 1964, Mix 1949) and eastern North
America (Mix 1949).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 276.28 (HA 1314, PYCC 5728), isolated
from black alder (Alnus glutinosa), Europe (?); NRRL T-493,
from apparent black alder, Sweden (?); strains HA 1335, HA 1346
and HA 1365, all from black alders, Slovakia. Additional strains were
studied by Bacigálová et al. (2003).
Ecology:
Taphrina tosquinetii is considered a cosmopolitan species
occurring on black alders in central, northern and eastern Europe
(Bacigálová 1994a, Bacigálová et al. 2003, Gjaerum 1964, Mix 1949).
The strains examined were isolated from A. glutinosa, but according
to Mix (1949) this species may also cause infections on Alnus crispa
var. mollis and Alnus hybrida (A. glutinosa3A. incana).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 420.54 (PYCC 5729), isolated from
red elm (Ulmus rubra), Kansas, USA.
Ecology:
Taphrina ulmi may occur in Europe or North America. The
strain examined was isolated from red elm in the USA. Other hosts
listed by Mix (1949, 1954b) are Ulmus alata, U. americana, U. crassifolia,
U. fulva (5U. rubra) and U. thomasii in North America and U. glabra
and U. laevis in Europe.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 679.93 (PYCC 5730), isolated from
a fern (Dryopteris filix-mas), collected by F. Oberwinkler (FO 36526)
in Germany; HA 244 (CBS 679.93), from Dryopteris filix-mas,
Germany.
Ecology:
Taphrina vestergrenii occurs in Northern and Central Europe
on species of Dryopteris (Gjaerum 1964, Mix 1949). The strain examined
was isolated from Dryopteris filix-mas, but Bacigálová et al.
(2002) reports D. carthusiana as a host for this species in Slovakia.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 340.55 (PYCC 5731), isolated from
American hop-hornbeam (Ostrya virginiana), USA.
Ecology:
Taphrina virginica occurs on American hop-hornbeam
(Ostrya virginiana) throughout eastern North America (Mix 1949).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 275.28 (PYCC 5732), isolated from
sweet cherry (Prunus avium), Europe(?); NRRL T-293, from sweet
cherry, geographical origin unknown; HA 1388, from European dwarf
cherry (P. fruticosa), Austria; HA 1437, from sweet cherry, Slovakia;
NRRL T-460 (PYCC 5893), from fire or pin cherry (P. pennsylvanica),
USA.
Ecology:
The strains examined were isolated from different cherry
species (P. avium, P. fruticosa and P. pennsylvanica). Other hosts listed
by Mix (1949) are P. cerasus, P. pseudocerasus, P. serrulata and
P. yedoensis. According to the same author, the geographic distribution
of the species includes Europe, North America, Australia, New
Zealand, South Africa and Japan.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
U97-412-1 (IFO 10925, NRRL Y-27308,
CBS 8765), isolated from flower of Japanese blueberry (Elaeocarpus decipiens,
Elaeocarpaceae), Iriomote Island, Japan. Other strains: U97-412-3
(IFO 10926, CBS 8766), from flower of Japanese blueberry; U97-436-2
(IFO 10927), from leaf of large-leafed orange mangrove (Bruguiera conjugata,
Rhizophoraceae); U97-437-2 (IFO 10928, CBS 8767), from leaf of
Asiatic mangrove (Rhizophora mucronata, Rhizophoraceae), all from
Iriomote Island, Japan
Ecology:
The currently available information suggests that the species
may be endemic to Iriomote Island and part of a clade that is
endemic to the Nansei archipelago.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6284 and CBS 6285, isolated from
a cockroach (Blatta orientalis, Henninger and Windisch 1976a).
Ecology:
Whether or not T. blattae is an intestinal symbiont of the
oriental cockroach is not known, as there have been no further
reports of its isolation from that or any other habitat.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
ML 4554 (CBS 8957, NRRL Y-27350),
isolated from a food processing plant, Georgia, USA (Kurtzman et al.
2004).
Ecology: unknown

Paragraph of Species Studied:
U97-101-2 (IFO 10929, NRRL Y-27309,
CBS 8762), isolated from soil, Iriomote Island, Japan.
Ecology:
The species is known from a single isolate from soil on
Iriomote Island.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
TN1-01 (TISTR 5828, JCM 12664, CBS
10093) and 20 others, isolated from forest soil, Nam Nao National
Park, Phetchabun Province, Thailand.
Ecology:
The recovery of 21 isolates in soils from three forest types
in Nam Nao National Park but of distinct relatives in Japanese and
South African localities suggest that the species is endemic to
Thailand and adjoining regions.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
U96-107-4 (IFO 10899, NRRL Y-27310,
CBS 8763) isolated from soil, Ishigaki Island, Japan; Yk-305a2 (IFO
1883), from soil, Yaku Island, Japan.
Ecology:
The recovery of strains of the species from soil of two
islands and its relatedness to plant surface isolates from the same
archipelago suggest that the species may be endemic to those
islands.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 4417 (NRRL Y-8282), isolated from
soil, J.P. van der Walt.
Ecology:
Tetrapisispora phaffii is known only from a single South
African soil isolate (van der Walt 1963).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 1146 (NRRL Y-866), a strain of
uncertain origin that was received by J.P. van der Walt from
L.J. Wickerham and designated by van der Walt (1970d) as the neotype
of Torulaspora delbrueckii; NRRL Y-172 (CBS 133), type strain of
Candida (Torula) colliculosa, isolated from ragi, Java, Indonesia; NRRL
Y-1502 (CBS 158), type strain of Torulopsis stellata var. cambresieri,
from a gummy material in a sugar refinery, A. Monoyer; NRRL
Y-1535 (CBS 404), type strain of Saccharomyces torulosus, from fermenting
juice of black grapes (Vitis sp.), Switzerland, A. Osterwalder;
NRRL Y-1567 (CBS 817), neotype strain of Torulaspora rosei, from the
Central Laboratory of the South Manchurian Railway (CLSMR); NRRL Y-1602 (CBS 705), type strain of Zygosaccharomyces mongolicus and
Saccharomyces saitoanus, from sour milk, Institute of Brewing, Tokyo,
Japan; NRRL Y-2229 (CBS 818), type strain of Torulaspora fermentati,
from sorghum brandy, Manchuria; NRRL Y-6687 (CBS 2924), type
strain of Torulaspora nilssonii, from soil, Sweden, A. Capriotti; NRRL
Y-7432 (CBS 2733), type strain of Saccharomyces vafer, substrate
unknown, K. Kominami; NRRL Y-7433 (CBS 3018), source unknown;
NRRL Y-7435 (CBS 3003), type strain of Saccharomyces inconspicuous,
from grapes, France, E. Peynard; NRRL Y-7436 (CBS 4662), from
grapes, Slovakia, E. Minárik; NRRL Y-11634 (CBS 6991), type strain of
Torulopsis taboadae, from colonche, Mexico, M. Ulloa Sosa; NRRL
Y-12643 (CBS 6339), type strain of Saccharomyces florenzani, from a
grape, Italy, G. Florenzano; NRRL Y-12652 (CBS 5448), soil, Brazil,
K. Kodama; NRRL Y-12653 (CBS 5636), type strain of Saccharomyces
microellipsoides var. osmophilus, from bark of Combretum apiculatum,
South Africa, J.P. van der Walt; NRRL YB-4770 (CBS 4865), type strain
of Schwanniomyces hominis, from a skin lesion, Brazil, A. Chaves
Batista.
Ecology:
Torulaspora delbrueckii is widely distributed in nature and
has been isolated from soil, fermenting grapes and other berry juices,
agave juice (Lachance 1995), tea-beer (Teoh et al. 2004) and tree
bark (Bhadra et al. 2008a). The role of this species in food spoilage is
discussed below.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2926 (NRRL Y-6686, NRRL
Y-17532), isolated from soil, Spain, A. Capriotti.
Ecology:
The single known strain of T. franciscae was isolated from
soil in Spain (Capriotti 1958a).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 764 (NRRL Y-12650), type strain of
Debaryomyces globosus, isolated from soil, West Indies; NRRL Y-1982
(CBS 2947), from soil, New Guinea: NRRL Y-703, NRRL Y-973, NRRL Y-
2021 (CBS 5380), sources unknown; NRRL YB-1481, from soil, Tafo,
Ghana.
Ecology:
Where recorded, isolates of T. globosa have been isolated
primarily from soil in Brazil, Ghana, New Guinea and the West
Indies. This limited number of isolations suggests that T. globosa may
be indigenous to the tropics.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NBRC 11061 (BCC 25515, CBS 10694),
type strain, isolated from the leaf of a mangrove tree, bakau (Rhizophora
stylosa, Rhizophoraceae), NBRC 11062 (BCC 25516, CBS 10695), from
soil, rhizosphere of a black mangrove (Bruguiera gymnorrhiza,
Rhizophoraceae), both from Iriomote Island, Okinawa Prefecture, Japan;
BCC 7714, BCC 15018, BCC 15195, BCC 15196, BCC 15198, BCC 15265, BCC
17685, all from moss except the last strain, which was from forest sediment,
and all fromvarious provinces, Thailand (Limtong et al. 2008b).
Ecology:
The majority of known strains of T. maleeae were isolated
from moss growing in several different provinces in Thailand. Two
additional isolates, one from a leaf of Rhizophora stylosa and one from
soil in the rhizosphere of Bruguiera gymnorrhiza, were from Iriomote
Island, Okinawa, Japan. Limtong et al. (2008b) noted that T. maleeae is
the only known species of Torulaspora to be isolated from moss.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 427 (NRRL Y-1549), isolated from
apple juice, Germany; CBS 6142 (NRRL Y-17058), CBS 6143 (NRRL
Y-17059), from tea-beer, Finland; CBS 6641 (NRRL Y-17060), from
exudate of sandalwood (Myoporum sp.), Hawaii, USA; CBS 6762
(NRRL Y-17061), from lemonade, Switzerland. The preceding strains
were identified from D1/D2 LSU rRNA gene sequence analysis.
Ecology:
The ecology of this species is poorly known. The few isolates
available for study are predominantly from high sugar substrates,
as seen from above.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2187 (NRRL Y-17251, NRRL
YB-4104), type strain of Saccharomyces pretoriensis, isolated from soil,
South Africa, J.P. van der Walt; NRRL YB-2430, from soil in a tobacco
field, Armenia.
Ecology:
The two known strains of T. pretoriensis have been isolated
from soil, but Schwan and Wheals (2003) reported that the species
was also present in natural fermentations of cocoa.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NCAIM Y.01848 (CBS 10922, NRRL
Y-48475), mating type hT; NCAIM Y.01849 (CBS 10923, NRRL Y-
48476), mating type hI; NCAIM Y.01850, mating type hT; NCAIM
Y.01851, mating type hI; all strains were isolated from moldy honey
combs, Hungary, G. Péter.
Ecology:
Trichomonascus apis is known only from moldy honey
combs in Hungary. Consistent with this habitat, the species can grow
on 50% glucose-yeast extract agar (Péter et al. 2009a).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 4856 (ATCC 22873, IFO 10192,
IGC 3818), type strain of Candida ciferrii, isolated from a cow, The
Netherlands; CBS 5165, from a fence post, The Netherlands, A.H.
Klokke; CBS 5295 (NRRL Y-10943, IFO 1854, IGC 4164), from a pig,
The Netherlands, D. Swierstra; CBS 5646 (IFO 10195), from a bovine
placenta, UK, D. Yarrow; CBS 6699 (IFO 1855, IGC 4165), from soil,
South Africa, J.P. van der Walt; CBS 215.79 (IFO 32952), type strain of
Sporothrix catenata, from calf skin, Romania; NRRL Y-7306, from a
human infection, UK, P. Austwick; NRRL Y-11580, from an ear infection,
Toronto, Canada, J. Kane.
Ecology:
Trichomonascus ciferrii is often associated with humans and
animals (de Gentile et al. 1995, Furman and Ahearn 1983, García-
Martos et al. 2004, Gunsilius et al. 2001).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 140.71 (NRRL Y-17593, IGC 4592),
isolated from a basidiocarp of Hirneola auricula-judae, Netherlands,
W. Gams; CBS 421.78, type strain of Blastobotrys gigas, from a frozen
mummy, Greenland, J. Bodenhoff; CBS 259.70, type strain of
Sporothrix fungorum, from a basidiocarp of the tinder polypore (Fomes
fomentarius), Germany, W. Gams. Other strains: from a basidiocarp of
Corticium (1); from a basidiocarp of Hirneola (1); from Sphaeriales (1).
Ecology:
Most strains of T. farinosus have been found on dead carpophores
of ascomycete and basidiomycete fungi. The species may be
somewhat psychrophilic, because the type strain of Blastobotrys gigas
was isolated from a mummy in ice (Bodenhoff et al. 1979).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
TRTC 21820, on the corticiaceous
fungus Radulomyces confluens on balsam fir wood (Abies balsamea,
Pinaceae), Ontario, Canada, H.S. Jackson; TRTC 32120, Ontario,
Canada, R. Cain.
Ecology: The species is considered a mycoparasite.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 9601 (NRRL YB-1951), isolated
from insect frass, dead conifer, McCormick’s Creek State Park,
Spencer, Indiana, USA; CBS 9602 (NRRL YB-2092), type strain, from
insect frass, dead white oak (Quercus sp., Fagaceae) Salem, Missouri,
USA; CBS 9603 (NRRL YB-2093), from insect frass, hickory (Carya sp.,
Juglandaceae) Salem, Missouri, USA, all from samples collected by L.J.
Wickerham.
Ecology:
Trichomonascus petasosporus was isolated from the frass of
tree-boring insects occurring in a conifer, an oak and a hickory tree
growing in Indiana and Missouri, USA.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-27307 (CBS 10351), isolated
from wine, California, USA, H. Stender.
Ecology:
The single known strain of T. californica was received as an
unidentified isolate from wine, with the comment (Henrik Stender,
personal communication) that it might represent a common contaminant
in California wines.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 4878 (NRRL Y-6690, NRRL
Y-17650), type strain of Torulopsis cantarellii, isolated from grape
must, South Africa, J.P. van der Walt; NRRL Y-27306, from wine,
California, USA, H. Stender. Other reported strains: CBS 5383, CBS
5445, CBS 5654, all from grape must, Japan, H. Nonomura.
Ecology:
Of the five strains of T. cantarellii commonly available from
culture collections, all have been isolated from grape must or wine,
indicating that grapes or grape-growing areas are the primary habitat
of this species.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 1040 (NRRL Y-1579), CBS 1041
(NRRL Y-7769), isolated from beer, Germany, H. Schachner; CBS 4095
(NRRL Y-7770), from grapes, Brazil, O. Verona.
Ecology:
Strains of T. variabilis have been isolated from beer and
grapes, but the frequency of isolation is low.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 4077 (NRRL Y-5715), isolated from
grape must, Japan, H. Nonomura.
Ecology:
The single known strain of T. vinaria was isolated from
grape must (Ohara et al. 1960).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2163 ( NRRL Y-8283), isolated
from soil, South Africa; NRRL Y-2397, NRRL Y-2400, van der Walt;
SUB 87-417.1, from fruit, Stenocereus pruinosus (Cactaceae), Chiapas,
Mexico.
Ecology:
Vanderwaltozyma polyspora is only known from van der
Walt’s original soil isolates and a single strain from a cactus fruit. It
would therefore be premature to speculate about the possible adaptive
function of the multi-spored state in this yeast.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2684, type strain of Candida tannotolerans
and CBS 6070, both isolated from tanning liquors containing
tree bark, F.H. Jacob, France; CBS 8242, a stable diploid obtained
by crossing auxotrophic subcultures of CBS 2684 (?) and CBS 6070
(a) (van der Walt et al. 1986b).
Ecology:
The liquors from which strains of V. yarrowii were isolated
contained approximately 6% tannins extracted from the bark of various
trees (Jacob 1970). Whether or not this isolation source is significant
in defining the niche of this yeast is not known. The three
strains examined grew well on yeast nitrogen base agar supplemented
with 0.5% tannic acid as the carbon source, which is not particularly
unusual. Many other yeasts in the Saccharomyces clade also
grow on that medium.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 4565 (IFO 1116, NRRL YB-4819),
type strain, isolated from the dung of a wild squirrel (Calloseiurus
erythraeus thaiwanensis), Japan, M. Soneda; CBS 6627 (NRRL
Y-17358), from an unspecified substrate, France, F. Hinzelin.
Ecology: unknown

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UWOPS 95-604.3 (CBS 8456, NRRL
Y-27360) and other strains, isolated from flowers of morning glory
(Ipomoea spp., Convolvulaceae); UWOPS 95-631.3 (CBS 8457) and other
strains, from flowers of Hibiscus spp. (Malvaceae); UWOPS 95-686.3,
and other strains, from nitidulid beetles (Aethina spp., Coleoptera:
Nitidulidae); UWOPS 95-737.2 and other strains, from a fruit fly
(Drosophila hibisci), in New South Wales, Queensland, and Northern
Territory, Australia, and from Fiji and Rarotonga (Cook Islands); UWOPS
05-260.2, and another strain from a nitidulid beetle (Eupuraea gestroi,
Coleoptera: Nitidulidae), and UWOPS 05-264.4 from Drosophila sp., in
flowers of Ipomoea cairica, Cameron Highlands, Malaysia.
Ecology:
The distribution of W. australiensis extends across the
Australasia-Pacific biogeographic region, matching to a large extent
the distribution of the genus Aethina, a nitidulid beetle that occupies
with Drosophila species the ephemeral flowers of Hibiscus and
Ipomoea species. The species is one of a handful in that ecosystem,
that is known to span the Wallace line, but it has not been isolated
in Hawai’i where Kodamaea anthophila and a few other South Pacific
species have apparently been introduced together with Aethina concolor
(Lachance et al. 2001e). The absence of W. australiensis may be
the result of competitive exclusion by W. occidentalis and W. lipophila,
both of which are abundant in Hawai’i.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UFMG 96-267 (CBS 8454, NRRL
Y-27362), UFMG 96-381 (CBS 8455), and one other strain, isolated
from flowers of columnar cactus (Cereus pernambucensis); UFMG 95-
343.2, from a flower of columnar cactus (Pilosocereus arrabidae);
UFMG 96-LS32 and UFMG LS-34, from flowers of Cereus calcirupicola,
all from the states of Rio de Janeiro and Minas Gerais, Brazil
Ecology:
The original isolates of W. cacticola came from flowers of
columnar cacti where they were ostensibly vectored by drosophilids
or beetles. Later isolations demonstrated that they occur in nitidulid
beetles found in the flowers (Lachance et al. 2001e). The species may
be endemic to South America.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-6692 (CBS 4351), type strain
of Torulopsis domercqiae, isolated from a wine vat, South Africa;
NRRL Y-6698 (CBS 4733), type strain of Torulopsis saccharum,
from effluent from a sugar cane factory, Brazil.
Ecology:
The species is rare, making ecological generalizations
uncertain.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
UWOPS 91-681.3 (CBS 8458, NRRL
Y-27367) and other strains, isolated from flowers of morning glory
(Ipomoea spp., Convolvulaceace); UWOPS 00-340.1 (CBS 8812) and
other strains, from a fruit fly (Drosophila floricola); UWOPS 87-2199.1
and other strains, from an endemic drosophilid (Exaloscaptomyza calliginosa,
Diptera: Drosophilidae); UWOPS 00-710.3, from a nitidulid
beetle (Conotelus mexicanus, Coleoptera: Nitidulidae); UWOPS 00-
657.3, from a nitidulid beetle (Prosopeus subaeneus, Coleoptera:
Nitidulidae), Hawai’i.
Ecology:
The species stands out by its narrow range of growth abilities
contrasted with strong hydrolysis of Tween 80. Most strains reported
as “Candida species L” by Lachance et al. (1988) were later identified as
W. lipophila, and a few as W. occidentalis. The distribution data clearly
suggested a strong association between the two species and drosophilids
found in morning glories, in contrast to Metschnikowia and related
species, which appeared to be associated with another substrate, later
found to be the nitidulid beetles that visit the same flowers (Lachance
et al. 2001e). Unlike W. occidentalis, W. lipophila has hitherto been isolated
only in Hawai’i, and is abundant there. The possibility exists that
it is endemic to Hawai’i in association with endemic drosophilids such
as Exalloscaptomyza calliginosa. The yeasts may be involved in enriching
the flies’ diet by converting flower lipids into a nutritionally richer
biomass consumed by the flies.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
(Conotelus obscurus, Coleoptera,
Nitidulidae) collected in morning glory (Ipomoea pandurata,
Convolvulaceae), Tennessee, USA; UFMG95-401.2, from a flower of
Ipomoea cairica; UFMG96-197, from Conotelus sp.; UFMG96-212 (CBS
8453), from a flower of Ipomoea carnea var. fistulosa, Minas Gerais,
Brazil; UWOPS 91-698.4 (CBS 8452, NRRL Y-27364), isolated from a
flower of Ipomoea indica, Island of Hawai’i, and other strains from
flowers of various morning glories (Ipomoea spp.); UWOPS 87-2197.2
and other strains, from Drosophila floricola; UWOPS 00-355.4, and
other strains from Conotelus spp. (Coleoptera: Nitidulidae); UWOPS
00-618.2, and other strains from nitidulid beetle (Aethina concolor,
Coleoptera, Nitidulidae); UWOPS 00-623c2, from a bee, Hawaii;
UWOPS 99-323.1 and other strains, from Conotelus sp. from flowers of
a Bignonaceous vine; UWOPS 01-114.2 and other strains, from nitidulid
beetle (Carpophilus sp., Coleoptera, Nitidulidae); UWOPS 01-141c1,
from a dipter collected on Ipomoea indica; UWOPS 01-142c2, from
Conotelus sp., Guanacaste Province, Costa Rica.
Ecology:
Wickerhamiella occidentalis is the most widespread of
Wickerhamiella species, having been isolated from morning glories
and their insects in Hawai’i as well as South, Central and North
America. The distribution to some extent parallels that of Drosophila
floricola, which is known to occur in warmer parts of the Americas
and to have been introduced to the Hawaiian archipelago in the 20th
century (Montague and Kaneshiro 1982). The northernmost samples
came from localities in Tennessee, USA, where drosophilids can be
observed in flowers. However, samples taken from Convolvulaceae
and their beetles in the Great Lakes (USA/Canada) area, as well as
coastal Maine, USA, and Southern Québec, Canada, where drosophilids
are absent from the flowers, did not yield members of the
Wickerhamiella clade.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6986 (UCD-FST 68-928A, NRRL
Y-11625), Agassiz, British Columbia, Canada; CBS 6987 (UCD-FST 68-
940, NRRL Y-11626), Vancouver Island, British Columbia, Canada; CBS
6988 (UCD-FST 68-985, NRRL Y-11627), Olympic National Park,
Washington, USA. All strains were isolated from the flux of alder (Alnus
rubra) trees (Phaff et al. 1979).
Ecology:
The three presently known strains of W. alni are from fluxes
in alder trees growing in the State of Washington, USA and the
Province of British Columbia, Canada (Phaff et al. 1979). Further sampling
may showalders to be the primary habitat of this species.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-366 (CBS 5759), received from
F.W. Fabian, USA, as Willia anomala Saito; NRRL Y-102, NRRL Y-945,
unknown sources; NRRL Y-993 (CBS 113), type strain of Willia schneggii;
NRRL Y-1773, from J.E. Mackinnon, Argentina?, clinical source?;
NRRL Y-1783 (CBS 605), type strain of Candida pelliculosa, from
infected human lung, P. Redaelli, Italy; NRRL Y-12811 (CBS 8021),
type strain of Hansenula ukrainica, from phyllosphere of a pedunculate
oak (Quercus robur), Ukraine, I.P. Bab’eva. Identification of the
preceding strains as W. anomalus was from nuclear DNA reassociation
experiments (Kurtzman 1984b, 1992). The following other
strains were examined but their identity is from phenotype: NRRL Y-
7081, from wheat flour, Midwest, USA, C.P. Kurtzman; NRRL Y-7391,
NRRL Y-7394, from smoked fermented sausage, Philadelphia,
Pennsylvania, USA, J. Naghski; NRRL Y-7406, from crop of a pigeon,
Maryland, USA, H.F. Hasenclever; NRRL Y-7437, NRRL Y-7439, from
bovine semen, Iowa, USA, J. Richard; NRRL Y-12790, from human
blood, New York, USA, I. Weitzman.
Ecology:
Wickerhamomyces anomalus is widespread in nature, occurring
in soil, plant material and as an opportunistic pathogen of
humans and animals. Presumably the primary habitat of this species
is plants, and Sláviková et al. (2007) reported W. anomalus to be one
of the most frequent yeasts isolated from leaves and needles of 10
different tree species growing in the Small Carpathian mountain
range of Slovakia.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 1890 (NRRL Y-1482), isolated from
frass from insect tunnels in the bark of a spruce tree (Abies sp.), Austria,
O. Beck; CBS 6468 (NRRL Y-11610) from human scalp, Finland, M.
Laaksonen
Ecology:
The type strain of W. bisporus was from insect tunnels in a
spruce tree, but a second strain represented a clinical isolate leaving
the natural habitat of this species uncertain.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2616 (NRRL YB-4184), isolated
from the cecum of a cow, Portugal, N. van Uden; NRRL Y-6627, NRRL
Y-6628, from unknown substrate, Spain, J. Santa María; NRRL Y-
12831 (IFO 1886), from leaf litter, Japan, M. Mikata. The latter three
strains were identified from phenotype.
Ecology:
Taysi and van Uden (1964) reported isolating eight strains
of W. bovis from Atlantic Ocean waters near the Portuguese shore
between Cabo da Roca and Lisbon. Pignal et al. (1988) isolated yeasts
from the digestive tract of the beetle Ips sexdentatus (Scolytidae) that
had infested several species of conifers, and identified W. bovis from
among the isolates. However, the ecology of W. bovis is likely to be
uncertain, because only the type strain has been characterized from
gene sequence analysis.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-1888 (CBS 1992), isolated
from insect frass from a red pine (Pinus resinosa), Ontario, Canada, L.
J. Wickerham; NRRL Y-1514 (CBS 601), type strain of Candida melinii,
from wood pulp, Sweden, M. Melin; NRRL Y-1782 (CBS 1461), from
wood pulp, Sweden, E. Rennerfelt; NRRL Y-1987 (CBS 2430), from Ips
sp., on an Engelmann spruce (Picea engelmannii), Steamboat Springs,
Colorado, USA, R. Davidson; NRRL Y-2340 (CBS 2431), type strain of
Hansenula wingei, from dead conifier, Medicine Bow Mountains,
Colorado, USA, L.J. Wickerham; NRRL Y-2341, from frass, Engelmann
spruce, Dillon, Montana, USA, H.H. Hendron; NRRL YB-1915, frass,
dead conifer, L.J. Wickerham; NRRL YB-1916, from frass, dead conifer,
L.J. Wickerham; NRRL YB-1931, from termite frass, pine tree (Pinus
sp.), Spencer, Indiana, USA, L.J. Wickerham; NRRL YB-4170 (CBS
5676), from frass, eastern white pine (Pinus strobus), L.J. Wickerham; NRRL Y-1888 (CBS 1992), isolated
from insect frass from a red pine (Pinus resinosa), Ontario, Canada, L.
J. Wickerham; NRRL Y-1514 (CBS 601), type strain of Candida melinii,
from wood pulp, Sweden, M. Melin; NRRL Y-1782 (CBS 1461), from
wood pulp, Sweden, E. Rennerfelt; NRRL Y-1987 (CBS 2430), from Ips
sp., on an Engelmann spruce (Picea engelmannii), Steamboat Springs,
Colorado, USA, R. Davidson; NRRL Y-2340 (CBS 2431), type strain of
Hansenula wingei, from dead conifier, Medicine Bow Mountains,
Colorado, USA, L.J. Wickerham; NRRL Y-2341, from frass, Engelmann
spruce, Dillon, Montana, USA, H.H. Hendron; NRRL YB-1915, frass,
dead conifer, L.J. Wickerham; NRRL YB-1916, from frass, dead conifer,
L.J. Wickerham; NRRL YB-1931, from termite frass, pine tree (Pinus
sp.), Spencer, Indiana, USA, L.J. Wickerham; NRRL YB-4170 (CBS
5676), from frass, eastern white pine (Pinus strobus), L.J. Wickerham; NRRL YB-4660 (CBS 5677), from dead tree, Canada, L.J. Wickerham;
NRRL YB-4662 (CBS 5678), from dead tree, Canada, L.J. Wickerham. .
Ecology:
Strains of W. canadensis are predominantly from insect frass
obtained from pine and spruce trees in the U.S. and Canada
(Wickerham 1951, 1956). The CBS Website lists other strains from
tree-invading larvae in Chile and a strain isolated from the lungs of a
black shrew in Sri Lanka, but the identity of these isolates needs to
be confirmed from gene sequences.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 1900 (NRRL Y-2378), isolated from
tanning liquor, Italy, J. Boidin.
Ecology:
The single known strain of W. chambardii was isolated from
tanning liquid and is likely to have been associated with trees.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 111 (NRRL Y-1031), isolated from
pod from the Tonka-bean tree (Dipteryx odorata), Dominican Republic, R.
Ciferri; NRRL Y-1322, mycelial variant from NRRL Y-1031, L.J. Wickerham.
Ecology:
Wickerhamomyces ciferrii is presently known only from one
available strain that was obtained from the pod of a Tonka-bean tree,
but Spencer et al. (1996) reported the species to be common on pods
and exudates from algarrobo (Prosopis spp.) and acacia (Acacia spp.)
trees growing in northwest Argentina.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL YB-4128 (CBS 7208), isolated from
frass in a dead, cut oak (Quercus sp.), Camp Sargent, New Hampshire,
USA, L.J. Wickerham; NRRL YB-4153, from an acorn, shingle oak
(Quercus imbricaria), Bradley Park, Peoria, Illinois, USA, L.J. Wickerham.
Ecology:
The two known strains of W. hampshirensis are from oak
trees and may be associated with the frass of insect larvae.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6695 (NRRL Y-7723), the only
available strain of this species, was isolated from uncultivated grassland
soil collected near Pretoria, South Africa by J.P. van der Walt.
Ecology:
The description of W. lynferdii was based on a single strain
that had been isolated from grassland soil collected near Pretoria,
South Africa (van der Walt and Johannsen 1975b). Since then, Silva
et al. (2000) reported W. lynferdii to be common among microorganisms
associated with the natural fermentation of coffee cherries
(Coffea arabica) that were processed in the State of Minas Gerais,
Brazil. Mushtaq et al. (2007a,b) isolated W. lynferdii from butter
made in the Karachi region of Pakistan, and they also reported W.
lynferdii to be common in the nectar of flowers from the shrubs
Chinese hibiscus (Hibiscus rosa-sinensis) and jungle geranium (Ixora
coccinea), both growing in Karachi, Pakistan. Strains from the studies
of Silva et al. (2000) and Mushtaq et al. (2007a, 2007b) were identified
from phenotype, and before it can be concluded that W. lynferdii
is common worldwide, the identity of the strains needs to be verified
from gene sequence analysis.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL YB-1344 (CBS 6341), isolated
soil, Marion, Illinois, USA, L.J. Wickerham; NRRL Y-7934 (CBS 6884),
from soil, South Africa, J.P. van der Walt, conspecific with NRRL YB-
1344 based on nuclear DNA reassociation experiments (C.P.
Kurtzman, unpublished data).
Ecology:
Wickerhamomyces mucosus is known from two isolates, one
from soil in Illinois, USA, and the other from soil in South Africa, as
noted under “Origin of the strains studied”.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 5587 (NRRL Y-7123), isolated
from an infected human nail, The Netherlands, M. Bruining; CBS
5649 (NRRL Y-11526), from dust, Germany, E. Friedrich; CBS 6573
(NRRL Y-27126), seawater, Southern Ocean, J.W. Fell. Conspecificity of
the preceding three strains was determined from D1/D2 LSU rRNA
gene sequence comparisons (C.P. Kurtzman, unpublished data).
Ecology:
The primary habitat of this species is unknown. Isolates
have been obtained from an infected human nail, dust, sputum and
seawater, as noted above.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 2887 (NRRL YB-4309), isolated
from buttermilk, South Africa, J.P. van der Walt; NRRL YB-810, from
blackberry fruit (Rubus sp.), Marion, Illinois, USA, L.J. Wickerham.
Conspecificity of the two strains was determined from D1/D2 LSU
rRNA gene sequence analysis (C.P. Kurtzman, unpublished data).
Ecology:
Unknown. The two available isolates of W. pijperi are from
different habitats, i.e., buttermilk from South Africa and blackberry
fruit from Illinois, USA.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6797 (NRRL Y-7945), isolated
from feces of an African snail, Rabaul, New Britain, Papua New
Guinea, M. Soneda; CBS 6908 (NRRL Y-11533), from a rat liver,
Nigeria, H.C. Gugnani; NRRL YB-4344, from watermelon (Citrullus
lanatus), commercial market, Chicago, Illinois, USA; CBS 6908 was
identified from phenotype, but the other two strains were identified
from D1/D2 LSU rRNA gene sequence analysis (Kurtzman and
Robnett 1998a, C.P. Kurtzman, unpublished data).
Ecology:
The ecology of this species is uncertain because the three
available isolates are from diverse habitats, i.e., snail excrement, rat
liver and a watermelon.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-1678 (CBS 1705), NRRL Y-1679
(CBS 1706), isolated from gum of wild black cherry trees (Prunus serotina),
Peoria, Illinois, USA, L.J. Wickerham; NRRL YB-3450, from gum of
a wild pin cherry tree (Prunus pensylvanica), Wisconsin, USA, L.J.
Wickerham; NRRL Y-7005 (CBS 5800, JCM 1516), type strain of
Endomycopsis muscicola, from moss, Tottori Prefecture, Japan.
Ecology:
The majority of W. silvicola isolates are from the gums of
cherry trees growing in the eastern half of the US (Wickerham 1951).
An exception is the strain described as Endomycopsis muscicola,
which was isolated from moss growing in Japan (Nakase and
Komagata 1966). In view of the geographic separation of these two
habitats, it would be of interest to compare the various isolates from
gene sequences other than D1/D2.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-2383 (CBS 2939), isolated
from tanned leather, France, C. Ramírez; NRRL Y-6730 (CBS 2940,
Boidin 75D), NRRL Y-6731 (NRRL Y-11547, NRRL Y-11981, CBS 5005,
Boidin 75E), tanned leather, France, J. Boidin.
Ecology:
Presently known isolates are from tanned leather (Ramírez
and Boidin 1953a) and were probably associated with trees used to
make tanning liquor.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL Y-1029, NRRL Y-1308, NRRL
Y-1318, NRRL Y-1319, strains from C.L. Bedford that had been isolated
from sugar egg concentrate, syrup, grape juice, and dried prunes,
USA; NRRL Y-1096, labeled Zygosaccharomyces soya, soy sauce flavoring
strain, China, P. King; NRRL Y-1813   NRRL Y-1838, from fermenting
cucumbers, North Carolina, USA, J.L. Etchells; NRRL YB-3328,
authentic strain of Pseudohansenula peiping; from soy sauce, China;
CBS 7164 (NRRL Y-17244), authentic strain of Hansenula arabitolgenes,
from jam, China.
Ecology:
Wickerhamomyces subpelliculosus is typically isolated from
high osmotic substrates, especially high salt or high sugar foods,
such as brined vegetables and jams (Etchells and Bell 1950a,b).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 5995 (NRRL Y-7130), CBS 5986
(NRRL Y-10995), CBS 5987 (NRRL Y-10996), isolated from frass from
tunnels of the Bostrichid beetle (Sinonylon ruficorne), infesting the
shrub red bush willow (Combretum apiculatum); CBS 6152 (NRRL Y-
17352), type strain of Candida nitrativorans, from insect tunnels in
Cryptocarya latifolia (Lauraceae); CBS 6153 (NRRL Y-10977), frass
from tunnels in the shrub known as the coastal red milkweed
(Mimusops caffra), all from South Africa.
Ecology:
With the exception noted below, W. sydowiorum has been
isolated from insect frass in several different shrubs in South Africa.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6701 (NRRL Y-7904), isolated
from exudate of a willow (Salix sp.), Japan, K. Kodama; NRRL Y-27710
(BG 02-7-16-011A-1-1), from the gut of the insect Amphix cincta
(Endomychidae), Barro Colorado Island, Panama (Suh et al. 2005b).
Ecology:
Little is known of the ecology of Y. akitaensis. One strain
was isolated from the exudate of a willow in Japan (Kodama 1975),
and the second known strain was from the gut of an insect collected
in Panama (Suh et al. 2005b).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 7066 (UCD-FST 76-308A, NRRL
Y-11818), isolated from agria cactus (Stenocereus gummosus),
Palmilla, Baja California Sur, Mexico; CBS 7067 (UCD-FST 76-391B,
NRRL Y-11819), from organ-pipe cactus (Stenocereus thurberi), Rancho
Cuñaño, Baja California Sur, Mexico; CBS 6023 (NRRL Y-17683), type
strain of Candida terebra, from soil, Japan; CBS 5815 (NRRL Y-17672),
type strain of Candida veronae, from grape must, Italy; CBS 6306
(NRRL Y-7785), type strain of Candida entomaea, from an insect tunnel
in pine (Pinus radiata), South Africa; NRRL Y-27174, CBS 8159),
unknown source, Japan; NRRL Y-12806, clinical isolate, USA; NRRL
Y-27059 (CBS 2089), residue from pressed olives, Italy; NRRL
Y-27094 (CBS 4434), from cow with acute mastitis, Sweden. The following
strains were isolated by L.J. Wickerham: NRRL YB-1265, NRRL
YB-1267, NRRL YB-1297, all from insect frass, short leaf pine (Pinus
echinata), Piney Woods, Mississippi, USA; NRRL YB-2642, insect frass,
cottonwood tree (Populus deltoides), USA; NRRL YB-3130, from
Japanese plum tree (Prunus sp.), New Orleans, Louisiana, USA; NRRL
YB-4162, gum exudate of a black cherry tree (Prunus serotina),
Peoria, Illinois, USA.
Ecology:
When first described, Y. mexicana was known only from
decayed tissue in cereoid cacti (Stenocereus thurberi, S. gummosus,
Pachycereus pringlei and Opuntia spp.) from the North American
Sonoran Desert at locations in Baja California Sur, Mexico; Sonora,
Mexico; and Arizona, USA (Miranda et al. 1982). This suggested that
the species might be specific to cactus-inhabiting areas. However, as
listed under “Origin of the strains studied”, the three Candida species
that are conspecific with Y. mexicana were isolated from soil (Japan),
grape must (Italy) and a pine tree (South Africa). Strains isolated by
L.J. Wickerham from trees in various regions of the eastern U.S. were
later identified from their D1/D2 sequences as Y. mexicana.
Consequently, the species appears to be nearly worldwide in distribution,
and can be isolated from a variety of habitats.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6700 (NRRL Y-7903), isolated
from exudate of an oak (Quercus myrsinaeforia), Japan, K. Kodama;
NRRL YB-2808, from insect frass in a Japanese zelkova (Zelkova serrata,
Ulmaceae), USA; NRRL YB-3099, from insect frass in a birch tree
(Betula sp.), Big Lake, Wisconsin, USA, L.J. Wickerham.
Ecology:
The three known strains of Y. nakazawae have been isolated
from insect frass from deciduous trees growing in the northern
hemisphere.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6696 (NRRL Y-7813), CBS 6725
(NRRL Y-7814), both isolated from grassland soil; NRRL Y-7765,
unknown substrate, all from South Africa, J.P. van der Walt.
Ecology: Known isolates are from grassland soil.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 4802 (NRRL Y-5512), CBS 4803
(NRRL Y-5513), isolated from frass of the bark beetle Scolytus ventralis
in fir (Abies concolor), California, USA; CBS 5006 (NRRLY-11539), CBS
5454 (NRRL Y-11540), CBS 5455 (NRRL Y-11541), from insect frass in
balsam fir (Abies balsamea), California, USA, the preceding stains
were from H.J. Phaff; NRRL Y-6027, NRRL Y-6096, from insect frass in
pine trees (Pinus sp.), unspecified location, USA; NRRL Y-7908, NRRL
Y-7910, from bark beetle frass, douglas fir tree (Pseudotsuga menziesii),
unspecified location, USA; NRRL YB-1243, NRRL YB-1403, from
beetle frass, Lake Wabatongushi, Ontario, Canada, L.J. Wickerham;
NRRL YB-1503, from beetle frass, Coulter pine (Pinus coulteri), Santa
Barbara, California, USA.
Ecology:
Known isolates of Y. scolyti have been isolated from insect
frass in beetle damaged fir and pine trees growing in the U.S. and
Canada. Boone et al. (2008) presented evidence that certain microorganisms,
including Y. scolyti, attract parasitoids and dipteran predators
to their bark beetle prey.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 4094 (NRRL Y-5714), isolated from
tamari soya, Japan (Ohara and Nonomura 1954c); NRRL Y-27109 (CBS
5280), from human lung tissue, The Netherlands; NRRL Y-27114 (CBS
8007), from seawater, near Sicily, Italy. CBS 7551, not examined in this
study, was isolated from pickled Chinese mushrooms, The Netherlands.
Ecology:
The ecology of Y. triangularis is unresolved as the four
known strains are from different substrates. However, a unifying
theme is that three of the isolates are from saline environments

Paragraph of Species Studied:
NRRL YB-423 (CBS 6124), type strain
of Y. lipolytica, NRRL YB-419, NRRL YB-420, NRRL YB-421 (CBS 6125),
NRRL YB-422, all isolated by L.J. Wickerham from milled corn (maize)
fiber tailings, Illinois, USA; NRRL Y-321 (CBS 2071), type strain of Pseudomonilia deformans (which is closely related to Y. lipolytica), isolated
from a fingernail, Austria, F. Zach; NRRL Y-323 (CBS 2070), type
strain of Monilia cornealis, from a corneal lesion, Italy, G. Pollaccii;
NRRL Y-1094, NRRL Y-1095 (CBS 6317), unknown source, USA?, used
for citric acid production from hydrocarbons; NRRL Y-5383 NRRL
Y-5386, from petroleum storage tanks in Iowa and South Dakota,
USA, R.S. Flippin; NRRL Y-7207, NRRL Y-7208, from cold-stored frankfurters,
USA, D.G. Ahearn; NRRL Y-7484, from sputum, Cleveland,
Ohio, USA, J.W. Heller; NRRL Y-7751 NRRL Y-7757, from refrigerated
meat products, Virginia, USA, R.W. Bothast; NRRL Y-7817, from
refrigerated Canadian bacon, Peoria, Illinois, USA, C.P. Kurtzman;
NRRL Y-11853 (IBFM 183), NRRL Y-11854 (IBFM 184), authentic
strains of Saccharomycopsis pseudolipolytica, both from soil, Russia,
V.M. Blagodatskaya.
Ecology:
Yarrowia lipolytica is widespread in nature, as seen from
the sources of isolation, some of which are given above. Substrates
high in lipids are a common source of this species. Whether Y. lipolytica
has a primary habitat in nature is unknown, but it is often found
in marine environments (Hagler and Mendonça-Hagler 1979),
including hyper-saline waters such as the Dead Sea and the Great
Salt Lake of Utah, USA (Butinar et al. 2005).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
Mating types a: CBS 4028 and CBS
6736 (NRRL Y-7923), isolated from washings of ion exchange resin, T.
Nakase, type strain of Candida inositophila; CBS 7652, from skin of a
foot, Sweden, B. Petrini; CBS 9640, from human blood, M.E. Brandt,
USA (Brandt et al. 2004). Mating types ?: CBS 5839 (NRRL Y-7136),
from mastitic bovine udder, J.P. van der Walt, type strain of Candida
steatolytica; CBS 6726, from equipment in soft drink factory,
Germany, A.M. van Grinsven; CBS 6779, from deep-frozen orange
juice, Germany, H. Scholer; CBS 8424 (NCYC 2304), from a fermentation
vessel, S. Campbell.
Ecology:
As listed under “Origin of the strains studied”, the majority
of Z. hellenicus isolates have been obtained either from human and
animal infections or from fruit drinks.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
Mating types a: CBS 4075, isolated
from grape must, Japan, H. Nonomura; CBS 4099 (NRRL Y-17319),
from fermenting grape must, Greece, O. Verona, type strain of
Trichosporon hellenicum; CBS 6173, from organic acid fermentation,
Israel, R.I. Mateles; CBS 6360, from tunnel of Xyleborus ferrugineus,
South Africa, D.B. Scott; CBS 7115, from synthetic medium of sucrose
and ammonium, pH 1.5 3.5, Israel, J.N. Groot. Mating types ?: CBS
7521 (NRRL Y 17436), from rotten pear, China, X. Lu, type strain of
Pichia hangzhouana; CBS 8425, from fruit of Opuntia stricta, Great
Inagua Island, Bahamas, M.-A. Lachance; CBS 8426, from Drosophila
muelleri, on fruit of Opuntia, Great Inagua Island, Bahamas,
M.-A. Lachance.
Ecology:
Zygoascus meyerae is known from various substrates, such as
grape must and rotten fruits, and appears worldwide in distribution

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 8129 (CBS 6851, NRRL Y-10998,
IFO 10709), isolated from soil, Ofuna, Japan, J.A. Barnett.
Ecology:
The single known strain of Z. ofunaensis was isolated from
soil in Japan.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 6065 (NRRL Y-17392), type strain of
Pichia tannicola, CBS 6067 (NRRL Y-7499), type strain of Pichia abadieae,
both were isolated from vegetable tanning fluid, France, F.H. Jacob.
Ecology:
At present, Z. tannicolus has been found only in
vegetable tanning fluid.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 680 (NCYC 1416, NRRL Y-2227),
type strain of Saccharomyces bailii, from Institute of Brewing, Tokyo;
CBS 685 (NCYC 563), isolated from sorghum brandy mash; CBS 749
(NCYC 573), from sour red wine, USA; NCYC 464, sweet pickle, UK;
NCYC 1427, origin unknown; NCYC 1553, from salad cream; NCYC
1766, from grape and blackcurrant juice, UK; NCYC 2790, from anthocyanin
liquid from grape skins.
Ecology:
Zygosaccharomyces bailii is widely distributed and is most
often associated with food spoilage, particularly of acidified, preserved
foods containing high concentrations of fermentable sugars
(Thomas and Davenport 1985). Sources from which Z. bailii has been
isolated include honey, fruit juice and juice concentrates, grape must,
mayonnaise, salad dressing, sweet pickle, vinegar, wine and soft
drinks (Barnett et al. 2000a, Kurtzman 1990c, Thomas and Davenport
1985). Z. bailii is not part of the normal yeast flora of well-run food
factories, and where it does occur, the number of Z. bailii isolates in
the yeast population is usually small (Steels 2005). The natural habitat
of Z. bailii is most probably in dehydrated, “mummified” fruit
lying beneath fruit trees or gummy exudates from trees (Davenport
1975, Thomas and Davenport 1985).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 702 (NCYC 1495, NRRL Y-12626),
from K. Saito; CBS 1083 (NCYC 1496), from tea-beer fungus, Java; CBS
2449 (NCYC 1497), from pickled cucumbers, USA; NCYC 171, origin
unknown
Ecology:
Zygosaccharomyces bisporus, like Z. bailii, is often foodassociated,
although it does not appear to be recovered with the
same frequency. Observations of spoilage in soft drinks indicated
that Z. bailii was implicated at 10 times the frequency of Z. bisporus
(M. Stratford, unpublished data). Foods from which it has been isolated
include pickled cucumbers and salad dressing (Barnett et al.
2000a, Kurtzman 1990c). Other sources of Z. bisporus include tea
beer fungus (Barnett et al. 2000a), and soft drinks (M. Stratford,
unpublished data).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 8849 (NCYC 2999, NRRL YB-
4811), isolated from kombucha tea, Russia; CBS 8850 (NCYC 3001),
from kombucha tea, USA; NCYC 3000 (NRRL Y-27162), from kombucha
tea, USA.
Ecology:
All currently characterized strains of Z. kombuchaensis have
been isolated from kombucha tea (a fermented tea-based beverage)
from either Russia or the USA (Kurtzman et al. 2001d).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 8574 (NCYC 2789, formerly NCYC
D2627; NRRL Y-27276), isolated from spoiled orange juice, UK; CBS
8516 (NCYC 1601), from spoiled orange squash; CBS 8517 (NCYC
2406; NRRL Y-27275), from spoiled tomato ketchup, UK; NCYC 2955,
origin unknown; NCYC 3055, from spoiled pear and blackcurrant
squash drink, Ireland; NCYC 3101, origin unknown.
Ecology:
Zygosaccharomyces lentus has been isolated from different
fruit-based drinks, including pear and blackcurrant squash, orange
juice and orange squash, as well as from tomato ketchup and wine
(this study; Steels et al. 1999).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 736 (NCYC 2403, NRRL Y-12628),
isolated from honey, USA; NCYC 2998, from honey; NCYC 3005, origin
unknown; NCYC 3009, from alpéchin; NCYC 3010, from alpéchin,
Spain.
Ecology:
Zygosaccharomyces mellis, like Z. rouxii, is typically found in
highly osmotic habitats (Kurtzman 1990c). Strains of Z. mellis have
been isolated from a variety of sources including alpéchin, honey,
strawberry juice, sugar, and wine grapes (Barnett et al. 2000a).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 732 (NCYC 568, NRRL Y-229),
type strain of Zygosaccharomyces gracilis ssp. italicus, isolated from
concentrated black grape must, Italy; CBS 686 (NCYC 583), type
strain of Zygosaccharomyces nadsonii, from bonbon of bitter orange
syrup, France; CBS 730 (NCYC 561), type strain of Zygosaccharomyces
variabilis, from wine grapes, Germany; CBS 731 (NCYC 567), from
Portuguese white wine; CBS 4357 (NCYC 1522), from salted beans,
The Netherlands; CBS 7804 (NCYC 381), from raw cane sugar; NCYC
720, from pineapple jam; NCYC 2700, from wort.
Ecology:
Zygosaccharomyces rouxii, like its close relative Z. mellis, is
typically found in highly osmotic habitats (Kurtzman 1990c). Strains
of Z. rouxii have been isolated from a wide variety of sources, including
cane sugar, chocolate syrup, concentrated black grape must,
honey, jam, maple syrup, marmalade, marzipan, miso, red wine,
salted beans, soft drinks and soy sauce (Barnett et al. 2000a,
Kurtzman 1990c).

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 746 (NRRL Y-1560), isolated from
grape must, Italy; CBS 748 (NRRL Y-1558), type strain of
Zygosaccharomyces eupagycus, from orange drink, Italy; CBS 6081
(NRRL Y-12642), from mountain laurel (Rhododendron sp.), Japan;
NRRL YB-4286, isolated from a fruit fly (Drosophila pseudoobscura),
California, USA, H.J. Phaff.
Ecology:
Of the four known strains, two are from fruit products and
a third is from a fruit fly, which suggests that fruit may be a common
source for Z. florentina.

Paragraph of Species Studied:
CBS 4218 (NRRL Y-12654), CBS 4219
(NRRL Y-12655), both from silage, Italy.
Ecology:
The two known strains of Z. mrakii were isolated from
silage in Italy (Capriotti 1958c).
